text: Hon. R. G. Halverson OBE) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers. AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE· STOCK INDUSTRY BILL 1997 First Reading Bill presented by Mr Anderson, and read a first time. Second Reading

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Title: Unknown
text: I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The purpose of the Australian Meat and stock Industry Bill 1997 and associated bills is to provide a legislative framework to facilitate the move from statutory to new company structures and operational arrangetine ments for the Australian red meat and livebeing addressed. stock industry. The new arrangements are a major step forward, advancing industry towards management of its own affairs and, importantly, increasing efficiency and competitiveness in structuring this industry continue as a world leader. This reform is focused on the future needs of industry. Background The government is committed to improving the overall international competitiveness of Australian industry. We are particularly keen to do so in our important agricultural indusfor tries. Unless we continue to improve productralian tivity and cost efficiency throughout the food supply chain, we will lose ground against our international competitors and will not be able to maximise our national wealth, export opportunities and value enhancing potential. The meat and livestock industry earns Australia, on average, about three billion export dollars per year. We need to set our targets for achievement at a higher level. As a single agricultural commodity export earner for Australia, red meat and li vestock ranks third after wheat and wool. The potential of the industry is considerable. However, to realise this potential, we need to deal with a range of inefficiencies, including high costs in the processing sector. In 1994, the Industry Commission inquiry into the performance of the meat processing industry confirmed the importance of achieving and maintaining improvements and competitive efficiencies. No-one can contest these simple objectives. The commission found that Australia was not able to capitalise on its comparative production price advantage because the industry's processing sector was operating at significantly higher cost levels than the processing sectors of our major competitors. The commission, at the time it put forward its report, found that Australia was losing market share in almost all its major export markets. It is not just these barriers in the Liveprocessing sector which are impeding the meat industry's capacity to be competitive in world markets, but other costs associated with Australia's labour market, waterfront, quaranand meat inspection processes are also Honourable members will no doubt agree that we must have a vision for the future and that reform in these key areas is vital to the to long-term viability of Australia's meat and livestock industry. This government is tackling these necessary reforms, and significant initiatives are already under way. For example, in the key area of industrial relations, the government has put the Workplace Relations all Act in place and, as a consequence, award simplification test cases have been formulated examination by a full bench of the AusIndustrial Relations Commission. One of the test cases includes the red meat processing industry and the particular issue of the tally system. The outcome of these cases will have particular importance for the industry. The response to the Industry Commission's 1994 report was the establishment of the Meat and Live-stock Industry Act 1995 which allowed for some institutional restructuring, particularly in relation to priorities and policy direction. The act was designed to commence the process of engaging industry to accept a greater role in self-determination. This bill, in effect, takes the major final steps towards empowerment by providing the industry with a structure which offers ownership and management of its own affairs. Review of current arrangements By the end of 1995, it was clear that beef producers were suffering from the effects of a major drought and other significant international market factors which forced saleyard prices down to very low levels with consequential reduced returns to producers. Furthermore, other red meat producers and other sectors .of the industry were also facing problems. The government instigated a review of the current institutional arrangements to determine whether early action might address at least some of the meat and livestock industry'S problems. To that end, a joint industry and government meat and livestock industry reform task force was established in 1996. The task force reviewed the structural arrangements, the financial management and operational effectiveness of the present statutory bodies. It also pinpointed key industry policy and program issues for early action by government and industry. The task force found that market and industry circumstances had changed since the establishment of the Meat and Live-stock Industry Act 1995. The task force found that the current statutory arrangements, which had worked well in the past, needed to be adjusted to deliver what industry required for the future. Prevailing and future commercial realities demand a structure which can deliver more flexible and focused commercial programs and operations. A sense of industry ownership and deeper involvement by levypaying stakeholders is also required. Working from these findings, the task force report offered a wide range of recommendations based on two underlying principles. The first was that the meat industry in Australia must move towards a more self-regulated, responsible and market driven operation. The second was that the role of government must move to one side, with a more clearly defined set of core functions for industry, same time improving strategic alliances with and within industry for the delivery of these functions. The report also suggested that significant savings could be achieved by changing the current structures and levyfunded functions and making the provision of services fully contestable and transparent to the. industry stakeholders. Finally, the report advanced proposals for government on joint industrygovernment policy and program. actions. These proposals cover a broad range of joint actions that, in large part, cross stateCommonwealth responsibilities and those of industry. Many. aspects of these proposals are already being addressed by Commonwealth and state agencies in direct consultations with industry. A number of recommendations were made on the need for uniformity in regulatory legislation and administration across Australia. A whole of government approach is essential to ensure an integrated and consistent basis for meat safety and other regulations and to provide a national regulatory underpinning for industry driven quality assurance and selfregulation schemes. I intend to continue to advance these issues with my colleagues on the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand, ARMCANZ. New arrangements The government decided on new arrangements following extensive consultations with all parts of Australia's vast and divergent meat and livestock industry. Full consensus has not been possible and is not possible. In an industry as diverse as this one, this is not surprising. I am pleased to say, however, there is. broad agreement on major issues and each sector is in the process of implementing the changes sought. These included the need for a non-government, commercially based organisation; the necessity for industry to manage its own affairs; a more hard-headed approach to how levy-payer moneys are spent; and separately accountable beef and sheepmeat marketing and promotion divisions and separately accountable research and development divisions, within a commercially based while at the organisation. Another key area of agreement is that joint industry functions, such as research and development, food safety and quality, market intelligence and market access issues, animal health and welfare, crisis management, eating quality standards, and Ausmeat should be dealt with cooperatively and collectively, and be adequately funded and serviced. The industry is now focused on their collective responsibility in scoping projects and programs within each of the joint function areas. This is fundamental and very important. The new structures will consist of a new producer-owned service delivery company, limited by guarantee under the Corporations Law, to provide a range of services to the industry, including professional guidance. The role of the company needs to be recognised, more so than the fact that it will be producer owned. The company will replace the statutory authorities of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation (AMLC) and the Meat Research Corporation (MRC). The company will be accessible to all sectors within the industry in every sense, including service delivery, professional guidance and advice. All sectors will independently enter into contracts with the company for specific services. Importantly, the company will be a fully professional organisation which will be able to develop initiatives and proposals and advise industry and government on key issues. There will be separate companies, limited by guarantee, for the meat processors, livestock exporters and for the red meat advisory council, which I will discuss shortly. There will be a memorandum of understanding between industry sectors and government to ensure cooperation in the overall interests of the red meat industry. There will be a commitment to the principles of a meat industry strategic plan and collective activities under genuine partnership arrangements. This bill is designed to free the industry from the legislative constraints imposed upon statutory bodies. The new, privately owned structure will allow industry to take appropriate steps towards: 1. Increasing industry's role in self-determination and self-regulation, in a commercially oriented environment; 2. Enhancing industry's capacity to determine and address areas of market failure; 3. Progressive implementation and facilitation of future industry agreed structural and other reforms; 4. Encouraging inclusion of all parties through willing partnerships, as well as separate contractual arrangements; 5. Improving industry cooperation, principally through empowering industry leadership, with rapid development of sound policy decisions and cooperative mechanisms; 6. Minimising government intervention while at the same time ensuring continuing and appropriate representation, governance, accountability and crises management arrangements; together with, 7. Providing clear ownership by levy payers and non-statutory contributors, and appropriate participation in decision making processes and resultant benefits. The new arrangements will empower the industry peak councils to take leadership roles. The peak councils are expected to be as broadly representative of their sectors' interests as possible, bearing in mind that there will always be dissenters and detractors of any systems put in place. Under voluntary systems, it is rarely possible to have full representation. Members of each sector should seek to make their views and concerns known to the peak councils. It is the responsibility of each and every participant of the industry to make their views known and seek to influence industry representation where appropriate. A requirement of what we are doing is that the relevant representative bodies be open to all views and embrace genuine representative responsibility. Peak councils will carry responsibility for decisions on levels of levies and non-statutory funding for the new service delivery company. They will be responsible, among other things, for the development of their sector's input into the meat industry strategic plan and for the implementation of that plan. To be able to effectively carry out the new responsibilities which will be required of them, the peak councils will need to be adequately funded so that they can have access to the professional expertise they will require. A primary new source of funding for peak councils will be income earned from investment of industry reserves. We must approach this issue practically and sensibly, according to the needs and responsibilities of each sector or agency. The 'red meat advisory council', which may operate under another name, is primarily to provide advice to government on issues affecting the whole of industry. It is proposed that the advisory council be incorporated as a company limited by guarantee with directors being the chairs of each of the six 'peak councils who will be voting members, and representatives of the processor and livestock exporter companies who will be participants. It will also draw, as appropriate and when required, on advisers from government and other involved expert areas of the industry. The framework in which the advisory council will operate will be agreed in the MOU. Its functions will include: advice to the minister; custodianship of the MOU and the meat industry strategic plan (the MISP); coordination and development of, and assessment of performance against, the industry strategic plan; being the trustees (within a deed of trust) for industry reserves currently held by the statutory corporations, and ensure the investment of these moneys by a reputable and reliable trust fund manager; administer arrangements to fund peak councils including the distribution (from investment of reserves) to peak councils; provide an interface for resolving sectoral differences or problems in a way which does not adversely affect industry but in a way which promotes the image and purpose of the industry. The terms of the council's custodianship of the industry reserves will be determined jointly by industry and government. The principal requirements will be that the funds be used for the benefit of industry as a whole, be managed transparently in a mannerconsistent with an industry developed strategic plan, and be based on accepted commercial practice. It is envisaged the returns on investments would be used primarily to fund peak councils and, in a small part, to defray the costs of running the council. Levies, charges and other fUlu:ling Under present arrangements, industry levies and charges primarily go towards funding the industry's three statutory bodies.,.......,.theALMC, the MRC, and the meat industry council. Other agencies which receive funding from industry levies and charges iI}clude the National Residue Survey (NRS), the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation (RIRDC), the National Cattle Disease Eradication (NCDE) program and the Australian Animal Health Council (AAHC). Under the new arrangements, contributions will be sourced from various industry sectors, either on a statutory or a non-statutory basis. The collection of statutory levies will still be based on the present system but with changes allowing fora transaction levy on sheep, lambs and goats to replace the livestock slaughter levy previously paid by processors, and a separate transaction levy component on grain fed cattle. The transaction levy approach for sheep, lambs and goats was adopted at the request of a clear majority of industry whose submission met all of the requirements of the government's levy principles. A similar request was also submitted by the grain fed cattle industry sector for a separate cattle transaction levy. Again this submission met each of the of funds government's levy principles. The existing levy and charge impOSItIOn acts have been modified to provide for clear sectoral ownership. Processors and livestock exporters will contribute on a non-statutory basis. To accommodate the non-statutory nature of the funding, the now separate processor and exporter levies will be set at zero, provided these sectors meet their share of whole of industry obligations under the new arrangements. There will be no changes to current levy rates until the new arrangements, including formal agreement on the nature and extent of processor and livestock exporter contributions, are fully in place and contractually deliverable. Should the non-statutory contributions processors and livestock exporters fail to meet agreed . funding levels· for joint industry functions, and as specifically agreed by these two sectors, the government has their prior agreement to maintain levies at a required level to ensure that there is adequate funding. The buffalo industry sector has chosen use RIRDC to meet its collective research development programs and will not be contributing to the new service delivery company. Separate levy legislation will provide for direct buffalo industry sector contributions to transferred RIRDC and continued contribution by this sector to the NRS and· NCDE. The government will continue to match industry R&D commitments. Matching funds to will continue on a dollar for dollar basis on eligible expenditure up to the maximum matching of 0.5 per cent of the industry's gross value of production. However, to qualify for matching funding for levy monies, contributing groups will need to meet specific as a whole. eligibility criteria. MOU and deed of grants The bill recognises that much of the prescriptive detail for flow of levy funds and management of reserves will be set out deed of grant. The deed of grant will be implemented between the government and the producer owned service delivery company. The deed will set out the conditions upon which levy monies and matching funds are passed to the company and how those funds may be applied. It will also set out the minimal accountability requirements enable me to meet my responsibilities under the Audit Act 1901. The MOU will primarily be between indusboard try peak bodies and also the government. Where appropriate and where they have will, identified responsibility, the service delivery company and other entities will be required be signatories. The document will consist a statement of principles and supporting schedules clearly outlining the new arrangetrading ments to which industry sectors have agreed. It will also outline intended joint function areas, core function areas and set out the guiding principles for the operation of the meat advisory council. by Assets and liabilities In consultation with industry and appropriate central commonwealth agencies I will determine the most appropriate placement of the assets and liabilities of the ALMC and the MRC. The legislative provisions to effect the transfer of such assets and liabilities to private to companies is provided for in the Australian and Meat and Live-stock Industry (Repeals and Consequential Provisions) Bill 1997. Some of the industry reserves will be to the new service delivery company to offset liabilities which exist at the time of transfer and to meet start-up capital requirements. A full due diligence exercise will be conducted for accountability purposes ensure all assets and liabilities are identified prior to transfer. Start-up capital will also be provided to the processor and livestock exporter companies. I will, in consultation with industry, determine how the balance of reserves will be used to benefit the industry Role of government, ministerial powers and accountability The role of government in the new arrangein a ments will be minimal, but will remain necessary while taxpayer monies are involved. Ministerial powers of intervention and mechanisms to guarantee appropriate standards of governance and accountability to parliament and levy payers will be retained through the combination of legislation-including the Corporations Law-regulation, appropriation, that deeds of grant and the industry MOU. The Commonwealth will not be a member of any of the new companies, nor will it have representation or carry any liability in relation to their operations. The government however, continue to fulfil its responsibility. The government will also continue to to assist industry through working to ensure the of economic framework provides for a genuinely competitive environment and that the global environment does not disadvantage our competitive advantages. The government will continue to maintain a strong presence in areas of food safety and hygiene, research and red development, industry adjustment processes, training and education delivery, market access negotiations, competition and contestability, workplace reform, and infrastructure. Legislative provisions The legislative package consists of this, the principal bill, and sixteen associated principal bill makes provision for some staging by proclamation of implementation. This is critical because many of the mechanisms which will underpin effective and efficient industry management, the creation of representative corporations, the development of industry contractual arrangements and negotiations by industry leaders, must be completed before the current legislation is repealed and levies adjusted. These activities are well advanced. The legislation provides for the continued management of existing export licences, export quotas and enforcement powers. At present these functions are managed by the ALMC and paid for by levy payers. They will now transfer to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, including the provision for full cost recovery for the administration of licences and quotas. Provision is made in the bill for the secretary of DPIE to have regard to policies formulated by prescribed industry bodies when exercising licensing and quota powers. Provision is also made for levy funds for marketing and promotion activities and R&D functions to flow to the new service delivery company. There is also provision for the government to identify those organisations which, after meeting prescribed conditions, will be recognised as eligible donors for the purpose of Commonwealth matching funding on eligible R&D expenditure within the service delivery company. The principal legislation makes provision for ministerial direction, but only in situations of emergency and where the national interest is involved. The power of direction is limited to matters for which the Commonwealth has authority under the constitution. The new structural arrangements impact directly on other legislation, including the meat industry'S present levies and charges acts. The Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry (Repeals and Consequential Provisions) Bill 1997 makes provision to repeal or amend relevant parts of the affected acts. In addition, a new set of levy and charge bills has been drafted to accommodate the change to the nature of future contributions. The bills. The changes are as follows: the Cattle Export Charges Act 1990 will be replaced by two new cattle export charge acts which deal separately with producers and exporters. This allows for subsequent reduction of the export sector levy components to zero when that sector delivers on its funding commitments under the new partnership arrangements. the Live-stock Export Charge Act 1977 will be replaced by two new livestock export charges acts which deal separately with producers and exporters. This will also allow for subsequent reduction of the export sector components to zero. the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Act 1964 will be replaced by a Live-stock Transactions Levy Act and a Live-stock Slaughter (Processors) Levy Act to allow for the separation of producers' and processors' fundirtg and for the processors' funding to move to zero levy rates. the particular requirements of the buffalo industry will be met by new buffalo export charge and slaughter levy acts. Separate levy acts are needed because the buffalo industry will retain slaughter levy and export charge arrangements. Contributions from the buffalo industry will continue to go to RIRDC, the NRS and the NCDE as at present. the Beef Production Levy Act 1990 will be amended to allow for the processors' funding to move to zero levy rates. the new act replacing the Cattle Transaction Levy Act 1995 will provide for the imposition of separate levy components for grass fed and grain fed cattle producers to support their individual contributions to the new service delivery company, as well as continued funding to the NCDE and AAHC. a revised set of national residue survey bills has been included in this package to allow for continuation of the provision of producer linked payments on cattle, buffalo, sheep, lambs and goats. In all cases, the promotion, marketing, R&D and program specific components will be specifically identified. Provisions will ensure collections of levies and voluntary contributions relating to any particular sector will be clearly and transparently identifiable. Collection arrangements and cost recovery for these levies will remain as they are at present. National eating quality standards scheme I have long promoted the need for a proper meat grading system in this country. I expect the new service delivery company to maintain the high priority being given to the early introduction of the proposed national eating quality standards scheme and further expects funding for this initiative to be of a high priority for the industry sectors. As they say, if you like to eat, you are involved in agriculture. One thing that we really can do thatwill benefit the consumers of this nation and beef producers-or meat producers of all persuasions-at the same time is to ensure that we have in place a mechanism which means that the consumer can be reassured as to the eating quality of whatever it is that they are purchasing. Support for producers' marketing initiatives I have asked the new service delivery company to give careful consideration to ways to assist groups of producers who wish to pursue various marketing initiatives. Such initiatives would include the development of brands and the development of niche markets and a means by which innovation and initiatives can reap rewards. Finally, I would like to repeat that the legislation package I have just outlined will facilitate the reshaping and refocusing of the Australian red meat and livestock industry. The new statutory arrangements will: empower industry; reduce government involvement; achieve a more focused and cost efficient service delivery; provide a more responsive structure capable of adapting to rapidly evolving competition and customer needs; and encourage the development of systems and structures which promote the culture of industry cooperation and a sense of corporate behaviour in developing and ensuring the future prosperity of the Australian red meat industry. These new arrangements represent a radical move to industry self-determination. The changes will be carefully implemented to ensure that structures, relationships and operations are corporate in their nature and have proper and workable settings and control measures. Since the announcement of the government's decision, industry has had time to appreciate the historic opportunities being offered to it and acknowledged that the package will accommodate most, if not all, of what the various sectors have been seeking. All sectors have assured me that they accept the decisions taken and that they will get behind them to ensure their effective implementation. Above all, industry has recognised that the new arrangements are offering a necessary opportunity to bring about a fundamental cultural change. Rather than relying on government involvement and legislated instruments, the package offers industry control and ownership of its own destiny. I commend the bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum. Debate (on motion by Mr MCMullan) adjourned. Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Title: CATTLE TRANSACTIONS LEVY BILL
text: Gwydir-Minister for Primary Industries and Energy) (10.04 a.m.)I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The purpose of this bill is to impose levies payable by producers on transactions involving sheep, lambs and goats. This bill will replace the levy imposed on the sheepmeat and goat industries by the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Act 1964, which provided for levies at the point of slaughter and was paid for by processors. The levies will be used to fund the new industry service delivery company, disease eradication and animal health for the sheepmeat, wool and goat industries. In the light of decisions sors and live exporters to move to non-statutory levies, and for reasons of simplicity, equity and transparency, the Sheepmeat Council of Australia and the Goat Industry Council of Australia proposed a transaction levy be introduced in lieu of a slaughter 'pass-back' levy. The Sheepmeat Council of Australia has demonstrated this is clearly the majority industry decision, including support of this approach by the Wool Council of Australia. The transaction levy under this bill will closely parallel the existing transaction levy that has operated successfully in the cattle sector for many years. By aligning industry collection mechanisms with those already existing for cattle, meat industry levy tions are effectively standardised. It is this standardised approach that has assisted in gathering strong support. The bill also makes provision for exemptions in such circumstances as are prescribed by regulation to provide the flexibilityiri the future to cater for industry decisions in relation to levy exemptions. Such regulations will be disallowable instruments and the industry, in seeking levy exemptions or concessions, will need to clearly demonstrate that the proposal has majority industry support and meets all the requirements of the government's levy principles. The Sheepmeat Council of Australia and the Goat Industry Council of Australia have requested· an exemption from levy for sheep, lambs and goats sold for $5.00 per head or less to cater for cases of genuine hardship. This exemption has met the requirements outlined above, and I intended to give effect to this and to any subsequent decisions that might be made through regulation. I commend the . bill to the honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum. Debate (on motion by Mr MCMullan) adjourned. Speaker: Ms WORTH
Title: HEALTH LEGISLATION
text: Adelaide-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services) (10.15 a.m.)-I move: That the bill be now read a second time. This bill amends provisions in the Health Insurance Act 1973, the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973, the National Health Act 1953 and the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Family Measures) Act 1995. The bill amends the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 to remove doubts about whether hedging contracts made incidental to the borrowings or investments of the Health Insurance Commission require ministerial approval. When section 36AA was inserted into the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973, it was not intended that such contracts would require ministerial approval. The bill also amends the Health Insurance Act 1973 ('the act'). The most significant changes will: allow the claiming and payment of Medicare benefits by means of electronic transmission. This will substantially improve access to Medicare services, especially for many people in rural and remote areas. Doctors will be able to electronically lodge claims for all Medicare services instead of only bulkbilled claims; eliminate unnecessary consideration by a Specialist Recognition Advisory Committee of questions relating to the continued recognition of a specialist or consultant physician, where recognition was intended to be short term for the purposes of a locum tenans or the specialist or consultant physician applies to have that status ended. This amendment is consistent with the government's policy to reduce the extent to which regulatory provisions intrude on the conduct of business and the professions; allow optometrists to charge in excess of the schedule fee in circumstances to be specified in the optometrical undertaking. A revised undertaking will make exceptions in respect of domiciliary visits-as is currently the case-and those occasions where an optometrist attends a patient on the first occasion and the client had attended another optometrist in the previous two years; extend the application of subsection 10(1) to a professional service rendered during a 'domestic journey'. A domestic journey will include all forms of domestic travel whether prior to or at the end of an international flight. The provision would enable a person who leaves Australia for an international destination but who, before arrival, is required to return to Australia due to ill health to claim Medicare benefits for any professional services; inform the direction and management by the Commonwealth, states and territories of the immunisation programs by releasing de-identified data for research purposes from the Australian Childhood Immunisation Register. The Privacy Commission has confirmed that the release of information from the register is not in conflict with privacy principles; insert a new clause 128C providing a penalty for charging public patients for the provision of public hospital services in prescribed circumstances. It will be an offence for a medical practitioner where a patient is known to be a public patient to raise a charge or receive any payment for a public hospital service in the circumstances as set out in regulations made under this section and provides a penalty of 50 penalty units; and insert a new subsection 130(4A) which corrects anomalies in the existing secrecy provision (section 130), which make the necessary transmission of confidential information in specific circumstances. It will allow the return of information relating to a Medicare claim to the claim:ant or practitioner who provided information associated with the claim, without the permission of other persons whose information is associated with the claim. Mr Deputy Speaker, this bill also makes some minor but important amendments to the National Health Act 1953 governing the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, PBS. Firstly, it introduces a system which will enable a private hospital or residential care facility to be reimbursed for the administration of some pharmaceutical benefits to its patients or residents from the institution's own stocks, in order to obviate the need for a prescription for the pharmaceutical benefits. The system will apply to pharmaceutical benefits determined by the minister to be appropriate for these arrangements and will come into operation on 1 May 1998. Secondly, it provides for the appointment of an additional member of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee to represent the interests of consumers. Thirdly, it amends the secrecy provisions, to complement similar amendments being made to the Health Insurance Act 1973, to correct an anomaly which inhibits the necessary transmission of confidential information in certain circumstances. The bill also. makes a number of minor technical amendments to the Health Insurance Act 1973 and to the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Family Measures) Act 1995. Ipresent the signed explanatory memorandum to this bill. Debate (on motion by Mr MCMullan) adjourned. NA MANAGEMENT BILL 1997 Second Reading Debate resumed from 30 September, on motion by Mr Ronaldson: That the bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr LEO MCLEAY
Title: SYDNEY AIRPORT DEMAND
text: Before I rose to speak on the Sydney Airport Demand Management Bill I was sitting here contemplating the terrible damage that has been done by Sydney airport to the people in my electorate and to the people of my previous electorate of Grayndler. I was first elected to public life in 1971 as a councillor on Marrickville Council on a policy of reducing aircraft noise. It is appalling that 26 years later I am still in parliament talking about the atrocious effect that Sydney airport has on the people of my electorate. Unfortunately, that airport was never really planned. When it became the principal airport for Sydney, no-one looked ahead to the day when air transport might be the usual way of moving people between Australian cities and overseas. Nobody looked ahead and nobody listened to the growing complaints of residents. This lack of interest can largely be attributthe ed to one factor: the residents of the suburbs around the airport were, for the most part, working class. They did not carry the weight of being in marginal seats. They did not have access to the media. They were not the rich and powerful. The airport kept growing and evolving and the planes kept getting bigger and noisier and, unfortunately, far more frequent. The growth of a very centrally and conveniently located airport was in the interests of who could afford to use the facility and in the interests of the owners of airlines and the bureaucrats responsible for building and maintaining the airport. This very powerful lobby group won hands down every time. The airport only emerged as a major issue once the planes became of such a size and frequency that they started flying low over suburbs which were of upper or middle class. These people had access to the media and lived in marginal seats. Suddenly the noise and pollution became an issue and suddenly governments started focusing on the problems caused by Sydney airport. I do not expect miracles and the people of my electorate do not expect miracles. There is no expectation on my part or, I think, on the part of most of my constituents that Sydney airport will one day be packed up and taken away and that the site will be turned into parkland or a marina development. Indeed, many of my constituents work at the airport. It is a very significant local employer and should remain that way. But what the people of my electorate do expect is a fair and just outcome for the noise and pollution that they have put up with over the years. I speak particularly of my current electorate and the residents of the suburbs of Earlwood and Kingsgrove, who are suffering under the new flight path regime instituted by the Howard government. I cannot gloss over the decision of my own party to construct the third runway at Kingsford Smith airport. I was vocal in my opposition to this decision as were a number of other Labor members whose electorates surrounded the airport. That decision, however, was carried out with the full support of then opposition, the now government. The current Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the former Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Mr Sharp, were the ones who were saying we should expand Sydney airport and we should do it quickly. They fully endorsed that course of action until it became obvious that the optimum flight paths for using parallel runways at Sydney airport would take the traffic over their electorates. What a turnaround! From all espousing the virtues of a third runway and even being supportive of raising the airport curfew, the Liberal Party and its members of parliament went full circle. By the time the election came around we had the Prime Minister saying to the electors of Lowe, 'If you vote for Mr Zammit' - the current member for Lowe-'you will have no more aircraft noise. If you want aircraft noise, you should keep on voting for Labor's candidate. If you want your property values to go up, you should vote for Mr Zammit.' Unfortunately, the people of Lowe took the Prime Minister on his word and they voted for Mr Zammit. They believed the Prime Minister when he said that there would be no planes flying over the electorate of Lowe under a Liberal government. They were sucked in. The Prime Minister has not stopped the planes flying over Lowe. But I do note that he has stopped them flying over his own electorate-self-interest will always out. The Prime Minister has just moved the noise around so that more people suffer from the effects of the airport. Those suffering at the moment include the residents of Earlwood and Kingsgrove in my electorate who now have a great many flights skimming over their rooftops any time from 5 .30 a.m. until midnight seven days a week. Even more alarming to all those people living around Sydney airport was the decision to go back to basics over the location of a second Sydney airport. For over 20 years we have been looking at a site for a second Sydney airport. The Fraser government in the long distant past instituted the major airport needs of Sydney inquiry to look at where we should have an airport. Finally, after the Labor government made the disgraceful decision about the third runway they decided on Badgerys Creek as the preferred site for the second airport for Sydney as part 'of that package. Without any forewarning after the last election, particularly to the voters of Hughes, the Minister for Transport and Regional Development suddenly dragged out a Holsworthy option and put it forward as a possible airport site. This sop to a group of Liberal Party supporters and the Lawrence Hargrave project delayed yet again any real progress towards a second Sydney airport. It was another red herring. thrown into the ring to distract anyone who was interested from the real game-the game of getting a second airport into the Sydney region and thereby ameliorating the effects of aircraft noise and pollution on the people of the inner west and south-west of Sydney. Finally, a few weeks ago the government came out and confirmed what everybody already knew-Holsworthy was a stupid proposition and Badgerys Creek was the only viable site left in the Sydney region for a second Sydney airport. This was the position we had come to in the Labor Party many years earlier. Badgerys Creek will provide a solution for the increasing problems with Kingsford Smith airport that is just and fair to all Sydney siders. It will also, like Kingsford Smith, generate a great deal of employment where it is needed out in the western suburbs. But in the same way that justice delayed is justice denied, the delaying of the construction of Badgerys Creek will deny the people of my electorate and those surrounding Sydney airport any hope of an improved quality of life or even a halt to the deterioration of their current quality of life. While we await a longer term solution, Kingsford Smith should be managed to ensure that the least possible noise and pollution to the fewest number of people is achieved. One key aspect of such a management plan is to limit the number of take-offs and landings to ensure that there is not continued growth at Sydney airport. The plan put forward in the Sydney Airport Demand Management Bill 1997 simply revisits the proposals in the Sydney Airport (Regulation of Movements) Bill 1996, which was put forward in this House last year by my colleague the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) and me. The member for Grayndler and I proposed a cap on aircraft. movements of 80 movements an hour into and out of Kingsford Smith airport. This would hold traffic at Sydney airport at around its current levels. Many of course would tell you that such a cap is not necessary-those people who advocated the third runway and those people who advocated lifting the curfew. They believe that the airport should be utilised to its limit-and that limit is being talked as being up to as many as 120 movements an hour, two movements a minute, one movement every 30 seconds. They also suggest the lifting of the curfew. The more bizarre of them even suggest a fourth runway. These same people are quick to advocate no second airport for Sydney. They seem convinced that, if they keep ignoring the problems associated with Kingsford Smith airport, these problems will go away. They are happy to see the difficulty experienced by those in the inner west exacerbated by increasing the use of this site, which I might say is one of the smallest site areas of any large international airport in the world. Without some artificial limit being placed on the number of aircraft movements, there will be no pressure to address the real aviation needs of the Sydney region. Already we have seen the projections passed that were made some five years ago about when Sydney airport would saturate. With the exponential growth that you are seeing in this countryboth international tourism into and out of Australia, and the attitude of Australians of moving around the country via aircraft rather than via cars, buses and trains as people used to do-there is going to be more and more demand on Sydney airport. The deregulation of the airline industry put in place by the previous Labor government has seen aircraft fares reduce and come within the range of ordinary working people. This has seen the use of aircraft skyrocket. Yet another set of short-term fixes would be put in place if the people who have the attitude that Sydney should get bigger and bigger are the ones who win. There is a real danger with the approach to the 2000 Olympics-when the facilities at Sydney airport will be pushed to the absolute limit-that people will say, 'We have coped with Olympics. Let's leave it there and let's do nothing.' If the government had shown some leadership on this issue rather than dangling the Holsworthy red herring, which is something that amazed everyone, we would have seen a start on the facilities at Badgerys Creek and probably seen them in place to deal with some of the overload in the year 2000. But we saw nothing. We saw the government cause 18 months of delay once again. On behalf of my constituents, the people of Watson, I support this legislation wholeheartedly. I think the government should have been a little bit more generous and dealt with the legislation of the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) and me last year, or indeed done what the minister said he would, which was introduce legislation last year to do just ,this. But better late than never. This legislation will go some way to assisting the residents of the electorate of Watson, and particularly those of the suburbs of Earlwood and Kingsgrove, to at least maintain some standard of comfort rather than have it further eroded. But the government should not stop here. The government should announce that it will be starting work on a second airport at Badgerys Creek immediately. If the government was fair dinkum it would provide an injection of funds from the Federation Fund to kickstart this project and thus assure the people of Sydney an aviation infrastructure capable of taking them into the 21st century and reassure the people of my electorate their problems will not continue to escalate. If the government has money available to build a railway from Adelaide to Darwin then surely there should be money for a genuine infrastructure program which will be used and of benefit to Australia rather than a bit of cargo cult for the voters in the Northern Territory. Enough is enough! The government must get on with building Sydney's second airport. This legislation goes some way to at least making that a more urgent matter because, by capping the movements at Sydney, we will ensure that people have to focus on the future rather than continuing to have ad hoc decisions at Sydney which will cause that airport to get bigger, noisier and nastier. It would be stupid, as I said earlier, for any member who represents the airport to say that it should be closed. It is a very significant generator of work for the people of my electorate and I have never argued that Sydney airport should be closed. We should tame this beast, and we should tame it now, but we should ensure also that the work that it provides stays there for the people who live around it. I also think that those people out in the western suburbs who were originally proponents of Badgerys Creek, and have now all of a sudden become opponents of it, should start to think about the people that they represent who need jobs, as well as the nimby approach, because as the Mayor of Liverpool has said, Badgerys Creek airport will become the single most significant generator of jobs in the western suburbs of Sydney that we have seen in the last 50 years. It will provide work and it will provide work for ordinary working-class people, which is what is needed out in the western suburbs. But we must tame Kingsford-Smith. This legislation goes some way to doing it. I commend the government for that, but I condemn the government for taking so long to get to this piece of legislation. I condemn the government for not starting on Badgerys Creek yet. By condemning the current government I also do not give any comfort to my colleagues who held this project up either. The previous Labor government was wrong in building the third runway. The previous Labor government was wrong in not getting a start on Badgerys Creek, although it did make the final decision to build the airport, and it did acquire the land. The current government has sold a large site adjacent to the airport which will make it very difficult to keep up with some of the plans that should occur at Badgerys Creek. To conclude my remarks, this legislation will at least say to the people of my electorate that the beast has been tamed a little, and there will be some certainty put back into their lives. I could make some remarks about the government's phoney program of sharing the noise, but I do not think that is all that constructive. I will just complete my remarks by picking up on a matter regarding the member for Lowe (Mr Zammit), who the government has sold out with great distinction. The member for Lowe, in his remarks, mentioned a stunt he got up to by writing to all the local councils and members about his press release. All I will say to the member for Lowe is: stop the stunts, get out there and try to exercise some influence on your government. You got elected on the phoney promise of no planes over Lowe. When there are no planes over Lowe, then he can hold his head up high. He has been sold out by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), he has sold out his own people and all he can get up to is stunts. I think that probably shows about the level of the member for Lowe.

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: SYDNEY AIRPORT DEMAND
text: The Sydney Airport Demand Management Bill 1997 delivers on another commitment that has been made by the coalition. Certainly we accept the support that we have been receiving from members of the opposition, although I noted there has been a little bit of a division in the opposition camp with regard to the development of Badgerys Creek. I acknowledge the contribution of the member for Watson (Mr MCLeay) in support of that option and would say in defence of the government's actions on the EIS process that at least we did that. We went through that rigorous EIS process with Holsworthy to make sure that the decision to exclude it was a justifiable decision and to make sure that the decision on Sydney's second airport was justified on solid grounds. We can move forward now to the completion of that process with Badgerys Creek. In listening to the debate last night, I noted that there is still some division between some members of the opposition with regard to the proposal to build Sydney's second airport at Badgerys Creek, but I note the very positive comments of the member for Watson. The bill that we are debating is a delivery of a coalition commitment. It provides certainty for operators. Everybody knows what is going on. It establishes a maximum limit on aircraft movements at KSA to 80 movements per hour while introducing a slot management system. I suppose in discussing these matters everybody has their own individual concerns and most of them are born out of representing their constituencies. The opposition speakers we have been listening to obviously have strong feelings one way or the other. We know that the deVelopment and management of the KSA airport has been a very vexed issue for the Labor Party and the seats around it. We heard the member for Watson say that he never agreed with the establishment of the parallel runway. As a representative of regional Australia. I, too, was keen to see in this slot management system an acknowledgment of the important role that regional airlines play in New South Wales. I understand that they have been given a regional airline slot pool, which has been introduced in this bill as well. The opposition are complaining about the time it has taken the government to make more progress or to get the development of a second Sydney airport started. The Labor Party in governmerit had 13 years to tackle this problem. They could not sort it out internally. It is public knowledge that there are concerns from some of the members in the government about the EIS process with Holsworthy, but the decision was taken as soon as the results of the EIS were out. The government promised to open the eastwest runway if elected to government. We have done that. The government promised a more equitable distribution of the aircraft noise problem. We have done that. The government promised a review of the flight paths for Mascot airport, and we have done that. In opposition the coalition was committed to capping aircraft movements to 80 per hour and in government the coalition is implementing this promise. Eighty movements an hour equates to approximately 500,000 movements per year. This is in excess of Sydney's 353,000 movement limit which is specified in the long-term operating plan. Under Labor, 50 per cent of the movements were over the suburbs north of the airport. These residents never got a break at all. The coalition has already cut these movements by 33 per cent. The target is to cut it further around 17 per cent. Under the coalition, 17 per cent of aircraft movements will be to the north, 15 per cent to the west, 13 per cent to the east and 55 per cent will be to the south and over water. What is being done here is exactly what we set out to do-that is, to create a more equitable situation not only for the movement of aircraft in and out of KSA but also for the distribution of noise. We are a government that has inherited a problem that we are dealing with. To be criticised for not dealing with it more expeditiously, I think, is a bit disingenuous of the opposition. There has been positive action to deal with the surrounding suburbs around KSA in an equitable way. We have put those measures in place. The slot system is the means by which the cap can be monitored. The implementation of the slot system will be ·beneficial to all users of the airport. It is designed to alleviate congestion in a non-discriminatory way. While the bill sets out the general framework for the slot system the detail, to be determined by the slot manager, will be contained in adisallowable instrument. The slot system will be fully operative by March 1998. The slot system is consistent with worldwide practice. The slot management system is used at approximately 130 airports around the world. The system being implemented in Australia is based on the lATA model with some modifications that reflect the particular conditions that exist at KSA-for instance, as I alluded to earlier, protection for regional services, better access to slots for new entrants, and the introduction of compliance mechanisms. They are all important elements of what we are attempting to achieve here, and I think it should be recognised. It is important to recognise the right of those regional operators to also have access to KSA. All those commuters have an expectation and a right of quick access to the business community in Sydney and should not be penalised because of their smaller aircraft. It is an important element of this bill. The slot system forces airlines to move away from cluster scheduling where flights to are scheduled to arrive and depart and are beyond the capacity of the airport to support. Cluster scheduling can be claimed therefore, particularly at peak times, to be the root cause of the delays experienced at KSA, which is the flip side of the problems. It has been criticised over the years for the low number of hourly movements in comparison to international standards. The 80 movements per hour is not presently being met at KSA. There will be opportunities for new entrants to obtain slots during all operational hours. This includes peak times. There is a general expectation that there will be a degree of competition for any slots available during peak periods. Potential new entrants will have equal access with their established competitors on a fifty-fifty split. KSA is one of the fairest airports around the world in this area and is consistent with a deregulated aviation industry. At most, other airport incumbents get first go at the slots available. The bill establishes a slot manager, which is envisaged to be a company formed by Sydney airport and Australian airlines or operators using the airport, which will administer the allocation and compliance. As I have already noted, special arrangements are going to be put in place by the government for regional airlines. We are committed to providing services to regional New South Wales. The needs of regional New South Wales will be preserved by the use of ring fencing whereby KSA regional airline services have their own slot pool. Existing regional services will be guaranteed a regional slot. These slots cannot be sold or swapped to interstate or international services. So that is locking in opportunity for continuity of regional services in and out of KSA so they do not get elbowed out, so to speak, by the larger operators. It would be difficult to put a cap on aircraft movements without some sort of effective compliance mechanism to ensure that it was not abused or misused in other ways. This is the crucial element of the slot management system. The aim is to promote efficient scheduling performance. There will be steep fines for non-compliance. Delays at KSA will be now more open to scrutiny as the slot system introduces a clear set of criteria for flight movements. The maximum penalties are fairly hefty-for a no-slot movement and an off-slot movement, the penalty is $220,000 and $110,000 respectively. A no-slot movement is the most serious breach, and it jeopardises the cap and disrupts other airport users who have applied for a slot. So, if you have an airline operator who just does not tum up, does not utilise the slot they have been allocated, it means that someone else has missed out, the whole schedule has been put out of whack. That is how critical the timing will be in the operation of the slot management system. To make sure these companies and airline operators are focused on what is trying to be achieved here, the compliance measures will be implemented. The coalition is a government of action, unlike Labor, which did nothing but create anxiety and stress for the people of Sydney for those 13 years. I note that the member for  know whether he has actually spoken on this bill. .

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: SYDNEY AIRPORT DEMAND
text: Not yet, but I am sure he is going to and I am sure the member for Chifley will probably be at variance with some of his colleagues with regard to the development of the airport at western Sydney. But you can rest assured that this government will deliver on alleviating the problems as far as the second airport in the Sydney basin is concerned. We will not be vacillating on this the way the Labor Party has done. In the last 18 the months we have become used to listening to the opposition talk about what they were going to do if they had got another term in government. This is just another one of those areas. It took a long time for them to try to address the problem with the parallel runway at KSA. They went through the process of identifying Badgerys Creek. We heard the member for Watson criticise the decisions that have been made by his former government for not getting on with the job. This government is at least going through a rigorous process of eliminating Holsworthy first, and now we will move forward with the job of developing a second airport in Sydney. We will not muck about and wait for 13 years to pander to different interests in some of our electorates, as we have seen happen around KSA. We will get on with the job so there is certainty in what is going to happen in aviation in Australia. The implementation of the slot management system and the guarantee of 80 movements per hour will create a lot more certainty for the travelling public, inbound international tourism and the businesses that operate in and around KSA, particularly the airline operators, and will provide other competitors with the opportunity to get into that slot management system. But, just as importantly, it will provide the opportunity for regional travellers within New South Wales to have what they perceive as their reasonable right to access the Kingsford Smith airport in Sydney when they need to get in there and, subsequently, do their business in the city. In closing, it good to see a majority of opposition members supporting this bill.  little surprised at the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile). I was expecting a more with it. spirited bid for a ministerial bench in that speech of his. Mr Lee-He has obviously got land transsay. port.  transport. I have to say I have a little money on him. I am not going to quit yet, but I did expect a more spirited defence. want to pick up one thing-that is, all opposition members support the Sydney Airport Demand Management Bill. I am a little to surprised that he is suggesting they do not. fact, I think the honourable member for ber Grayndler (Mr Albanese) and the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo MCLeay) are be commended for being the instigators this bill. I do not think that there can be any member of this House who does not have some sympathy for the plight of constituents who reside, for example, in the electorates Grayndler, Watson or Barton. Mr Lee-Or Lowe.  terms of the way their lives are changed by airport noise. Mr Hockey-Or North Sydney.  extraordinary to see the lengths that this government goes to to protect the citizens Bennelong and other electorates on the North Shore. Mr Deputy Speaker, as you may be aware, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) thought he was launching some pleted, vicious attack on me in purporting to make some great revelations to the House about statements I have made in this place in supexactly port of Badgerys Creek. For the record, also think the most nerve-racking time for me as a new member in this place was talking to my party units who had had a history, dating back to to Galston airport, of being opposed to an airport in western Sydney and my advocating that we should in fact look at having an is airport in western Sydney. In 1985, in looking at the way things have developed, an airport for Badgerys Creek was, in retrospect or am a hindsight, a 1980s issue. Mr Hockey-You went to the last election  I think you will find that I have quite a bit to In western Sydney it is true that an overwhelming proportion of the population supported an airport at Badgerys Creek. I bit of have some sympathy with the comments of the member for Watson, who said that it is a I do pity they did not get on and build it. The truth is that the proposal started off as a general airport. The runway was extended allow a certain class of aeroplane to use it In but not all aeroplanes. Indeed, I well rememthe comments by, I think, one of the state premiers at the time, who said that Badgerys to Creek would only be required, looking at of airport demand, in the year 2010. I have certainly changed my position. I make no apology for that. Indeed, it is not something new to my constituents or new in of the western suburbs of Sydney. But what is the reason for me wanting to change my position on Badgerys Creek? Firstly, I think it is fair to say that the proposal for the third runway and the flawed EIS at the time not only disturbed a lot of people in the inner city but started to raise doubts in the people of the western suburbs the efficacy of an airport at Badgerys Creek. I remember a number of meetings that of Labor members from the western suburbs of Sydney had during 1995. There was complete agreement that, when we went into the next election-that is, the 1996 election-the three studies that we had promised would be comthe flight paths would be available, there would be a high degree of community consultation and every citizen would know how that airport would actually affect I them. History shows of course that this was not done, and I must say that it left people like me well and truly isolated. I have already referred to a meeting at Memorial Hall during the election period, which {was genuinely informed the member for Lindsay, Jackie Kelly, was invited to attend. For the record, Jackie has said that she was never invited and I accept that. But we did have the former Senator Woods come along. Do people remember Senator Woods, of travelrorts and a few other things? What did former Senator Woods say at that meeting? He said that the coalition stood for an open, transparent and publicly accountable EIS process. More than that, as the inner city community groups had been funded by Labor, the relevant groups in western Sydney would also be funded by the coalition. Have we had an open, transparent and accountable EIS process? Of course we have not. Other speakers have referred to the Holsworthy episode, fiasco, whatever you want to call it. I thought it was really interesting as part of upholding this open, transparent and accountable EIS process, we suppressed the information which would allow us to examine what led the government to abandon Holsworthy and refine down its sole solution to Badgerys Creek. Does the honourable member for North Sydney believe this is accountable, open and transparent? He really does swallow the government's propaganda lines to a degree that I did not think was possible. Mr Lee-He has been part and parcel of it.  obviously correct there. He has been part and parcel of it. But let me just talk about noise. I think there was nothing more criticised in the third runway EIS than the use of Australian ANEF standards. They were totally discredited. But what standards are we using in the Badgerys Creek EIS? The very same standards. Even by the time of the last election, people in my part of western Sydney knew that 24 hours was never going to be a goer. Then we have issues of air quality. It is true-and the honourable member for Greenway (Mr Mossfield) will confirm thisthat in western Sydney we have an extraordinarily high incidence of asthma. That affects not only people of my age but, of course, young children. What do we have in terms of fine particle pollution in the EIS? Th-re is absolutely no mention of the US standard of 2.5 microns. That is not mentioned in the EIS at all. Why should I raise that? That is the fine particle pollution that lodges and remains in the lungs of people who come in contact with it. I hope that the new fine particle pollution standard currently being negotiated by the federal government with the states does include a 2.5 micron standard because I think, of all things, this alone probably will rule it out. The EIS does not address ozone pollution. Is the honourable member for North Sydney not concerned about ozone? There is the issue of the remaining stands of the Cumberland Plain woodland and, of course, the 31 endangered species that are in the flight path of the proposed airport. Also in the EIS are the figures that show, under the various options, that, the dramatic decrease in the value of houses to people. For an airport that is alleged to traumatise cows only, it is surprising that the bam value is going to drop by as much, under one option, as $61 million. The member for North Sydney probably does not even flinch at $61 million, given the value of houses in his electorate. But I remind him that in western Sydney these houses represent the life savings of battling families. This is the way we have traditionally saved. People's prized assets-their family homesare going to dramatically decrease in value. I have said all along-and I have sometimes been criticised for it-that, since the change of government, the real people who are capable of influencing the government on this issue of Badgerys Creek are not the member for Greenway, although he has always been in that fight, or me or even the member for Prospect, Mrs Crosio. The real keys to Badgerys Creek are the government members like the member for Lindsay. What is her position on Badgerys Creek? We cannot quite work it out. Certainly, Danna Vale left us in no doubt about where she stood in relation to Holsworthy. Apparently, options A and C are not acceptable to the member for Lindsay, but she apparently has no problems with option B, although she has already conceded she may very well lose her seat over it-and I think that is right. There is Kerry Bartlett, the member for Macquarie. What is his position? My understanding is that he will go with the flow, whatever the government decides, or whatever the member for North Sydney instructs him to say. We are offering a reward for the member for Parramatta (Mr Ross Cameron) on what his position is. But I make no apology for saying that I will respond to what I see are the needs and aspirations of my constituents. That is a bare minimum position for any member. Yes, it is true, I have changed my position on Badgerys Creek. Mr Hockey-Ha, hal The big change!  I have never denied that. But you go around as though I have kept this as some super secret from my constituents. It is also true that WESROC, representing regional organisations of councils, has come out against Badgerys Creek. Of all the councils in western Sydney that belong to WESROC-and they all belong-the only council that supports Badgerys Creek is Liverpool. Mr Hockey-What about Penrith?  erys Creek, as well as Blacktown, Parramatta, Merrylands, CampbelltownMr Mossfield-Camden.  able member for Greenway for reminding me of that. Time is running out on me, I regret to say.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: SYDNEY AIRPORT DEMAND
text: I suggest you ignore the member for North Sydney.  always attempted to follow your injunctions and, in trying to accede to your injunction, I do so but I admit to a great deal of difficulty. The Liberal Party are saying that they have this EIS process. I want to remind them that they promised an open process, a transparent process and an accountable process, and they are wimping out on these issues. If they believe that they can get Badgerys Creek up in this way, I believe that they will fail.. I say again that those who are in a position to greatly influence the outcome of the government's decision on Badgerys Creek in the western suburbs of Sydney are the members for Lindsay, Parramatta and Macquarie. I am sure that, as the campaign gets under way led by an alliance of councils in western Sydney, increasingly they will be asked to stand up for their constituents. If I could just finish, because I have only a minute left, by repeating: it is not fair for the member for Lyne to suggest that there is some split on the issue of the bill before us. In fact, all opposition members not only support the bill but also understand what led the member for Grayndler and the member for Watson to take the initiative on this matter that has led to this legislation. We in western Sydney regret what a lot of constituents have had to put up with in electorates surrounding Kingsford Smith airport. I say with great respect that no member really is entitled to say to us in western Sydney, 'Well, you know, you've got to put up with noise pollution. You've got to put up with pollution.' We are not going to cop it. Prevailing attitudes to airports have changed. Whilst I believe it is an urgent necessity to seek relief from Kingsford Smith airport, I am not convinced that Badgerys Creek is a solution in the 1990s and beyond.

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Title: SYDNEY AIRPORT DEMAND
text: I am certainly pleased to support the principles embodied in this Sydney Airport Demand Management Bill 1997, given that it arose from a private member's bill moved by me in this House and seconded by the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo MCLeay). All I can say is that it is about time. It is about time that this government started to make some genuine decisions and progress about Kingsford Smith airport and what it will do about the hundreds of thousands of residents that are affected by its ever increasing noise. This is a government characterised by prevarication, delay and an avoidance of making the tough decisions. The delay in this bi1I is symptomatic of the lack of leadership from the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that we have seen on a range of issues. Ever since the coalition came to government, it has been delaying action on the Sydney airport problem.· Despite Holsworthy. being a clearly unsuitable site-coming second last in the last EIS process-the. government set up a process so as to delay the decision about the second Sydney airport for yet another year. Despite clear election promises to introduce a cap of 80 movements an hour, the government did not raise the issue until this month, 18 months into office. It took a private member's bill from the opposition to put this issue on the agenda. For a whole year, the government has tried to avoid having a debate on my private member's bill before this House. Its delaying tactics take a toll not only on the credibility of this government but in more real ways on the people who have to live under Sydney airport's flight path. These people have been kept waiting over this period by this government's indecision. I first made the demand for a cap in my private member's bill, the Sydney Airport (Regulation of Movements) Bill 1996, which was introduced and had its first reading on 4 November 1996. The second reading was on 18 November. After the government failed to respond to this challenge and decided to delay the decision, I made repeated calls for the cap, including in the grievance debate on 10 February 1997 and in a speech concerning the Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill (No.1) 1997 on 18 March 1997. On 19 June 1997, the member for Watson and I tried to suspend standing orders to bring on the debate regarding the Sydney Airport (Regulation of Movements) Bill. I raised the issue again in the debate on the Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2) 1997 on 26 June 1997. Why were we so concerned about pursuing this? Because Kingsford Smith airport accounts for 49 per cent of all passenger traffic in Australia, and this level of passenger traffic is on the increase. In 1965-66, 2.6 million passengers passed through this airport; in 1995-96, 20.3 million passengers passed through the same airport. This figure is expected to double by the year 2009, with an estimated 40.4 million passengers expected to pass through Sydney. Currently, residents who live around Kingsford Smith airport experience up to 753 aircraft movements per day. By 1999-2000, they will have to experience an average of 866 aircraft movements per day. Added to this, as we all know, Sydney airport-and my electorate-is surrounded by the most densely populated urban area of Australia. A recent Airservices Australia report stated that the number of people living in the 20 ANEF contour range has increased from 68,380 to 116,860. That is over 100,000 people per day putting up with a substantial level of aircraft noise. By and large they are not the people on the far North Shore of Sydney, I might remind my Labor colleagues; by and large they are working people in inner city electorates who have voted Labor their whole lives. That is why we need a solution to this issue. No doubt aircraft noise will continue to increase until a second Sydney airport in the Sydney basin-which is the only place it can be-is built. Kingsford Smith airport, of course, is continuing to expand. This government's decision to delay the building of the second international airport has also been taken in a period when they have supported the expansion of international facilities at Kingsford Smith airport. Ironically, the decision to expand KSA has been the only decision the government has made with regard to the airport issue that has not involved delaying tactics. On 19 J,une 1997, the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works announced that the international terminal at KSA should be upgraded at a cost of $350 million. On 29 August 1997, Senator Robert Hill, Minis-er for the Environment, concluded that an EIS for the expansion of the international terminal at Kingsford Smith airport was not required. So I say to my colleagues on both sides of the House: let us not have any of this nonsense about people being concerned about people around the inner city and not being concerned with Sydney West; we are getting an expansion of facilities and an expansion of flights without an EIS. Interestingly, however, the Public Works Committee noted in their final recommendation that: Any further development of Sydney airport should have appropriate environmental clearances before being referred to the committee. In that, the Public Works Committee is clearly stating its dissatisfaction with the government's crash-through approach on this issue. The com-ittee was clearly concerned about subjecting the residents around Sydney airport to increased noise and pollution, even if John Sharp and Senator Hill were not. The committee also noted that, because no decision had yet been made on the location of a second Sydney airport, the expansion of KSA had to occur. Why has a decision not been made about the second Sydney airport, despite the commitment of the government, prior to the election, to build a second Sydney airport, despite the fact that there was an obvious growing need for a second Sydney airport and despite the fact that the previous Labor government had already allocated $306 million for airport development at Badgerys Creek, $21 million for a control tower and firefighting services, $23 million for environmental safeguards, $480 million for roads, $17 million for a rail corridor and had already spent $152 million on land acquisitions around Badgerys Creek? Despite all this, what we had was· a delay in the EIS process because of the Holsworthy fiasco. That delay has meant an expansion at Sydney airport. We all know that Holsworthy was never seriously a contender. It had already been considered and knocked over. However, the government proceeded with the sham and told us all it considered Holsworthy a potential site. The government was becoming famous for its delaying tactics when, in the budget of 20 August 1996, it allocated $21 million for the EIS for the Badgerys Creek and Holsworthy second airport options. When the draft EIS was released, of course we all knew that Holsworthy had been excluded, but at a cost of delay to the second Sydney airport, at a cost of an ever increasing expansion at Sydney airport and at a cost of millions of dollars to the taxpayer. We are now back at the point at which we were in March 1996. All this has achieved is the alienation of thousands of people in southwestern Sydney around Holsworthy airport. How can we trust this government's commitments to solving the problem at Kingsford Smith airport when the only real, concrete action we see is the expansion of facilities at Kingsford Smith airport? The other issues which have come before the Sydney Airport Community Forumchaired by the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey)-unfortunately have also been ignored by this government.
