We have seen the movement of the threshold on the third runway where a clear decision by the Sydney Airport Community Forum was knocked over by the previous Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the member for Hume (Mr Sharp). We have seen the long-term operating plan proceed. I do not argue that everything in the long-term operating plan is bad, because clearly it is not. Clearly, aircraft noise has been an ever increasing problem over decades at Sydney airport, and clearly no government, Labor or conservative, can say it has a proud record on these issues, because I do not believe any of them have. Let me say that the main problem I see with the long-term operating plan is the number of take-offs to the north, which it clearly favours, rather than take-offs to the south. They are clearly favoured for one reason and one reason only: if a plane takes off to the north, it can veer to the west all over the western parts of my electorate, the Ashfield municipality, and all over the electorate of Lowe whereas if it lands from the north it has to fly over the electorate of Bennelong. It seems to me that the priority of this government has been to protect the residents of the North Shore of Sydney at the expense of the residents to the immediate north of the airport. There have been a number of other issues brought up by the Sydney Airport Community Forum which are yet to be addressed. There is the issue of those people closest to the airport. I say to the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson), who spoke last night about the terrible noise that people in Turramurra suffer, that those same planes are a hell of a lot lower when they are over Sydenham than when they are over Turramurra. And hearing is not related to income. People who cannot afford to live at Turramurra-they would probably like to but have to live in weatherboard houses in Sydenham-do not have different hearing from the people in Turramurra. They are the same planes; they are just 10 times noisier when they are over the residents of Sydenham and St Peters. The member for North Sydney and others to their credit have visited Sydenham and shown a genuine sympathy f9r the residents around the Sydenham-St Peters area. I congratulate the member for North Sydney and thank him for his efforts on behalf of those residents which I believe have been very genuine. But the fact is that the residents of Sydenham are still waiting for two major questions to be answered. They are waiting to hear about the issue of those people who are living in weatherboard houses which cannot be insulated. They live in weatherboard houses because they are living in the suburb with probably the lowest income in Sydney. The average income is certainly a lot lower than the electorates of Prospect or Greenway. They have the cheapest houses in Sydenham. I can assure honourable members that in the inner west housing boom that is going on prices are not increasing in Sydenham and St Peters. What is happening is that the houses cannot be insulated and they are just being left as a result of the government's failure make a decision. The government should make a decision regarding those residences. We have a buy-out program that has been approved unanimously by the Sydney Airport Community Forum and those residents deserve certainty. We have heard a lot over the last couple of days about the government's commitment to small business. But I say to Peter Reith or anyone else in the government, 'Go down, to Sydenham, just as Lindsay Tanner, the shadow minister, has done twice since the election and have a look at the boarded up shops there.' If you acquire a whole suburb of 151 houses, you knock them over literallydemolish the houses-and you are left with a park, it is not surprising that the news agent, the chemist and the local stores all close; and those people deserve compensation. Yes, the Labor Party acquired those houses and, yes, that was a great program, because you cannot leave people living in an over-40 ANEF noise zone. The former minister showed his ignorance of the issue. Perhaps he should have come down to Sydenham. I invite the member for Lowe, Paul Zammit, to come down. I am sure that I can organise one week living in Sydenham in one of these houses free of charge for any MP or adviser on the other side of the House. I will even give them TA-which the government is concerned about-out of my own pocket to live there for a week and argue that those houses should not have been demolished and that people should not have been given compensation and allowed to live in first world conditions. Last night I was amazed that the member for Bradfield praised the former transport minister for the personal time and effort he had put in in visiting the people of Pymble. The member for Bradfield said: Despite his extremely busy schedule-and, despite... the very secure margin of Bradfield in ... returning a Liberal member-he was even prepared to see individual members of my electorate who were concerned and on the verge of psychological despair over airport noise. Dear, dear! The people from Turramurra suffering from psychological despair. In 18 to months the former minister did not come to Sydenham, my electorate or to the area which is most affected. The shadow transport minister, two visits; government, zero. I ask whoever the incoming transport minister is to come to my electorate, sit down and talk to the people there and experience what the noise is. I say to people on my own side of the House, to Labor members, or any other MP who supported the third runway, 'Come and stand in Yelverton Street, Sydenham and tell me it was a good decision.' And none of them have. All the economic rationalists from whatever side of politics cannot defend the decision to build the third runway. I want to conclude by talking about Sydney West airport and the need for it to be built. I want to quote the report of the New South Wales Labor government's Standing Committee on Public Works, chaired by Paul Crittenden. It is a great report, entitled Report on State Infrastructure Requirements for Sydney West Airport. In the executive summary it says: SWA offers Western Sydney the opportunity to secure a commercially viable international airport with an associated commercial/industrial complex that will complement and reinforce other economic development catalysts planned for the region. These projects represent a strategic infrastructure network that will significantly enhance the region's tive base, create jobs and provide opportunities for residential development in the SWA Sub-Region. This report outlines the measures needed to ensure that the environmental impact on residents of Sydney West are minimised. Noone who lives in or represents the area, noone who has experienced the trauma of Sydney airport, is about repeating the exercise or transferring the problem to Sydney West airport. It is important that there is a proper EIS and that the problems are not repeated. I support the residents of Sydney's western suburbs in seeking to ensure that the chaos around Sydney airport is not repeated. We do need to get a bit fair dinkum about this debate and to point out that the members around Sydney airport are not saying, 'No aircraft noise.' That is the lunatics in the No Aircraft Noise Party. We are not saying, 'Shut Sydney airport.' I have never said that. It would be opportunistic and I would be probably get a bigger swing if I did say that. But I am not saying that, because it is unrealistic-just as it is unrealistic to argue that Sydney does not need a second airport. In my view, it is worse than unrealistic to argue for airports at places like Goulburn and Williamstown, because that mea.ns an expanded Kingsford Smith airport. There is only one option, and it is now Badgerys Creek airport, as we have argued since the election. To give one figure from the draft EIS, the maximum number of people who will be living in the 20 ANEC range around Badgerys Creek is 3,000. There are over 120,000 people around Sydney airport. Compare apples with apples and not apples with oranges. What we need to do in terms of Sydney West airport is ensute that the mistakes are not repeated. )"/ I conclude by saying that the member for Bradfield suggested, in quoting me' out of context from an article, that I had said: 'Only a Labor or a Liberal government could fix the problem.' I did say that during the'eleCtion campaign, because I do not believe tHat the No Aircraft Noise Party or independents can solve anything. I am a big political' party person, and I believe that only governments, not individuals, provide real solution,s. He competiquoted me out of context, but he did not mention who wrote the article. It was Chris Falvey-John Sharp's adviser. So he has quoted it as an independent source. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr RONALDSON
Title: SYDNEY AIRPORT DEMAND
text: Ballarat-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development) (11.25 a.m.)-in reply-It was a fascinating evening last night and has been an even more fascinating morning. Those people listening in the gallery today would wonder whether indeed the ALP supported this Sydney Airport Demand Management Bill 1997. I can tell them that in actual fact they do, which may well surprise them, given the nature of the debate. Indeed, the shadow minister for transport, the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner), said that it was a good bill. I congratulate him on that, but I will not be congratulating him on much else that was said during the debate. The one thing that needs to be remembered in this debate is that we went to the last election with a policy of a cap of 80 movements per hour and, as with every election promise that we have made in relation to Sydney airport, we have kept to it. We have developed an agreed means with industry about how to give effect to that cap of 80 movements per hour. With the greatest respect to the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese), who was playing catch-up politics with his private member's bill, I suspect that it might actually have been a bit of a preselection ploy-that is what we reckon on this side of the House-that he needed to be seen to be doing something. But all his bill did was meet half of our election commitment. What he did not do was have the mechanism for the implementation. So :hehad a bit of paper, which was our election policy, and he said, 'Right. I've got that through. I'll put it on the table and I'll walk away.' Where - as the mechanism? Nowhere at all. He avoided the hard issue: the mechanism for the implementation. It was catch-up politics. He took our election campaign policy but did not have the means or the wherewithal to put in place the mechanism for. the implementation. At the end of the day, that meant that it was a first come first serve basis, which was going to be absolutely inappropriate and disastrous for the Sydney airport. The point to remember about our long-term operating plan for Sydney is that it meets our commitment to maximise flights over water and non-residential land and to more equitably share the noise generated by the airport. It is a fair policy that has been implemented by this government. Indeed, the assertion that there would be no flights over Bennelong was just a bit more cheapjack politics from those on the other side. The member for Grayndler knows that it is not true. It was absolutely untrue, a bit of a gee-up to keep the pot boiling but with no basis at all. Indeed, this plan is about sharing aircraft noise and about getting away from the funnelling across specific residential areas that was done by the previous government. The targets for the plan should be known by those opposite. They made no reference to it. They wanted to avoid the issue. They did not want to make the acknowledgments. The targets for the plan are 55 per cent of movements to the south-basically Botany Bay17 per cent to the north, 15 per cent to the west and 13 per cent to the east. It is sharing the noise. But what did the Labor Party have? They had over 50 per cent of movements over suburbs north of the airport. As the member for Grayndler knows acutely, the residents north of the airport never got a break under the Labor Party. We have already cut it to 33 per cent and, as he well knows, our target is to cut it to 17 per cent. The utter hypocrisy of the Labor Party, both before this debate and during it, is absolutely mind blowing. They went to the last election, as the member for Lowe (Mr Zammit) and the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) know, with not one commitment to a cap. Mr Albanese-I wasn't here then.

Speaker: Mr RONALDSON
Title: SYDNEY AIRPORT DEMAND
text: Oh! In AFL terms, that is the big free kick, the big handball: 'I wasn't here.' You poor little dear! What did you do about it before you got here? You let the residents of Sydenham boil and stew in aircraft noise. What have you done since you got here? You have done even less for the residents of Sydenham since you got here. What Labor promised at the last election was more of the same-nonstop jets on parallel runways such that the suburb of Sydenham was needlessly demolished at a cost of $30 million. Let us forget the cost. Let us talk about the people of Sydenham. Let us talk about the mums and the dads and the kids of Sydenham who, because of the ALP, went through sheer hell. What are we going to do? We have cut that from over 50 per cent, and our target is to cut it down to around 17 per cent. That is good for the people of Sydenham, who have been through sheer hell. I want to talk briefly about Badgerys Creek. This government is fully committed to building a second major airport for Sydney to a full international standard as a matter of priority, subject to an appropriate EIS process. The EIS process will be very different from Laurie's EIS process. We all remember that, don't we? What a deceptive little number that EIS process was from the member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton). We are doing it. It will be transparent. It will result in the right decision. We are absolutely firmly committed to it. Mr Zammit-It's 'Lauriegate'.

Speaker: Mr RONALDSON
Title: SYDNEY AIRPORT DEMAND
text: 'Lauriegate' indeed. I want to turn to a couple of matters raised by the member for Melbourne. I will give him his due and say that he was very quick in the first minute of his speech on this matter to say that the Labor Party supported the bill. Mr Albanese-It's our bill.

Speaker: Mr RONALDSON
Title: SYDNEY AIRPORT DEMAND
text: Oh! We have the poor little possum back again with some more comments about it. You weren't there, and then you were there,and then you weren't there. You are all over the. place, Anthony. You know that you are all over the place. You are not a bad bloke on a personal level, but you are all over the place with this. You do not know whether 'you are coming or going. It is just extraordinary. We had the member for Melbourne pleading the case for· the people of Sydenham: 'I have been there, and I have heard it, and I have seen it.' Do you know who caused it? The Australian Labor Party. The Australian Labor Party destroyed Sydenham, and here we have the shadow minister crying crocodile tears for the people of Sydenham. He went on to criticise the long-term operating plan, which is providing relief for the very people that he was talking about.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: SYDNEY AIRPORT DEMAND
text: They started pulling their houses down.

Speaker: Mr RONALDSON
Title: SYDNEY AIRPORT DEMAND
text: Indeed. They were the ones that put $30 million into pull people's houses down. They did absolutely nothing about it. I have a question for the member for Melbourne. What is fair about destroying the suburb of Sydenham? What is fair about that? Mr Albanese--:--Madam Deputy.Speaker, on a point of order

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: SYDNEY AIRPORT DEMAND
text: Frivolous, I can tell. Look at the smile on his face. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mrs Sullivan)-I hope it is not a frivolous point of order. Mr Albanese--:--Of course it will not be, Madam Deputy Speaker. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER-I will judge that. Mr Albanese--:--As the parliamentary secrehe tary knows full well, what is fair about leaving people in noise affected areas? That is what this government would suggest. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER-Order! Resume your seat.

Speaker: Mr RONALDSON
Title: SYDNEY AIRPORT DEMAND
text: What is fair about making one group of residents the virtual sole receivers of airport noise? There is nothing fair about that at all. I think the comment from the former Minister for Transport ;and Regional Development, the member for Hume (Mr Sharp), in this House on 29 May probably sums up what this is all about He said: The real winners in this are people directly to the north of the airport-people in the Labor stronghold suburbs of Sydenharn, Marrickville, Stanmore, Petersham, St Peters, Leichhardt and Drummoyne, who were unfairly treated by Labor in government and who are being treated faidy by the coalition in government. . That summed it up lock, stock and barrel. I would like to give enormous credit to the member for North Sydney, the member for Lowe, the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) and the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile). I would like to thank them on behalf of their constituents .and the people of Sydney for doing the right thing with aterrible problem. They have done it and they have delivered. I would now like to tum to the member for Barton (Mr MCClelland). I really felt desperately sorry for the member for Barton. He said that he basically agreed. In fact, his words were: There is not a lot that the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) has said with which I disagree. When that is the Labor Party and this is the government, that is code for: 'I agree with every single thing that you said.' Mr Albanese--:--It's olir bill.

Speaker: Mr RONALDSON
Title: SYDNEY AIRPORT DEMAND
text: I am going to talk about Backflip Bob soon, so you ought to hang around and listen to that. Basically, the member for Barton said that everything the member for North Sydney said was right. So that means it is a fair plan. Labor is hypocritical. It is hypocritical on Badgerys Creek. Indeed, as raised by the member for North Sydney, Backflip Bob does not know whether is coming or going. We thank the member for Barton for supporting your comments in relation to that-very generous. He said: The position of the Australian Labor Party is to support the construction of a second Sydney airport at Badgerys Creek. I will continue the quote-it is not my quote-from the member for Barton: As the actress said to the bishop, 'Just do it.' Thht ;brings me to the next point. We all knqwthat Bishop Bob Carr hasgone off the boit The impotent Bishop Bob is either unWilling or unable to· 'just do it'. We then had the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio). It is a shame that Hansard cannot record my facial expression. But, for the benefit of Hansard, there is a look of horror ort my face in· relation to the member for Prospect. This is the very person who stood up here last night and attacked the Badgerys Creek proposal. But she was quite happy to be part of a Labor government which promised to fast track an international 24-hour airport on the same site-the one and· the same. It is amazing what happens when you go from here on the government benches to there on the opposition benches. We had the same thing from the member for Chifley (Mr Price)-Hopalong Cassidy. He hopped from the government across to the opposition and totally changed every single thing he had said about Badgerys Creek in the space of about 35 seconds. After 13 years he changed in 35 seconds. Over he went. He completely changed what he said. As I said before, we are going to have a transparent EIS process. Those members should know that. I have already spoken about the member for Grayndler. I am not going to talk any more about that because I want to turn to the New South Wales Labor Party, the New South Wales ALP government-the great hypocrites in the debate about Badgerys Creek. The member for North Sydney mentioned some of this last night, but I will take the opportunity to do so as well. On 28 November 1994: State Labor has a strategy to build Badgerys airport by the end of 1997. On 10 May 1995: Fast tracking Sydney west airport will create thousands of new construction and service industry jobs in Sydney's west. Thousands of jobs in Sydney's west, yet the state ALP wants to destroy jobs, destroy the economy, destroy tourism, destroy exports. You name it, they want to destroy it. Backflip Bob. The Daily Telegraph of 21 May: Mr Carr said that Badgerys Creek was the best site for a second airport and the government needed to set the plan in motion immediately. I will quote the member for Kingsford-Smith too-this is fairly interesting: The major beneficiaries of these developments are the people of western Sydney. There will be a significant direct and indirect employment opportunity available in western Sydney and Macarthur region flowing out of these works. The establishment of a major airport is also likely to attract other industries to the region, again with consequent employment opportunities for western Sydney. But who has been driving the anti-Badgerys Creek process? Minister Knowles and a few of the ones that are sort of weaseling around over on the other side there, giving Knowles a bit of a push along: 'Go on, mate. Go on, you do it. We can't say much al?out it because we're fully compromised on this, but you go and do it.' Within minutes. of the Holsworthy decision being made, the New South Wales planning minister, Craig Knowles, said that the New South Wales state ALP government would at all costs be opposing Badgerys Creek. Who is going to pay for that? Not Backflip Bob. You know who is going. to pay for it as well as I do. The New South Wales taxpayers are going to pay for this. They are going to pay dearly for it if you continue to oppose it. Of course, all this happened when Backflip Bob was overseas. Knowles came out and said, 'We're going to put our full resources into opposing Badgerys Creek.' Premier Carr has got to make it quite clear, once and for all, whether he does or does not support Badgerys Creek. Roger, you know that as well as I do. He either puts Knowles Creek down or he supports him. If he is going to support him, he had better come clean and tell the people of New South Wales. And he ought to tell you guys as well. At the moment your strict policy is Badgerys Creek-you know it as well as I do-but Backflip Bob and Knowles are trying to squeeze it. Let us have a look at what this means. Let us cut to the quick on this and look at what it means. It means quite simply that, if you do not proceed with the second airport, Bob Carr needs to explain to all those voters in Labor's inner city heartland that this is code for lifting the curfew, lifting the cap of 80 movements per hour, building a fourth runway and squeezing more than 60 million passengers into Sydney airport-three times more than there are now. To quote the member for Watson (Mr Leo MCLeay), 'Bigger, noisier, nastier.' Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Message from the Governor General recommending appropriation announced. Third Reading Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith. Bill (on motion by Mr Ronaldson) read a third time. NA

Speaker: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Madam Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mrs Sullivan)-Do you claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Yes, I do. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER-Please proceed.

Speaker: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Allegations raised in today's media about the use of an airstrip in the south of my electorate are completely groundless. The registered commercial pilot sometimes engaged by me to transport me to this part of my electorate uses the airstrip on the property Orungal because it is the only all-weather airstrip located between Toowoomba and Goondiwindi. It is sealed, lit and has navigational aids. It is an approved landing area. I have landed at the airstrip to attend to official duties in Texas, Inglewood and at Waroo and Terrica. These locations are all within a maximum driving time of 30 minutes from Orungal. There are no airstrips located closer to these centres that are of a comparable standard to Orungal. The owner of the Orungal property is a registered commercial pilot who has been flying me on the occasions I have landed at the airstrip. I have only come to know the owner as a result of the occasions on which I have used his charter services. I have never gone-by flight or by any other means-to Orungal for the purpose of visiting the owners. Mr Crean-I'm seeking indulgence. Mr Reith-No, you don't have indulgence. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER-Order! No, the member should seek leave. Do you· wish to make a comment? Mr Crean-Yes, I do-on indulgence. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER-No, I ask you to seek leave, please. Mr Crean-Then I seek leave on indulgence. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER-Is leave granted? Mr Reith-No. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER-Leave is not granted. Mr Crean-I'm seeking indulgence. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER-I'm not granting indulgence. I asked you to seek leave. I left it to the House to decide. Mr Crean-What's the cover-up? Who's the pilot? Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER-Resume your seat You don't have the call. Resume your seat. Mr Crean-Let the record show that you would not answer fully in this House. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER-Resume your seat. I warn the member for Hotham. NA 1997 Second Reading Debate resumed from 25 September, on motion by Mr Williams: That the bill be now read a second time. upon which Mr Gareth Evans moved by way of amendment: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: ". "wh.ilst not declining to give the Bill a second rea?in?, the House notes that: (l),nativetitle rights, including on pastoral leases, - oare. t'undamentallegal property rights, acknow1edged and upheld as such by the High Court, and entitled to the same respect and protection as ·the property rights of non-Indigenous Australians: any amendment of the Native Title Act in response to the Wik decision or for any other reason must fully reflect that r<,ality; (2) iUs in the national interest that the Act balance and reconcile to the maximum possible extent the interests and reasonable expectations of both Indigenous Australians and other major stakeholders-farmers, miners and Australian taxpayers generally; (3) it is both in the national interest, and in the interests of Indigenous Australians, farmers and miners, that there be the maximum possible predictability and certainty about the status of the Act and its practical operation; (4) there is a need, in particular, to guarantee the constitutional validity of the legislation, by ensuring that legislation operates for the net benefit of Indigenous Australians; (5) it is also in everyone's interest that the processes established by this legislation to deal with the registration and determination of claims, and the reconciliation of competing interests, be as effective and expeditious as possible; (6) there are aspects of the Bill which may advance these objectives, in particular by encouraging and assisting the entering into of agreements, and by setting a stricter regime for the . registration of claims; (7) nonetheless, the Bill is seriously deficient, and requires substantial amendment, in many respects, including: (i) the reach of the validation provisions beyond that which is necessary for the practical redress of postWik problems; (ii) the manifestly unacceptable over-reach of the provisions purporting to confirm the extinguishment of native title where exclusive tenure has previously been involved; (iii) the unnecessarily broad application, in relation to coexistence on pastoral of the statutory authorisation of nonpastoral activities; (iv) the unnecessarily broad application of extinguishment in relation to the provision of government services and public works; (v) theindefensibly limited test for allowing statutory access rights for registered claimants; (vi) the dramatic limitation of the right to negotiate, and in particular its effective elimination in relation to mining on pastoral leases, which (along with the provisions amounting to direct or de facto extinguishment) significantly tilts the balance of the legislation against indigenous Australians; (vii) the unacceptable limitation on the effective enjoyment of the right to negotiate which is involved in powers of early ministerial intervention; (viii) the absurd and counterproductive sunset clause, which will simply ensure a proliferation of ambit claims under the Act, and the pursuit of future claims through expensive and complex common law processes; (ix) the inappropriately rigid mid legalistic constraints on Registrars in the management of claims; and (x) the inappropriate introduction of formal rules of evidence, and limitations on the extent to which cultural and customary concerns can be taken into account, in the Federal Court claims process".

Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Title: NATIVE TITLE AMENDMENT BILL
text: I wish today to associate myself with the remarks made by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) in this debate and to support the second reading amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans). I will be more general and briefer in my remarks than usual, given the lengthy list of speakers on our side and our undertaking to the government and publicly to ensure that the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 goes from the House to the Senate by the end of October. I hope to participate in the consideration in detail stage of the debate, which will occur after the Joint Statutory Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund reports on 27 October, by which time this House and the members of it leases, will have had the chance to contemplate the submissions made to that committee, the evidence received and the committee's report. At the heart of our attitude to the bill before the House today is the desire to make native title processes more certain, to make the act more workable, to make sure that the act is fair, and to make sure that the act is predictable. They are the hallmarks that the Leader of the Opposition has set down for our consideration of this bill. We want to see a native title process which is more certain, fair and workable. In my own case, I take part in this debate as a member of the parliament when the Native Title Act 1993 was passed by this House; as a Western Australian whose state, in practical terms, is the state most affected by the provisions of the Native Title Act; and as the shadow minister for resources and energy. The starting point for this debate is the Mabo No. 2 decision of the High Court of June 1992. The essential element of that decision by the High Court was that native title was recognised as a common law property right-a legal property right. That raised fundamental property and constitutional questions for the parliament to respond to. The subsequent High Court decision in the Wik case, which made the point that native title is not extinguished by pastoral leases, has seen this set of amendments come to the House. The key starting point is native title being recognised by the High Court as a fundamental property right. One of the difficulties that the then government and this parliament faced in 1993 was that this recognition came a couple of hundred years too late. In comparable jurisdictions such as the United States of America, Canada and New Zealand, the notion of a native title property right had been recognised much earlier. What this parliament and the previous government had to do was to grapple with the insertion of a legal property right into our property law framework 200 years after the event, and try to grapple with that in a much more compressed timetable. The High Court also made the point in the Mabo case that, whilst it was open for native title to be extinguished by valid government activity with an intention to so extinguish, there was no right of compensation at common law. However, any extinguishment had to be consistent with the Racial Discrimination Act. That was a view that the High Court took by a majority of six to one. i It is interesting to make the point that it was only by a four to three majority that the High Court in Mabo No. 2 said that compensation was not payable for any extinguishment of native title from inception. In other words, the High Court was one vote away from saying that native title, however so extinguished from the first moment of European settlement in this place, was compensatable. That is an important point which I will come to subsequently. So what the parliament had to do then and what the parliament has to do now is to work through a fundamental property right. There is one of two ways that the parliament or a government can go: either you can say, 'Let us leave it to the courts,' or you can say, 'Let us try to find some statutory process to manage this fundamental property right.' That was the attitude that the previous government took and that saw the enactment of the Native Title Act of 1993 through this parliament. If this parliament wants to legislate, this parliament can legislate only if it finds a valid head of power. In this area, given that until the decision of the High Court in Mabo No. 2 property rights had effectively been managed by state and territory jurisdictions, you need to find a Commonwealth head of power. There are only two Commonwealth heads of power that this parliament can resort to in this matter: the external affairs power and the race power as a consequence of the referendum change in 1967. So what are the limitations that the parliament then and the parliament now finds upon itself? It is dealing with a fundamental property right. It has got limited Commonwealth power and, therefore, constitutional limitations and implications. And, in a practical sense, it has to find a statutory regime which is attractive enough to the parties concerned to use it, because it remains open to any party to go to the courts to pursue a common law claim for native title. So, in addition to grappling with constitutional problems and in addition to grappling with a fundamental property right, you have to make the process attractive enough so that people want to use it. It is also desirable ensure that whatever process you establish encourages agreement rather than litigation. So they are some of the legal hurdles and some of the practical hurdles which this parliament now finds before it. The Native Title Act of 1993 has seen good outcomes and some bad outcomes. think the best outcome is the Yandicoogina agreement entered into between Hamersley Iron, a company operating in the north-west of Western Australia, and threelocal Aborigi2 nal tribal groups who formed a corporation, the Gumala Aboriginal Corporation, to reprewas sent them. The end result of the agreement between Hamersley Iron and the Aboriginal communities represented by that corporation sees a $705 million iron ore development go ahead, a maximum $60 million royalty stream to that Aboriginal community and, most law importantly, commitments to ensure that investment which goes to that Aboriginal community is an investment by way of jobs, by way of training, by way of community infrastructure and by way of improvements education. I think that is the best example of a regiontion al agreement that we have. On the other hand, you have the worse aspect of the Native Act of 1993, which has seen only one out of 600 claims proceed through the tribunal. In reference to a visit that I and the Leader of the Opposition made recently to Kalgoorlie, the Leader of the Opposition made the point in his speech that Kalgoorlie is perhaps the worse example where we see multiple claims, overlapping claims and an uncertain So on the one hand we see a good utilisation of regional agreements and on the other hand we see the need to massively improve processes. How do we fix this process? do we on the one hand continue to encourage regional agreements with those organisations that have the resources to do it and on the other hand fix the processes? This gets to heart or the fundamentals of the bill that the government has placed before the House. The great difficulty for this House and the parliament is that the government's bill does not make it better; the government's makes it worse. The government's bill has to serious constitutional question marks attached to it, will raise serious questions of just compensation and will encourage common law claims and the pursuit of claims before federal courts, state supreme courts and the High Court rather than discourage them. So some the solution which the government has put I before the parliament will make it worse rather than make it better. I alluded earlier to the compensation point and I said that the High Court in Mabo No. was one vote away from saying that native title, however so extinguished, from inception compensatable. If you have a look at what the High Court has recently said on compensation for property law entitlements, and a case that it has currently before it, it is clear that the High Court is in a mood to view very seriously the extinguishment ·of property entitlements and to apply a very rigorous the test so far as compensation is concerned. The most recent example we have seen coming out of the High Court was the comin pensation decision in respect of Coronation Hill. The High Court currently has before it a case dealing with Western Mining Corporaand the expropriation by the Commonwealth of petroleum exploration permits in the Title Timor Gap, expropriated by the Commonwealth to help enable the Australia-Indonesia zone of cooperation to go ahead in the Timor Sea. It will be interesting to see how that case is handled by the High Court, but there is now the question that the High Court these days is treating very seriously the notion of just compensation for the expropriation of process. property Jaw entitlements. The view which has been expressed by the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and is reflected by How the amendment which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has placed before the House outlines our view of the very serious constitutional and legal difficulties attached to this the bill. Our view has been sustained in recent days by the public release of a legal opinion prepared by the Australian Law Reform for Commission. As the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) last night described it on the ABC, bill the Australian Law Reform Commission is an 'independent, impartial and objective body'. What has the Australian Law Reform Commission had to say about the government's native title bill? It is not as if the government has been rushing off its feet to make this public, but on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald on Monday there is a reference to the Australian Law Reform Commission's opinion on the government's native title bill. The Sydney Morning Herald reports as follows: The submission, obtained by the Herald, said the Wik plan to effectively extinguish native title on pastoral leases is unconstitutional and "will yield more, not less, litigation and compound uncertainty and lack of confidence in Australian real property law". Most damaging for the government, it says the compensation payable would cripple taxpayers and hinder rather than promote mining development. It goes on to quote the opinion of the Law Reform Commission: The compensation implications of the bill are potentially so substantial that the Government ought to think very carefully before making such a large scale commitment of taxpayers' funds ... You do not need to go much further than paragraphs 1.7 and 4.10 of the Australian Law Reform Commission's comments on the Native Title Amendment Bill. At paragraph 1.7 the commission says: . . . the mechanism by which legal certainty for non-exclusive leaseholders is to be achieved will almost certainly fail on the grounds that it will yield more, not less, litigation and compound uncertainty and lack of confidence in Australian real property law. At paragraph 4.10 the commission, in respect of the compensation point, goes on to say: The Commission considers that the compensation implications of the Bill are potentially so substantial that the Government ought to think very carefully before making such a large scale commitment of taxpayers funds to the extinguishment of the property and cultural rights of indigenous Australians. The view reflected by the opposition's amendment is buttressed and supported by the Australian Law Reform Commission's opinion and view. The other day, in the course of debate, the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) referred to an article that I had written for the Australian Gas Association's quarterly journal where I made the point-quite openly-that on our side we regarded the Native Title Act 1993 as not producing a perfect result. 'jI'he member for Cowan referred to this as· iff this were somehow a stinging point. I would) like to draw his and the House's attention, to a speech I gave to the Australian Petroleum Producers and Exploration Association in April of this year, shortly after I became shadow minister for resources, where under the heading of 'Native Title' I said: The opposition will work in the national interest to seek an !j.cceptable outcome to native title, .Kim Beazley has made that clear both publicly and privately. The Native Title Act of 1993 is not perfect. However, when you are breaking new legislative ground, as we did with native title, that willaImost always be the case. As well, Federal Court and subsequent Tribunal decisions since have not helped the process or the procedures. Our proposed 1995 amendments reflected our own recognition that the Act was not perfect and that the procedures and processes needed to be improved and made more workable. These were not dealt with before the dissolution of Parliament and the election. One of the reasons the Act is not perfect is that the Senate amendments to the original Bill are imperfect. As Kim Beazley has said, we don't have a dog in the manger attitude to this issue, unlike the then Coalition Opposition, who in 1993 walked away in the Senate, leaving the Bill to the Greens CYVA) and Democrats. There is a clear national interest in an amendment Bill in the main being supported by both major political parties. That was the case in 1993, and it is the case now. If, however, you go down the extinguishment path, you will end up in the High Court forever, tying up development forever. There is in my view a better way through-we need a better, more workable process which will provide certainty and validity and which is fair to all the stakeholders. Those comments are reflected in the contributions made by the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. On our side we are committed to making sure the procedures under this act are clear, efficient and timely, but they will not be achieved in the form of the bill that the government has presented to the House. I'\'will conclude my remarks by quoting briefly· from the speech made by the Leader of tl1e 'Opposition on 21 September when he opened the debate for the opposition. He had this tp say: \ . The Wik case is a common law claim. It has been in the courts since June 1993. It is still there, mattei- of substance related to it yet to be determined.' That is four years down the track. Think of the 600 or so claims currently registered with the tribunal. The collapse, in the face of High Court challenge, of a badly amended act . . . by an unthinking government, would see all those cases, and more, clogging up our courts indefinitely. The pastoral industry might survive such a scenario but not the mining industry. The bill that the government has put before the House will not make matters better but make matters worse. It is a recipe for uncertainty, it is a recipe for multiple claims before the High Court and it is a recipe for massively clogging up the system altogether. The government should pay heed to the second reading amendment which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has placed before the House and should ensure that these matters are uppermost in its mind when it comes to, I hope, a proper, full, objective and fair consideration of these matters in the Senate.

Speaker: Mr DONDAS
Title: NATIVE TITLE AMENDMENT BILL
text: I have listened with a great deal of interest to what the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) had to say on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997, but I can only take into consideration all that has been said before in regard to native title amendment and the bill that is before us. I would say to the honourable member for Perth: you as part of the team got it very wrong in 1993 when the Prime Minister of the day clearly enunciated in his second reading speech that pastoral leases extinguished native title. You all voted on it. Mr Stephen Smith-And you are going to make it worse, mate.

Speaker: Mr DONDAS
Title: NATIVE TITLE AMENDMENT BILL
text: I am not making it worse. I am just saying that you were wrong then and you are wrong now. You will not let, and you will not give, the to-point plan of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), which is now being translated into legislation, an opportunity to work. It does give me a great deal of pleasure to rise this afternoon to discuss this very important piece of reforming legislation. The amendments will fix the diabolical mess left by the Labor Party in relation to the state of the land tenure system in this country. We all know with that in 1992 the High Court ruled in the landmark Mabo case that indigenous Australians' native title to land has always existed under common law. The High Court declared that native title held by indigenous people may survive, regardless of new laws enacted by a colonising government. Of course, the Mabo case specifically related to the Murray ISlands. However, the court noted that common law is the same across Australia and, therefore, native title may still exist on the mainland as well. This judgment by the High Court threw all existing land tenure systems in Australia into total disarray. Confusion reigned as to the status of leases held by pastoralists, miners and indigenous people, and there was concern about the ruling's impact on future development and access. The High Court's Mabo ruling dictated that the parliament issue an urgent and comprehensive legislative response in order to restore certainty. The Labor government acted when it introduced the Natiye Title Act in 1993, the most illconceived piece of legislation I think Australia has ever seen. In 1993 the coalition consistently declared the legislation unworkable and incomplete. I stand here today speaking on these amendments as proof that the opinion has sadly been proved correct. Four years and 600 native title claims later there has been only one determination of native title on mainland Australia. Meanwhile, thousands of honest hard working Australians have had their lives turned upside down by claims over their family farms and property. Companies wanting to develop land which would benefit this country's economy have had projects halted indefinitely by native title claims. Major developments in the Northern Territory worth hundreds of millions of dollars have had native title claims slapped on them and so cannot proceed. The Native Title Act was in urgent need of reform even before the coalition came to government. Once elected, the Prime Minister made it one of his priorities to fix this mess and appointed his parliamentary secretary, Senator Nick Minchin, to undertake a review of the act with a view to restoring certainty for both indigenous and non-indigenous Australians. The government started work on the amendments to the act immediately and waited with interest to see how the result of the Wik decision would affect the government's position. In December last year the High Court complicated matters further with the Wik ruling, which determined that pastoral leases do not necessarily extinguish native title. The government is determined to react responsibly to the challenges this ruling presents. The bill before the House today will reduce the uncertainties regarding land tenure, simplify the whole process in determining the existence of native title, improve the workability of the act, and increase the community's understanding of native title issues and processes. This bill is a result of the Prime Minister's and Senator Minchin's extensive consultation process. They have worked tirelessly to ensure that all interested parties have been consulted on the amendments proposed. At this point I would like to acknowledge the role the Northern Territory government played in these negotiations. I commend their efforts to ensure the situation in the territory was always prominent in the minds of those preparing this legislation. Out of these consulAffairs, tations came the government's 10-point plan which this legislation incorporates. Before commenting on the implications of this legislation for my constituents, I would like to remind honourable members of the exemplary record the Northern Territory has in the field of land rights for Aboriginal people. I got a bit sick of hearing from those Labor members opposite that the territory government is racist, and I think this is an opportune time to inform members of the real situation in the territory. Forty-eight per cent of the territory is covered by the title granted under the Aboriginal land rights act. That is almost 700,000 square kilometres of the Northern Territory. An Aboriginal benefits trust account allows for the progressive purchase of land throughout the territory, up to $20 million'per year. There is $1.4 billion in the Indigenous Land Fund, which should be sufficient to address the land needs of Aboriginal people. The Northern Territory already has community living areas. legislation which has resulted in living areaS for Aboriginals being excised from' pastoral properties. The tellitory has a comprehensive and effective sacr-d sites legislation, the single most important issue for traditional Aborigines. Aborigines have a statutory access regime in place for access to pastor-l lands for traditional activities like hunting and fishing. There is also a separate regime in place to allow access to sacred sites. The territory provides for the co-management of parks. There are now parks under joint control that would meet an international benchmark. In addition to these points, I would also like to add that, since the introduction of the Aboriginal land rights legislation, Aboriginal groups in the Northern Territory have been paid some $350 million in royalties. The evidence shows that the territory already has in place the mechanisms for recognition of indigenous people's traditional links with the land. Despite ATSIC spending $90 million of Commonwealth money on native title claims, the act has not delivered any tangible benefits to Aboriginal Australians. In fact, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Senator John Herron, has informed me that the state of Aboriginal affairs under Labor did not result in any gains in the area of Aboriginal health. There may have been gains in the area of land claims, but I have been informed by the minister that 30 per cent of Aboriginal children in Alice Springs still suffer from malnutrition. Meanwhile, someone in ATSIC decides that $90 million is better spent on land claims. This is why it is so important that the coalition government has a policy of quarantining ATSIC funds for health, housing and education programs, as it is clearly not always their priority. In addition to the 48 per cent of the territory already granted to Aboriginal groups, there are now extensive native title claims ovef our towns, beaches, public parks and the coa&t1ine. How can we forget the chaos that exists over the status of our pastoral leases? The 1previous Labor government developed the Native Title Act on the assumption that pastotalleases extinguished native title. The former Prime Minister stated that the government's view was 'under the common law, past valid freehold and leasehold grants extinguish native title. There is therefore no obstacle or hindrance to the renewal of pastoral leases in the future.' The High Court's Wik ruling proved him wrong. The Labor government's native title legislation was drafted on the assertion that less than 36 per cent of Australia's vacant crown land could be claimed. The Wik decision means that 78.6 per cent of Australia can now be claimed. State and territory governments will be able to legislate to allow the continuation and the protection of all existing activities defined primary production under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. These activities can be carried out without interference of native title holders. The coalition has worked very hard to fix the mess left by the Labor Party and this legislation is good for the territory. It addresses the concerns that territorians have about land tenure and delivers appropriate returns to Aborigines. The package guarantees the validity of any acts or grants issued on vacant crown land between the passage of the 1993 Native Title Act and the Wik decision. The territory government, acting in good faith, issued some exploration licences on the previously accepted premise that a pastoral lease extinguished native title, and these remain valid. State and territory governments will be able to confirm that native title is extinguished by 'exclusive' tenures like freehold, commercial and public works in existence on or before 1 January 1994. It is this provision that will ensure that most parts of the current claims over Darwin and Alice Springs will fail. Agricultural leases are also covered to the extent that, where it is reasonable to suggest through the purpose of the grant or the nature of the land use, exclusive possession is assumed. Any current or former pastoral lease conferring exclusive possession would also be included. Land grants from the Northern Territory government to bodies such as town councils would extinguish native title, meaning our parks and reserves could not be claimed. This legislation ensures that the provision of government services like pipelines, roads, railways and municipal services may not be impeded by native title claims. There will be a continuation of statutory access rights for native title claimants. This does not conflict with the current access rights enjoyed by Aborigines as a result of territory legislation. One of the most controversial aspects of Labor's legislation was the right to negotiate provisions in respect of mining and certain compulsory acquisitions. The right to negotiate has delayed many important commercial and mining developments Australia-wide. There have been no gains for Aboriginal people at the grassroots level through the as right to negotiate. It. often seems to be the case that Aboriginal land councils are more interested in achieving the right to negotiate for extraordinary amounts of financial compensation than in securing native title to land. A higher registration test will be required for claimants seeking the right to negotiate on future mining activity. Proof of attachment to a particular piece of land will have to be provided and claimants will not be able to impede mining exploration as there will be no negotiations on exploration licences. There will only be one right to negotiate per project. States and territories will be able to introduce their own mining regimes for dealing with land under their jurisdiction as long as the access rights of native title holders are not compromised. There will be no right to negotiate over vacant crown land outside towns and cities required for government type infrastructure. This is good news for high population growth areas like the territory as it means the government will have the ability to plan for schools, health clinics and powerlines with certainty. The ability of the territory government to regulate and manage airspace plus surface, subsurface and offshore waters would be put beyond doubt. The native title claim in Alice al capital, will be increased as a result of this framing of the legislation, rather than it benefiting consolidated revenue. As the commission concludes, it is seriously concerned: . . . that the government has . . . underestimated extent of compensation that will fall due as a consequence of the Bill. So there are two reasons for concern in relation to these issues that relate to the way in which what were previously grazing properties will be able to operate in the future should this legislation have effect. Firstly, there is an environmental concern which hitherto has been suppressed, despite advice to this government by its key biodiversity advisory body. Secondly, there is the cost of it, and the transfer of wealth from taxpayers to a handful of rich pastoralistsnot ordinary farmers. This has been suppressed as a consequence of the Attorney's suppression of the Australian Law Reform Commission. So there have been two acts of suppression, two acts of cover-urone on the environmental front, one on the Attorney's front-both designed to withhold from the Australian public the full implications of what this legislation intends. This legislation does not give either certainty or fairness. It is legislation which has been brought forward without proper consultation with those who wish this government well in finding a solution, and that includes the opposition. There is no interest in finding, with those of us on the other side, an effective outcome that benefits all stakeholders in this particular complexity. It now increasingly seems to be the case that we have a government that will not open its ears to independent critical comment, including comment that goes to the constitutionality, the legal validity and the compensation in the bill, or to the on-the-ground effects, particularly the environmental consequences. More than that, not only does it wish its own ears to remain deaf but also it wishes the Australian community to have its ears remain deaf. So we have the wise monkey approach: we have hear no evil and' see no evil, but we have a government that is perfectly prepared to speak the evil, and to speak it repe.ateclly. It is prepared to malign those who raise; any criticisms about the way it approaches this matter, and it is prepared to use language which is entirely inappropriate in terms of its the hostility and the conflict it is preparedJo stir up within the Australian community on this matter. ' So we get no certainty . We will find ourselves mired in more litigation. We find the cost to be underestimated. We find the government unprepared to recognise the impact this will have on the environment. We find an unwillingness on the part of the government to allow the work of those who have a critical and public role to play in Australia's. community debate. Those who are tasked with these responsibilities by government-the Biological Diversity Advisory Council and the Law Reform Commissionare having their work suppressed, and the Australian community is prevented from hearing what they are entitled to have put before them so they may put their views on these important public matters. Because of the way in which we are seeking to facilitate the conclusion of this debate within a reasonable time, I recognise that I should cut short my remarks at this point. I will conclude by saying that this government is mired in cover-ups of its own making which go not merely to its morality but also to public policy, and which now show the full impact of the malice that is behind it. The government is not prepared to deal with matters that we in opposition have been talking about for a longtime, which they have been criticising as coming from a partial commentator, whereas the fact is the impartial commentators who would otherwise have spoken have had their mouths silenced, quite improperly, by this government in a way which smacks of cover-up. Indeed, particularly given the pecuniary interests of certain front-bench members of this government, it almost suggests the smell of corruption.

Speaker: Mr COBB
Title: NATIVE TITLE AMENDMENT BILL
text: It is doubtful if there has ever been a more controversial, divisive, costly and relatively nonproductive decision in the history of the High Court in this country. I do not say that lightly. I represent a rural electorate. I represent Aboriginal people than anybody else in southregistered, east Australia. I have lived through· this debate over the last few years at the coalface, so to speak. There may be some of us who do not like the High Court decision, but it is now the of this country. Native title is now part of common law, and we must live with that and work with it. That is what I believe this reflects quite accurately. In 1992 the Mabo decision was brought they down by the High Court and they went on say that native title may exist on mainland Australia. In December 1996, the High Court brought down what is known as the Wik decision whereby they said that native title may exist on pastoral leases, and that was surprise to everybody. Even the present opposition did not factor that into their nal native title bill. Native title still has not been precisely defined by the High Court. I will use words of the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) when he made his second reading speech on this present bill. He said: Despite more than 3112 years of the operation of current act, for most of Australia we do not know where native title exists and, if it does, identity of the native title holders or the nature their rights. Of course we have to have rules for all this work, and this present bill clarifies these and adds some additional provisions to deal with the new concept of coexisting native title on pastoral lease land. Up until now there has been an expectation out there-especially amongst Aboriginal purchase people-that native title, including on pastoral leases, virtually equates to ownership. It not, of course. But as a result of this the Aboriginal industry has hurled money at making claim after ridiculous claim. There has been no limit on the size of the claim and of money. who may be registered. We have overlapping claims. One poor fellow with a mining lease in Western Australia has 26 overlapping claims on his mining lease. I am told that if you add up the size of land involved in all these claims it amounts to 143 per cent of the Australian land mass. more Six hundred and twelve claims have been over $100 million in legal fees has been wasted and we still do not have one square centimetre of native title land owned by Aboriginal people in Australia. In fact, there has only been one of the 612 claims law resolved and that was for a few acres of land our at Crescent Head on the North Coast of New South Wales and that was immediately sold bill back to the people who occupy the land. The land councils are forever claiming that want funds for quite proper activities that to need to be done amongst the Aboriginal people. But they have gone totally berserk on paying lawyers to chase frivolous native title claims. The Cape York Land Council is spending in excess of $12 million doing that a now. The Kimberley Land Council has spent in excess of $12 million. Even in New South origiWales, up to 30 June this year, the New South Wales Land Council has spent $4,433,475, including $2 million last year-a the total waste of money in the main. The red soil country around Brewarrina, Bourke and Wanaaring in my electorate where claims have been put in is selling for an the average of $8 an acre. It means that, if they yet had put that money into buying the land, they the could own in excess of 550,000 acres now of and own it outright. Even if native title were granted-and it will not be on the claims that have been put in so far-all they can do is go rules onto the land and hold a corroboree, which nobody is interested in doing in New South Wales, throw a line in the Darling River to fish or spear a goanna or something like that. Whereas if the money had been spent to the land like every other Australian, they could own the land outright. Money is does being wasted. It has caused incredible anguish, particularly amongst the landowners throughout my electorate, and it has set reconciliation back years. It is a wicked waste There is a myth afoot in this country that Aboriginal people own little or no land. The 1996 census showed that there are 353,000 Aborigines in Australia-that is, 2 per cent of the the population-and they owned 15.3 per cent of the land mass or 117 million hectares of land in Australia. That is greater in size the total land mass of New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania and the Australian Capital Territory or-if we can take an overseas example-greater than the land mass of Northern Ireland, Scotland, England, Wales, France and Germany, both East and West, put together. On top of this there is a certain amount of private land ownership. They own 341 properties and the last 200 that were purchased had an average value of $454,000 for the land alone. For example, that alone is more than double the land value of the property that I own. So we are not talking about insubstantial properties. In addition to all this,the New South Wales government puts aside 71J2 per cent of land tax collected to purchase properties. On those properties they also own all mineral rights, except for gold and silver, as well as oil and coal, and they get royalties from any mining conducted on those properties. There is also the indigenous land fund which is worth $1,289 million in 1994-95 dollar terms. The money put aside from that alone would purchase 100 farms for Aboriginal people every year forever-farms worth twice the value of my own property, for example. There have been other sources of funding. For example, the Northern Territory mining royalties to Aboriginal people now amount to more than $350 million. Under this legislation before the parliament today, 78.6 per cent of the Australian land mass is available for claim under native title legislation. One wonders if we have our priorities right. I saw a recent Medical Journal of Australia article on death rates in the Northern Territory. The most common cause of death amongst Aboriginal females was homicide. The most common cause of death amongst Aboriginal males was car accidents, closely followed by homicide, and the premature deaths of Aboriginal infants were four times the Australian average. It is an absolute disgrace. These are the sorts of things that we should reasons. be concentrating on and debating in this country today. But I see that ATSIC just recently funded an extra $80,000 to put a than challenge up against the Hindmarsh Island Bridge legislation, which everybody knows has absolutely no chance whatsoever of succeeding. It is doomed to fail, and $80,000 is totally wasted when they could be spending money in these proper areas that desperately need funding. My point'on this bill is that the High Court decision was supposed to deliver something benefiCial to Aboriginal people. So far it has delivered virtually nothing--certainly nothing on mainland Australia. In fact, it has wasted many millions of dollars. It has become an instrument of divisiveness. If you look at it objectively, it has become a curse to Aboriginal people in diverting these large sums of money to chasing ephemeral rainbows. I want to talk about pastoral leases, particularly those in New South Wales. The High Court said in the Wik decision that unless you have exclusive possession on leasehold land then native title may exist on leasehold land. This has caused much angst in New South Wales, but there has been a total misunderstanding of what the High Court said by both sides of the argument-Aboriginal on one side and pastoralists on the other. The New South Wales Farmers Association has attacked the coalition quite unfairly, I think, in calling us 'spineless, gutless, shallow' and just about every other colourful adjective that you can think of. I believe that they have whipped some people into an unnecessary frenzy on this. They have been asking for the grazing leases in the Western Division of New South Wales to be included in the schedule. They have done that almost to the exclusion of all other debate about the bill. There are a couple of points I would make. The schedule never existed until the coalition invented it, and it is attached to this bill. Of course, if the grazing leases are listed in the schedule, there is the belief that this makes them exempt from native title claims. That is true only if all sides of the debate accept that they should be in the schedule for proper There is a lot of legal advice around that there is some doubt as to whether these leases should be in the schedule. The New South Wales government's legal advice on two occasions said that they should not be scheduled. The Commonwealth took its own legal advice' from Professor Butt, an expert in property law who works in the law department' at the University of Sydney, and Grahame Tanna, who is the Principal Solicitor of the ,Attorney-General's Department. They clearly said in their legal advice to us that Western Division grazing leases do not confer a right of exclusive possession and should not be included in the schedule. We asked the New South Wales Farmers Association to get some legal opinion on this. They have eventually come before us with four opinions, but those four opinions· have some doubt about them. For example, the first opinion from David Bennett QC said in the conclusion: In these circumstances it is simply not possible to express with anything resembling certainty what view the High Court will take in relation to leases under the Western Lands Act. Further on in his conclusion, when talking about granting exclusive possession, he said: . . . the prospects of the High Court taking that view must be regarded as fairly evenly balanced. The second opinion that they obtained was from Peter MCEwen QC. Regarding the conclusions he had come to, he said: I have done so on the basis of relatively limited information. He also said: ... it is not possible to prognosticate the view Courtthat is, the High Courtwould take when applying the principles enunciated in Wik to leases under the Western Lands Act with certainty or precision. The third opinion they put to us was from Dennis Rose QC who said that the leases should be scheduled but the arguments he seemed to use were the very arguments that were rejected by the High Court majority judges in the Wik decision. To some extent, that is also valid for Sek Hume's opinion, who was the fourth QC that the New South Wales Farmers Association put before us. On balance, with all this conflicting legal advice, it would have been quite silly for us to schedule those leases, as the New South Wales Farmers Association wanted. I can understand and appreciate why they would want them scheduled. However, to do so would have destroyed the credibility of the schedule. It would have invited the other states who did not try this on to also have their leases which were excluded from the schedule included, and that would have collapsed the schedule. You may as well have taken out your Tippex, whited out whatever it was that was listed there and written in 'Australia', if that was the attitude. Also, it would have given the Labor Party a classic case to vote against everything in the Senate. Even if it had passed the Senatewhich it would not have-you would have immediately had a High Court challenge on the validity of the schedule. That would have delayed getting certainty into Western Division pastoral leases for many months, which is against the good interests of the people who occupy grazing leases in the Western Division who have been subject, in many cases, to a great degree of anguish and uncertainty. The New South Wales Farmers Association have said that we are going to need 5,000 test cases in the Western Division to resolve this. I believe that that is a gross exaggeration and not true. They have also said that we will see paralysis of agricultural production. Again, I do not believe that is true at all. They have said that, if it can be shown that the grazing the leases should be added to the schedule later on, it cannot be done. Again, I believe that is not true. If it is shown that grazing leases do extinguish native title, as I believe many of them would, then they can be added to the schedule later on. They have also used a Queensland comparison, saying that Queensland leases were included on the schedule where New South Wales comparable leases were not. Again, that is not quite correct. The small number of grazing homestead perpetual leases-small in area; I think it amounts to about 12.7 per cent of the state-are quite different from Western Division grazing leases. They have the right to apply to freehold the leases. They have the right to turn them into cultivation leases without permission. Their rents are calculated on the unimproved capital value instead of the livestock carrying capacity and so on. They are quite different leases from New South Wales grazing leases. Having said all that about the schedulebecause it has been such a contentious area-I do say that the bill, which is based on the 10point plan that we present to the parliament today, will fix everything that the New South Wales farmers want. There will be certainty returned to grazing because the primary production rights of the leaseholder predominate 100 per cent over the native title rights, even if they are shown to exist on some New South Wales grazing leases. No-one can come on to your property and interfere in any way whatsoever with your legitimate activities. Even if you want to do other things in the future-if you can get permission, as you have to do now, to carry on cultivation activity, agricultural activity, tourist activity, or even running a helicopter flying school base if you wish-if that conflicts with the native title right, then we have made provision in this bill that the native title right can be bought out and compensation paid to the native title holders. The cost of the compensation will be picked up 75 per cent by the Commonwealth government and 25 per cent by the state government. So the farmer, the pastoralist, the grazier will have no expense whatsoever. In fact, we will pick up 100 per cent of the cost of legal aid, if it is needed at any stage, for test cases to be run. I believe you would probably want only one or two and you could just about solve the problem in the Western Division in the future. I do believe that if we can get this bill through virtually .unamended and have it all finished by Christmas then this time next year all the difficulty and sorrow and everything else that has been associated with the present native title bill will have evaporated, because most of the claims in the Western Division, if not all of them as I have seen them, just cannot stand up. They will fail the registration test. Under our registration test you have got to have a proper identification of the area and proper maps. You have got to have a proper identification of the native title claim group under section 190 and you have got to have a proper description of the native title you are claiming for. It must be presented on a fc;tctual basis and you must have a prima facie case. Mineral rights are not included. Also, the physical connection with the land must be established. I will just read this: The Registrar must be satisfied that at least one member of the native title claim group currently has or previously had a traditional physical connection with the area covered by the application. This connection must amount to more than a transitory access or intermittent non-native title access. In other words, your grandfather cannot just have held a picnic there in 1920, or your relatives cannot have come in on a motorbike from South Australia, or you cannot just claim you have had a spiritual connection with the land. You must be able to establish a physical connection. I would have liked to have seen that a bit tighter, but I believe it is far superior to what exists in the present act and it will largely solve the problem. Overall, I do believe this legislation reflects accurately what the High Court wanted and it respects both sides of the debate. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Title: NATIVE TITLE AMENDMENT BILL
text: It is with some sorrow that I rise to speak in this debate. I say that because I believe that the thrust of this bill is an endeavour to tum the clock back. I think it was with some pride that, in the last couple of years, Australia as a nation has sought to make a statement that it really wanted to deliver and develop the concept of one nation-a nation committed to doing something for the betterment of all Australians irrespective of their background. In that context, I say that I very much support the thrust of the second reading amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Evans. The problem for the House today is that the thrust of this bill is really an endeavour by the Howard government to force a debate about Wik and native title, and it is a guise to launch a major attack on some of the most needy and disadvantaged people in our nation. That really is what the thrust of the bill is about-turning the clock back and walking away from the needs of the most'disadvantaged of this nation. Fdr . . many years Aboriginals and Torres Strait Iilanders were the people who were out of sight and out of mind. They very much sought the help of many members of the Howard government. But the Howard government considered them out of sight and out of mind, and had the capacity to tum their backs on the needs of the most disadvantaged people in the nation while they feathered their own nests in government. My position is that I think the Australian community at large is of the view that it is no longer possible to argue that they are the forgotten Australians. The tide has turned. It is not just the alarming issues of poor health, appalling living standards, shocking education levels and the lack of employment that have kept indigenous Australians in the public consciousness. The broader Australian community has come to look with pride on the expressions of a unique and vibrant culture which has correctly attracted international attention through artists and musicians and people such as Yothu Yindi and Christine Anu. Wherever we go as a nation now we stand with some pride when we· consider the achievements of our indigenous people. But the problem with this government is that it likes to embrace the Olympic champions, the international artists and the international musicians, but when it comes to the nitty gritty of really trying to do something about the most disadvantaged in the community, it wants to drive a wedge between mainstream Australia and those in the most disadvantaged places in Australia.
