I take, for example, Yothu Yindi in particular. Through their songs they have popularised the ambitions and struggles of indigenous Australians for land rights as an expression of their culture. Long years of deprivation, dispossession, abuse and neglect have left enduring scars, and so they ought to. None of us can be proud of those scars, but it comes back to an endeavour and a commitment to actually do something to ensure that we overcome those scars in the future. But, despite those scars, a vibrant culture is attracting the attention and support of the wider Australian community and the world. The Howard government has got to understand that, with respect to this debate, not only are Australian eyes on the HQuse of Representatives today but also, more importantly, the international community is monitoring what happens with respect to this bill. I suggest that the government's mishandling of the debate over Wik will reverberate around the world. No longer does Australia walk tall internationally. We have a Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) who has no international standing at all. The debate about Wik will further diminish Australia's standing internationally. I refer, for example, to the action in part of the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) which I suggest is part of a pattern of activity which reveals that this government see native title as an intrusion-an encumbrance-which they want to get rid of any way they can if at all possible. It is a problem that they want to sweep under the carpet because they are not committed to doing something to assist the indigenous people-some of the most disadvantaged people in this nation. It really is a massive irony that this government is acting firmly and resolutely against property rights just because the property holders, on this occasion, are not white. That is what it is all about-property rights for the white community but not for those with black faces. The Liberal and National parties, after all, . are the parties that trumpet their core ideological belief in property rights-yes, property rights for the whites but not the blacks. The Liberal and National parties, after all, are the parties which strut the Australian political stage declaiming their belief in law and order. In the Wik decision, the High Court, I would suggest, has decisively ruled that, yes, all Australians are entitled to property rights whether they have a black face or a white face. The High Court decision recognises the property rights-and correctly so-of indigenous Australians. The government might not like it, some pastoralists might not like it, some miners might not like it, but it is the law of the land and so it ought to be. It is the only way forward for Australia-a sense of security, a sense of opportunity for all Australians. Yes, the ruling might be inconvenient to the coalition government. That is why they are prepared to ignore the High Court decision as they run off to church and profess that they want to do something about the disadvantaged in this country. But, when it comes to making hard decisions and taking decisive actions, real problem is that they will go missing in action in the same way that they have historically gone missing in action when it comes to leadership, commitment and a willingness to do something. I suggest that the government's pig-headed attitude to Wik may actually become a very costly enterprise to Australia at a time when we need stability and security so as investment and create jobs. I refer to the Australian Law Reform Commission and the fact that it has pointed out and warned that the government's plans for native title will not deliver legal certainty but only deliver very costly litigation-all the way back to the High Court. My colleague the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, Mr Melham, has correctly tried to constructively argue this same case through the long months of public debate about these amendments, but the government, for some strange reason, has turned a deaf ear to these warnings. I might also say that the government has become very sensitive when it comes to the Wik bill because there is not a favourable legal opinion lodged with the joint committee on native title except-and we are not surprised-for the legal opinion from the Attorney-General's Department, from an Attorney-General who has a huge question mark over his head today not only with respect to. his future capacity to serve in Howard government but also, more importantly, with respect to his standing in the legal community. And that is not to be dismissed. It is a major problem for the government and it is a major problem for law and order in Australia. One of the greatest strengths of the Native Title Act as it now stands is that, wherever possible, it minimises the role of lawyers and it minimises the adversarial system of the courts. The Native Title Act, as it now stands, allows for a resolution of differences in a non-adversarial, informal setting with emphasis on mediation. The coalition now wishes to undermine this important process and introduce a costly legal process. Litigation will not only hurt indigenous Australia but hurt the mining and farming the communities and the wider economic interests of this nation. This is what this is all about: not just the needs, aspirations and rights of the Australian indigenous community but also the economic needs of a great nation-the Australian nation-a nation that ought to be committed to ensuring that we all have the same rights, irrespective of whether they are property rights or opportunities for decent to attract health, education and training. The right to negotiate, I suggest, has been a key part of the Native Title Act and it has been the opposition's contention all along that the decision to extinguish this right will be constitutionally invalid. I believe that this right to negotiate is a crucial element in allowing meaningful input by indigenous people into real decision making-a sense of emancipation and encouragement to participate-about the development of their communities, their lands and their futures. Since the right to negotiate was established, we have seen the indigenous community come up with some creative uses of this newfound right. Win-win solutions for all Australians have been the end result of that right to negotiate, especially, for example, the negotiated regional agreements which have put a heavy emphasis on a range of core needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. My commitment to native title is based on the a strong belief that we can only expect to achieve this important goal of reconciliation if we see native title as being part of a wider package which fronts up to the other stark problems that the indigenous community faces in Australia as we approach the 21st century. Regional agreements front up to exactly that issue. People negotiate, through regional agreements, ways to resolve crucial health, education, housing and job issues for indigenous Australians. The ability to come up with regional agreements, based on the right to negotiate, has empowered many indigenous communities with the right to determine, often for the first time, their own priorities. A to have some control of the future will, in time, impact on the stark statistics which confront us when we look at the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander population. I refer to these statistics today because, as far as I am concerned, you cannot separate the Wik debate and the issue of native title from your commitment to do something about the basic issues of health, education and jobs. Reconciliation and an effective Native Title Act should be used by all sides-yes, all sides-to ensure that, as we go into the 21st century, we develop acceptable and effective plans to resolve the stark statistics of Aborigibeing nallife. The release of the findings of the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander survey in 1995 has widened our knowledge of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander population. The survey shows that, while a high incidence of health problems such as asthma, hearing problems, heart problems and diabetes were widely reported, access to health care, especially in rural areas, was severely limited. Aboriginal people start life smaller and finish it earlier, with the life expectancy for indigenous females at about 62 years compared to an Australian average of 81 and the life expectancy for indigenous males at 57 compared to an Australian average of 75. At any age, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples are more than twice as likely to die as non-Aboriginal people. At the most crucial age of 25 to 44, the risk is five times greater. But not all the Aboriginal health statistics are gloomy. The death rate from cardiovascular disease has declined among Aboriginal males. Death from lung cancer is declining among Aboriginal men, although not among women. Alcohol related deaths are declining sharply as are male deaths from car accidents and homicide. The infant mortality rate continues to decline, but its rate of decline appears to have slowed. Many of the health problems I have talked about can be tackled if we work with local communities to improve the standard of Aboriginal housing, which is an acute problem. An indigenous family is 20 times more likely to be homeless than a non-indigenous right family and four times more likely to be in overcrowded accommodation. At least a quarter of the community lives in unsatisfactory housing. In rural areas, this proportion is roughly one in three. Overcrowding is particularly acute in rural areas where one household in three comprises six or more people, and three-quarters of these households had three bedrooms or fewer. In rural areas, about 40 per cent of these houses require major repair or replacement. I am pleased to say that I have witnessed a number of places in Queensland, confronted with those difficulties, where this issue is now effectively tackled by local Aboriginal communities. The communities are using the local housing crisis to provide new skills and to create job and training opportunities for their people and, in doing so, are resolving health problems for their old and young people. Just outside of Townsville is the Shalom College which is run by the remarkable Uniting Church minister, Shayne Blackman, who has trained young Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the skills to build appropriate housing in rural areas. As part of the hands-on training at Shalom College, the teenagers and young adults have built nursing homes for their elders and classroom facilities for the younger people attending Shalom College's primary and secondary school. It is about practical outcomes because they have a sense of capacity and opportunity. There are a number of other examples that I could refer to today, but time does not permit. Mr Deputy Speaker, I suggest to you that there are solutions. But the biggest problem confronting indigenous Australia is employment. In some localities, the unemployment rate exceeds 50 per cent but, in the early 1990s, employment opportunities for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people grew more rapidly than non-indigenous employment. This was largely due to the major expansion by the Labor Party of the community development employment projects scheme, under which participants have the opportunity to work on community projects funded by forgone unemployment benefits. Most of the CDEP work was low skill and part time and, overwhelmingly, it was rural and remote based. Because of the lack of jobs, the lack of education and the lack of skills, the annual income that indigenous Australians earn is very low. Three-fifths of people aged 15 or over receive $12,000 or less, while one in nine receive more than $25,000 per annum. Government payments are clearly the main source of income. In conclusion, I suggest that the Wik ruling provided new and vital opportunities for indigenous Australians to confront their major social problems, their unemploym-nt problems and the need to skill and train their people for new jobs that could be created by the rights invested in indigenous Australians by the Wik decision. If we are to allow Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to create new opportunities for themselves, the Howard government should not be actively campaigning to undermine the High Court's Wik decision. The government should act with respect for both the High Court rulings and the newly revived property rights of the first Australians. Some people on the other side might not like it, but the indigenous Australians are the first Australians and they have some rights and entitlements. The High Court has recognised them. It is about time the other side of the House recognised and respected the right of the High Court to make such decisions. The Wik ruling can bea godsend for all. I know the 'God squad' on the other side of the House do not have a lot of respect for the High Court when it comes to hard decisions. The Wik decision provides a path to help the reconciliation process, a path to help to resolve two centuries of dis empowerment which has created the awful statistics which are all too often repeated in discussions about Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. The time has come to take the hand off the prayer book, the hand off the heart; and to actually do something. Get your hands dirty. Respect the High Court decision, empower the indigenous people, respect the fact that in Australia black people as well as white people are entitled to property rights. Give them the capacity to further develop themselves-Give them the capacity to negotiate local arrangements and to do something in a practical way about health, education and the all important employment issues of jobs and training. Take your head out of the sand, stand on your high heels and actually do something rather than just talk about it.

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: NATIVE TITLE AMENDMENT BILL
text: The speech just delivered by the shadow minister, the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson), who is at the table, is undoubtedly one of the most offensive, odious and outrageous speeches ever to be uttered in this place. There is no doubt whatsoever that Aboriginal people are disadvantaged. There is no doubt that much needs to be done to bring their state of health up to the standard of those in the general community. We were treated by the shadow minister to a range of Aboriginal health statistics. They were sad statistics. Quite often those statistics were correct. The shadow minister has the hide, the audacity, to come in here in relation to the Native Title Amendment Bill and refer to those matters. The shadow minister is a member of a party which, for 13 years, controlled the treasury benches in Australia. For 13 years, that government did absolutely nothing. The Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) has referred the current reference into Aboriginal health to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs, which I chaired before my appointment as Government Whip by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). The government is absolutely determined to make sure that Aboriginal health and other disadvantage are redressed. The former government spent taxpayers' dollars and loads of this parliament's time talking about the problems of Aborigines and talking about native title but, at the end of the day, Aboriginal health, housing, infant mortality and educational standards remained as they always have been, and that situation is totally unacceptable. I think the Australian people will reject the hypocrisy of the now opposition. They had the hide to criticise this government when this is the first government to do anything. The shadow minister also suggested that we are trying to destroy the High Court decisions in Mabo and Wik. There is no doubt that, prior to the Mabo No.2 decision in 1992, nobody thought that native title survived. We all believed that the concept of terra nullius was in fact the law. When the High Court brought down the Mabo decision, it obviously exploded the certainty in land law that was previously there, and the former government brought in the Native Title Act. We then pointed out that that Native Title Act was an unworkable response to the High Court decision. When one listens to speakers from the Labor Party, one would think that that particular piece of legislation is a paragon of virtue. We, in opposition, pointed out that the Native Title Act 1993 was not going to work. Up until the present time, some 612 applications have been lodged before the National Native Tribunal and only one mainland determination has been made. We have listened to opposition speakers saying how the legislation before the House will destroy the workability of the Native Title Act. What an absolutely sick joke! The Native Title Act has no workability whatsoever. What is more, one of the basic fundamentals on which the act was predicated was exploded when the High Court brought down its deci$ion in the Wik case. It is interesting to look at what the then Prime Minister Keating had to say in the parliament on 16 November 1993 in his second reading speech on the then Native Title Bill: I draw attention also to the recording in the preamble of the bill of the government's view' that under the common law past valid freehold and leasehold grants extinguish native title. There is therefore no obstacle or hindrance to renewal of pastoral leases in the future, whether validated already valid. . There it is was in black and white in the preamble to the legislation. The then Senator Gareth Evans, when talking about preambles said: We all understand these days the role that preambles have in legislation as an interpretive tool for the courts and as a useful way of expressing the intended scope of legislation. The parliament, in the preamble to the Native Title Act, expressed the view that native title was extinguished by leasehold and freehold grants but, obviously, the court decided otherwise. This government accepts the decision in the Mabo case. We also accept the decision in the Wik case, but this legislation seeks to make the Wik decision more workable. Justice Michael Kirby, one of the judges in that case, pointed out that the decision in Wik could well bring about uncertainty. This government has had to redress the uncertainty delivered by the High Court. It is quite wrong for the honourable member for Batman to suggest that this government has had a pig-headed attitude to Wik. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Senator Minchin) ought to be congratulated for the exemplary way in which he has consulted with all stakeholders in Australia on achieving a situation which means that we are able to bring this bill before the parliament. He has consulted with pastoralists, miners, the indigenous community and with the general community. He ought to be praised for bringing forward this measured response which will seek to reduce uncertainty. It will improve the workability of native title processes and find a balance among the interests of all parties and it will, most importantly, maintain respect for native title. The government said in its election policy that it would amend the Native Title Act to improve its workability, and this legislation before the chamber is the delivery of yet another election promise. Far from those people opposite coming in here and seeking to condemn and criticise this government for this bill, they ought to sit back and say that this is another occasion or when we did not create the problem but we accept the responsibility to fix it up. This legislation is balanced, reasonable and takes into account the needs of pastoralists, miners and the general community, as well as the Aboriginal community. I want at this stage to refer briefly to the allegations made by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) against the Attorney General (Mr Williams) in relation to the Australian Law Reform Commission. lt ought to be recognised that the Australian Law Reform Commission operates on references given to it by the Attorney-General. The shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham), was Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in the last parliament. I have to concede that he was a pretty good chairman. Mr Tanner-Hear, hear!

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: NATIVE TITLE AMENDMENT BILL
text: The member for Melbourne interjects. He was a much better chairman of that committee than he is shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs. Both the Attorney-General and I were members of that committee. There was a report brought down in relation to the Australian Law Reform Commission and the chairman, the honourable member for Banks, signed off on that report which indicated that the commission ought only be able to operate in accordance with references given to it by the Attorney-General. With respect to the Australian Law Reform Commission, we have a gratuitous act by the commission in seeking to buy into the Wik issue and native title. There was no reference given by the minister. The Australian Law Reform Commission takes an extraordinary amount of time in many cases to report on references given to it by the Attorney-General of the day. Yet, despite that, it was able to find within its resources the time to put together a submission on Wik. The Attorney-General has pointed out that the Australian Law Reform Commission is supposed to act on references given to it by the Attorney-General. That is the position which was confirmed by a committee chaired by the Labor shadow minister in the last parliament. lt has always been the position. Simply put, what has been said is that the Australian Law Reform Commission, in this instance, have overstepped the mark. They have forgotten what their legislation says. They have bought into something where they do not belong. They do not currently have any reference in relation to native title, yet they have decided to put aside the references given by successive Attorneys-General and intrude into something which is not currently their responsibility. I think that is very unacceptable and most regrettable. The honourable member for Banks uttered a few things in his speech that indicated what was wrong with the former government. He showed how out of touch the former government was and the opposition now is with the community. He was divisive. It is very clear that the honourable member for Banks listens only to certain interest groups and does not consider the interests of mainstream Australia. The honourable member for Banks even managed to suggest somehow that the Native Title Act is workable. How on earth could anyone suggest that the Native Title Act is workable when there have been 612 applications lodged, yet only one determination by the National Native Title Tribunal with respect to mainland Australia? We all know about the paralysis that has hit economic development as a result of the Native Title Act and because of spurious and multiple claims over the same piece of property. What this government has done is bring down a situation which will reduce uncertainty. We want to improve the workability of native title processes. We seek to find an appropriate balance among the interests of all parties and we aim to maintain respect for native title. One would have thought that the opposition would have said to the government, 'Thank you very much for fixing up the mess that we created in 1993.' But, regrettably, we find that once again the opposition are playing politics. They are showing simply how irrelevant they are. lt is curious to look at the comments made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans) in the second reading debate on the bill. This really is the understatement of the year. He said: There are some problems that were created in the aftermath of the Wik decision. We, on the opposition side, are fully prepared to cooperate in their redress ... I call< upon the shadow minister to put up or shut up. Is he going to cooperate? Is the Labor Party going to cooperate? .Are they going to urge their senators to collaborate in making sure that we are able to fix up the appalling situation. in relation to native title that we inherited upon attaining government in March 1993? Are they going to do that, or are they going to do what speaker after speaker has said in this particular place? They are seeking to frustrate this attempt by this government to bring our 10-point plan to fruition, a 10-point plan that is fair not only to Aborigines but also to other sections of the community. Mr Tanner interjecting

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: NATIVE TITLE AMENDMENT BILL
text: The honourable member for Melbourne ought to be ashamed of himself. Once I used to think that he was a person who had some ability. Clearly, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) is still concerned about the member for Melbourne. On this issue the member for Melbourne is totally wrong. He ought to support the position enunciated by the government. As I said, we had the Mabo decision in 1992, we had the Native Title Act in 1993 which, I might add, was opposed by the then opposition at the time, and then we had the Wik decision brought down this year. This government has not rushed into a quick fix solution with respect to Wik. As I said, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister has consulted widely right across the Australian community with a view to obtaining a balance. I pointed out that he has spoken to pastoralists, indigenous interests, states and territories and also to industry. These proposals currently before the parliament seek to achieve a number of outcomes. Those outcomes include legal validity for acts done between the commencement of the Native Title Act in January 1994 and the Wik decision on the assumption that pastoral leases and other tenures extinguished native title. The proposals also seek to· restore certainty to pastoralists so that they can carry on primary production activities. We seek to have respect for native title, preserving the principle of native title as established in the Mabo case in allowing claims to proceed. Of course, that explodes the suggestions made by the honourable member for Batman who tries to point out that we are seeking to destroy the Mabo and Wik decisions. The proposals also will confirm the common law relating to native title and, in particular, that it is extinguished by current and historical freehold, residential leases, commercial leases, and those agricultural and pastoral leases providing exclusive possession. We also aim to improve workability through removing impediments to developing and building on the government's proposed amendments to improve the processes of the Native Title Act 1993. The proposals also include devolution to the states and territories and, in particular, allowing for alternative state and territory processes for granting mining leases on pastoral lease land. We also aim for a speedy and sustainable resolution of concerns and uncertainty. Some people were not happy with what the Prime Minister included in the to-point plan. It is interesting that some people said that the government did not go far enough and others said that the government went too far. That probably indicates that the government has it exactly right. The Prime Minister has shown exemplary leadership in relation to Wik. It would be very easy for us to rush off and urge wholesale extinguishment of native title by pastoral leases. It would have been easy for us to be populists and to go out there and say what many people wanted to hear. But the Prime Minister on this issue, as on the guns issue, and as on so many other issues, has shown himself to be a statesman. He has been prepared to spend an inordinate amount of time working out a position which is fair and equitable to all sides. That is why I am particularly proud to support this legislation which is currently before the House. Some people have said that there ought to be wholesale extinguishment. I can understand the superficial attractiveness of that approach. However, to have blanket extinguishment would undermine the very certainty and security sought to be brought about by this legislation. Our pastoralists, in particular, would be affected in a number of ways. Were we to go down the extinguishment road there would be legal problems, and it would considerably increase the likelihood. of a successful constitutional challenge to the validity .of the legislation. Claims, of course, would not disappear, they would simply manifest themselves as claims for compensation. There would be more time lost and there would be more paralysis. There would be substantial compensation paid for extinguishing native title. The courts, on a case by case basis, would have to decide what compensation would be paid in individual circumstances and there could be millions if not billions of dollars paid out. Also, one really has to be practical in politics. Life is not the art of the possible, is the art of the attainable. While we achieved a massive majority in the last election-the people of Australia resoundingly voted for the Howard coalition government-regrettably, owing to vagaries in the Senate voting system, we did not obtain a similar majority in the upper house. As a government we had to be aware that we must bring in reforms to the Native Title Act but it was important that, if they were going to be workable, if they were going to come into effect, we get them through the upper house. It was made very clear by the. Labor Party and by the minor parties in the Senate that, were we to go down the wholesale extinguishment road, our legislation would be unlikely to be passed by the Senate and there would be an indefinite continuity of uncertainty. There are very many proposals in this legislation of a technical nature which substantially improve the workability of the Native Title Act, and there was no point in our making a great big noise and bringing forward proposals for wholesale extinguishment which would have resulted in increased legal cases. It would have resulted in an enormous amount of financial outlay, even if we could have got the proposals through the parliament. But it is obvious we would not have got them through the parliament and so there really is a very practical as well as a moral reason for not proceeding down the road of wholesale extinguishment. Also, there were downsides for the Australian community generally if we were to go down the road of wholesale extinguishment. It would risk the reconciliation process. The honourable member for Batman said that we were not committed to reconciliation. That is absolutely untrue. This government and ministers have pointed out that we are committed to the reconciliation of Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians, and I think the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) would agree that this is a bipartisan approach. . The honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) actually sits on the national council with respect to reconciliation. So it is quite wrong, it is very dishonest-and I am pleased it to see that the member for Melbourne is nodding-to suggest that this government does not support the principle of reconciliation. As far as our international reputation is concerned, it would also have been damaged were we to go down the road of wholesale extinguishment. To sum up, as time is short, this is a very important piece of legislation. We are seeking through this legislation to fix up a problem which was left to us by our predecessors. This bill is balanced, it is fair, it is workable, it is equitable and it will be to the benefit of the indigenous people of Australia. It will also be to the benefit of miners; it will be to the benefit of the tourist industry and also of pastoralists. So this bill is a win/win/win/win situation. Those opposite stand condemned for their negativity, for their failure in government to do anything about Aboriginal people and for their bringing to Australia the Native Title Act, which has proven so far to be absolutely and completely unworkable. (Time expired)

Speaker: Ms HANSON
Title: NATIVE TITLE AMENDMENT BILL
text: Today this House will debate whether we are to be one people belonging to one nation or many peoples belonging to many nations. For many years Australia has been divided through policies of multiculturalism and an unfair view of history that have led to the impractical, discriminatory and stupid notion of land rights, and special treatment for so-called minorities at the .expense of everyone else. Today you may very well collude to enshrine that division despite even the previous Prime Minister's view of past validated freehold grants, residential, commercial, pastoral, agricultural and validated crown actions extinguishing native title. This extinguishment should be extended to cover vacant crown land as well. There is a need to put the High Court back into its rightful place. of interpreting the law, not creatirig the law. We must question who is running the country when seven judges, not elected by the people, presume to make such monumental decisions. It is imperative that the people of Australia understand that native title is, as is said, the 'thin edge of the wedge'. In conjunction with the Canadian government, the indigenous people of Canada have recently created Nunavut, a separate indigenous state within the nation of Canada. Originally, Nunavut was to be a tract of semiautonomous land of some two million square kilometres. However, a further deal was done and the two million square kilometres of semi-autonomous land of this state within a state became 350,000 square. kilometres of freehold land. This will be formalised in 1999, and will in effect leave Canada with another country bigger than the state of Victoria within its borders. It is imperative that the Australian people know and understand the international forces driving the Aboriginal industry and the flawed and divisive concept of native title. It is crucial to realise that the underlying blueprint and inspiration behind the creation of a separate indigenous nation within Canada and the impending creation of an Aboriginal nation within our own country is the United Nations Draft Declaration of the Rights of Indigenous Peoples. The Australian people, and through them the parliament, must be given the widest possible opportunity to understand the massive and irrevocable changes to Australia that will occur when this United Nations treaty, like so many before it, is ratified and implemented-as always, to the detriment of ordinary Australians. The report Indigenous peoples and environmental management: a review of Canadian regional agreements and their potential application to Australia, part 1, by Richardson and others, states: The Canadian experience is one strategy that Aboriginals might use to resolve the issues raised by the creation of native title in Australia. In the words of Mick Dodson, ATSIC Social Justice Commissioner, on 25 October 1996: We believe that in the process of adopting the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples, time is on the side of Indigenous peoples. We continue to believe that through perseverance with this process, it will be possible to achieve consensus on the provisions of the declaration, as it presently stands. Or let me quote Peter Jull, a former adviser to the Canadian Prime Minister and now a research fellow of the Northern Australian Research Unit and consultant to the Central Land Council, who said: Nunavut has prophetic meaning when viewed in an international context. It heralds a new world order. A hunter-gatherer people, with a stubborn sustainable development philosophy and no visible modem industrial economy, are taking over one-fifth of the world's second largest nation state. Such a breakthrough provides practical inspiration for other indigenous peoples. This does not mean it should be copied precisely elsewhere, but it can be usefully studied as a precedent. There is an undeniable link between the events in Australia and Canada. The man who was the architect of Nunavut in Canada is now living in Brisbane, and planning a Nunavut for Australia. There is no doubt the long-term goal of the Aboriginal industry is to create a separate indigenous nation within Australia: a separate country that the allegedly gUilty non-Aboriginal Australians will pay for. This is a clear and indisputable fact that will disturb all Australians who believe we are working for the future as one people. The concept and general understanding of 'indigenous' has been created with dubious purpose and dangerous intent. The tr.ue and much broader meaning of 'indigenous' is not generally understood, and as it stands it is meant to confuse and deceive. It is most important for us all to be Austral9 ians. How long you or your ancestors may have been here is irrelevant. It is a flawed argument to essentially suggest that some people are more Australian than others when some of us were born here and others have chosen to become Australians--either we are equal in all things or equal in none. When what is indigenous, what is Australian and levels of Aboriginality are mixed with the fact that the greater majority of so-called indigenous people are of mixed ancestry, often with only small percentages of Aboriginal blood, confusion of identity and entitlement reigns supreme. What is certain however is that, to progress together as one people, we must all be treated equally and not separated for special treatment. In Australia, Aborigines comprise less than two per cent of our population yet, under native title, they will claim perhaps as much as 75 per cent of land that is supposed to belong to us all. It is beyond belief to even consider giving less than two per cent of the population of Australia a stranglehold over 75 per cent of Australia, yet that is the issue before us. It is true that many Aboriginal people are not working and that they are living in appalling conditions. The current situation, with the corrupt and inefficient activities of ATSIC, does not allow much opportunity for improving their lifestyle. However, they do not have a monopoly on being disadvantaged, as it is also true that a million other Australians are not working and, although they feel little hope for the future, no-one is giving them land. Rather, you are taking the land that belongs to us all and making it the sole property of the few. I am accused of trying to tum back the clock to the 1950s but the government, by refusing to extinguish so-called native title, turning the clock back to the 1780s. Those who fear fairness and decency applying for everyone call me a racist, but by embracing so-called native title this government and its predecessors are advocating the ownership of land purely based on race. Let me remind members of this House of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975. Section of that act makes it unlawful for a person to do any act involving a distinction, exclusion, restriction or preference based on race which has the purpose or effect of nullifying or impairing the recognition, enjoyment or exercise on an equal footing of any human right or fundamental freedom. Section 10 of the act provides that if, by reason of a law of the Commonwealth, state or territory, persons of a particular race, the first group, do not enjoy a. right that is enjoyed by persons of another race, the second group, or enjoy a right to a more limited extent then, notwithstanding that law, the first group are to enjoy the right to the same extent as the second group. The noble intent of the act has however been nobbled by section 8 which allows special measures for ethnic and racial groups and hence discrimination against white Australians. We must be one nation. We must not have an Aboriginal or any other nation within our nation. The path of native title will eventually divide Australia into many nations of varying ethnicities: an Aboriginal nation will be just the beginning. We must extinguish native title, without penalty to the Australian taxpayer, through an amendment to the Australian constitution. This should be put to the Australian people in the form of a referendum to be held concurrently with the next federal election. If I had the opportunity to move an amendment to the Native Title Bill, I would move that consideration of the bill be deferred until the electors of Australia are given the opportunity to express their opinion by way of referendum. If our country must face division, let the people have their rightful chance to stop it.

Speaker: Mr WAKELIN
Title: NATIVE TITLE AMENDMENT BILL
text: On the evening of Thursday, 25 November 1993 I is rose in this House to oppose the Native Title Bill, as it then was. I asked the assembled members of this house a question: could it be that once again regional Australia had been asked to carry the heaviest load? Over those intervening years the answer has reverberated a very clear yes. That evening in Canberra in 1993, I pleaded with the parliament to understand that the ideas and the concepts they were playing around with were highly dangerous. The legislation that the government was supporting would divide this nation and the Aboriginal people of Australia would not gain one iota from the passage of that bill. Unfortunately, and I say this with no sense of pleasure, I believe that I was right. That evening my arguments were intended for the ears of Labor's then regional members. One characteristic shared by those honourable members at that time is that at the subsequent election they were unceremoniously thrown from office partly because of, I believe, the betrayal in that summer of 1993. The disastrous effects of the astonishing judgment of the High Court of Australia in the 1996 Wik decision and the deceit of the Keating-Beazley government in passing the Native Title Act have engulfed all quarters of our nation, not simply the entire regional section of the parliamentary Labor Party. Let us look at the native title impact on Australia today. The facts are obvious. Seventy-eight per cent of Australia is potentially subject to native title claim. That is undisputed. There has been only one negotiated successful claim in five years despite $88.8 million worth of funding through the representative bodies. I understand that is something like 600 claims and that everyone is aware of the overlapping claims issue. For instance, in my own electorate of Grey there is more native title claimed than actually exists. The most obvious effect has been the shutdown of minerals and resource development in this country. Already, in the three years from the Mabo judgment, offshore mining increased as a percentage of mining activity by Australian companies from 27 per cent to 41 per cent as Australia's miners were forced to halt activity in their own country. This is equivalent to around $486 million flying out of Australia in a single year. Yet Labor's Special Minister for State, the then member for Robertson, Frank Walker, now replaced by my colleague Jim Lloyd, told the House, 'I think that those who are suggesting that there will be some loss of investment are simply wrong.' Were that were so. Our farmers have been devastated by the High Court's decision and the subsequent acts of the Commonwealth. Even advocates such as Rick Farley, who many believe sold out his fellow farmers in 1993, have been forced to admit that farmers have been stymied by the Native Title Act. The Wik decision of last year has exacerbated such concerns. I come to the impact on my own electorate of Grey. By its very nature, my electorate has borne the brunt of much of the uncertainty of native title, remembering that it is 92 per cent of the land mass of South Australia. To be truthful, I wonder if my very presence in this parliament did not prejudice the efforts of my electorate to get a decent hearing from the previous government. Would they have had such disregard for the people of the north of South Australia if there had been a Labor member for Grey at the time? Regrettably the answer is yes for even the protestations of the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) who was dumped by the ALP for his efforts was unable to shift the Keating-Beazley mind-set. The farmers of Grey have been frightened, intimidated and provoked by the legal advocates of native title-advocates who are usually not Aboriginal; they are usually from Adelaide or Sydney and have no interest in the productive use of pastoral land.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: NATIVE TITLE AMENDMENT BILL

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: MINISTERIAL ARRANGEMENTS
text: I inform the House that the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) will be a few minutes late for question time. He is currently addressing the National Press Club. The Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) will answer questions on his behalf until he arrives. Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Attorney-General. I refer the Attomey-General to his claims that the Australian Law Reform Commission has no power to comment on the Native Title Bill because it has no current terms of reference directly on that subject. Why then did the Prime Minister's parliamentary secretary, Senator Minchin, involve the commission in discussing native title amendments from early 1996-a period of over 12 months-including by writing to the commission on 3 July this year on the bill? Exactly when, and in what circumstances, did the Attorney-General first learn that Senator Minchin and the government have been using the commission as a source of advice on amendments to the Native Title Act? Mr Ross Cameron- Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. My point of order relates to standing order No. 142, which states that ministers are responsible to this House for matters over which they have public responsibility. Ministers explicitly are not responsible for statements made by senators in the other place on this or any other subject.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Order! There is no point of order.

Speaker: Mr WILLIAMS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The Leader of the Opposition refers to my claim that the Law Reform Commission has no power. The Law Reform Commission must itself think the same because, under the previous government, it sought a reference on native title, which was declined. Earlier this year, there was correspondence in relation to the subject of new references. The commission sought another reference on the subject of native title', and it was not given. I cannot answer for'the in:. volvement of Senator Minchin; I do not know. Mr Crean-When did you find out about it; that's all you were asked.

Speaker: Mr WILLIAMS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: What I can say is that the submission that went to the Wik task force was not, to my knowledge, sought by the Wik task force, except in so far as it was sending out copies of the bill for comment. This all goes to an allegation that we are seeking to suppress the opinion of the Law Reform Commission. Mr Rose, the President of the Australian Law Reform Commission, does not seem to think that that was what was occurring. There was no direction given. There was no suggestion that any direction would be given that their opinion not be provided to the Wik task force or to the parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title. In the discussions that the acting secretary of my department had with the president of the commission, it was left on the basis that it was ultimately the commission's decision whether or not to comment on the Native Title Bill. But, if they were to do so, they knew that it was my view that they would be doing so without statutory authority. I would have been remiss in my duties as Attorney General, responsible for the Law Reform Commission, if I had not drawn that to the commission's attention. Let me just say that it is not the content of the submission which is in issue. My position would be exactly the same whether the position was favourable or unfavourable. I expressed similar concerns in relation to a submission that the commission made to another committee of this House, in this case on copyright law. You have also raised the issue of why I only raised concerns about this submission, and some of the interjections seem to be directed at that. I was not, in fact, aware until earlier this week that the commission has been making submissions on a wide range of issues that are unrelated to any current reference. I was not aware of this practice when I initially wrote to the president to put my view that making submissions on matters not the subject of an existing reference required my authority.

Speaker: Mr KERR
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: And you would give a direction.

Speaker: Mr WILLIAMS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Why, I ask the opposition, did the Law Reform Commission not advise on the Native Title Bill 1993? Why did they not advise on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1995? Why did they not advise on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1996? Why did they not offer advice to the parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund inquiry into the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act? The opposition has rushed off to the Clerk of the Senate and sought advice on the conduct ofMr Martin Ferguson-He's a better lawyer than you.

Speaker: Mr WILLIAMS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Let me respond to the member for Batman by saying that my understanding is that the Clerk of the Senate has no legal qualifications. I question the judgment of the clerk in rushing out on Monday two opinions based on hypothetical facts. The second of the opinions actually refers to me. So the set of facts in the first letter was not hypothetical at all; he was intending to refer to the situation regarding me, the commission and the committee. What he advised on was not fact. What I have done is endeavour to ascertain the situation on the basis of a proper statement of the facts. I have sought advice. The Chief General Counsel has advised that I am perfectly correct in asserting that the commission has no power under its act to offer a submission on a matter on which it has no current reference, in particular on the Native Title Bill. I also sought advice on the true situation regarding the discussion between the acting secretary to my department and the president of the commission. The acting secretary has, as a result of that discussion, decided the commission would not offer a submission. Mr Gareth Evans-He didn't have much choice, did he?

Speaker: Mr WILLIAMS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: He did have a choice. Let me just tell you what the acting secretary has told me. He said: I told himthat is, the presidentthat he was "at a cross-roads"-the Commission could go forward with the submission to the PIC and he would receive an "unhappy letter" from the Attorney. Or they could not go forward, and he would not receive any letter-instead he and I could sit down and try to work out a set of ground rules relating to submissions which would satisfy all the parties. AR expressed concern that I might wish to suggest that the Commission should be limited to only making submissions on matters relating to current references. I told himthat is, the acting secretary told himthat it was not my wish to be so restrictive. I then suggested to AR that he think about what I had said to him and that I would call him later in the day. In fact, I was not able to speak to him until the following day, when he indicated to me that the Commission would not be going ahead with its submission. Conversation was generally quiet and friendly. You might say, 'Well, what would the Clerk of the Senate have said if he had known those facts?' Let me tell you that the Chief General Counsel says that there is no suggestion of a breach of the Parliamentary Privileges Act on those events. You have been running around for the last four days raising issues in the Senate. Yesterday you did not even ask me one question on the subject. You did not have one question. You allowed it to be asked in the Senate where they do not have the facts. I had the facts. You let them go on. This can now be seen for what it is: it is really just an exercise in attempting to smear and besmirch. I reject it.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Mr Speaker, I have a supplementary question. My supplementary question to the Attorney-General is: then in your view that conversation that you had with the assistant commissioner does not constitute an effort to influence him?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The question is out of order. Mr Leo MCLeay- Mr Speaker, I ask that the Attorney-General table the notes he was reading from.

Speaker: Mrs GALLUS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware of criticism of Australia's greenhouse position? Has the criticism led to a reconsideration of the government's position?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My attention has been drawn to a report in today's Australian of some criticism made of Australia's position by Denmark. I will take the opportunity in replying to the honourable member for Hindmarsh to mention to the House that Denmark's environment minister, Mr Sven Auken, has criticised Australia's claims for what he describes as 'special consideration'. Let me start by saying that Australia is not seeking special consideration; Australia is merely seeking fair consideration. I Labor Party is once again siding with foreign criticism, as they always do. They always side with foreign criticism. Whenever the Australian national interest is at stake they always agree with those who criticise Australia. But may I take the opportunity of saying that, of all those who might choose to criticise Australia's position, Denmark is in a particularly vulnerable position. The reason that Denmark is in a particularly vulnerable position is that Denmark herself is part of some special arrangements that exist. For example, Danish statistics relating to emissions claim that emissions of CO 2 fell by 0.5 per cent in 1996. However-and this is the interesting part, Mr SPEAKER - this was achieved by deducting 13 million tonnes of emissions from energy exports to Norway and Sweden. Denmark's electricity, therefore, went into a black hole. While they talk about Nordic power sharing, neither Norway nor Sweden counted the emissions either. So, somehow or other, some of the European countries who, with Labor Party support here, adopt this self-righteous position and point the finger at Australia and say that Australia is asking for special treatment, themselves have some extraordinary special arrangements. According to my advice, if we adopted the Danish method we could all get our figures down but the environment would be no better off. Mr Speaker, can I say to DenlIlark, can I say to the energy minister of Denmark, and can I say to all the supporters of the Danish position who sit opposite that we are sticking up for the Australian national interest. What is involved in this greenhouse gas debate is a threat to 90,000 Australian jobs. What is involved in this greenhouse debate is an attempt by the Australian government to stick up for the Australian interest. Those who criticise our stance and those opposite who support the critics of our stance are doing the Australian national interest in the eye. What I am arguing for, what I will continue to argue for and what. my government will continue to argue for is a fair deal for Australia: not a special deal for Australia, not a Labor deal for Australia but a fair deal for Australia; a deal that will protect Australian industry and, even more importantly, protect notice the and generate Australian jobs. text: My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer advise the House of initiatives by the government to provide rollover relief from capital gains tax for Australian small business? Who will be eligible for this· relief?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Before this government was elected, it said that it would introduce a family tax package. We did. Before this government was elected, we said we would reduce the provisional tax uplift factor. We did. We said that we would reduce the fringe benefits tax compliance burden. And we did. We said that we would give small business capital gains tax rollover relief. And we did. We delivered on all of those tax commitments that we had put to the Australian people before the last election. In relation to capital gains tax rollover relief, we said that where a small business sold an asset to buy another or sold a business to buy another. the capital gain should allow it to be rolled over capital gains tax free. The Labor Party had never thought about small business in this way before. Not only did we deliver-we delivered in full, on time. What is more, it is not just rollover relief for small business, it is not just allowing you to rollover in relation to an asset or a business while you are in the business of business; we also wanted to allow small business people to rollover into their retirement. For many small business people all of their savings go into their business. They ought to have the opportunity when they retire to come out and have that capital gains tax free - quite often We moved an amendment to allow a $500,000 waiver of capital gain in relation to small business rolling over in retirement. Who do you think tried to stop that coming into effect? The Australian Labor Party, led by it- Senator Nick Sherry in the Senate. Get a load of this: he thought it was too generous to allow small business people to rollover into retirement! He probably thinks, 'Why don't small business people go home and stay with If you mum and claim money to do so?' The Australian Labor Party tried to put a test in relation to that which would include personal assets over $5,000 to disqualify small business people from getting that relief. For 13 years the Australian Labor Party sat in office and what did they do for the small business community of Australia? Nothing! You get a government which is elected on a platform, which comes into introduce its tax plans on time and in full, and what does the Australian Labor Party do? It tries to stop it, led by Senator Sherry. You will - ecall also the Leader of the Opposition said in this place that the Labor Party would support the government in reducing concessionality for high income earners in relation to superannuation. Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Is the minister aware that many farm businesses, which at the best of times can support only one family, are having to support two because the current asset test arrangements applying to the age pension discourage older farmers from gifting ownership of the family farm to the younger generation? Would the minister please outline to the House the changes to the gifting provisions relating to the transfer of ownership of the family farm, as announced recently by the Prime Minister and the minister in the AgricultureAdvancing Australia package?

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for his question. I know it is of great importance to him and to many other members. The gifting arrangements are a new policy and they are part of AgricultureAdvancing Australia. It sees the government delivering on a long standing commitment to address a very real need: the welfare need of aged farmers and the very difficult circumstances which have confronted Australian farmers over the last decade or so. The fact is that there are thousands of older farmers living on farms with the next generation, and sometimes the generation after that-their sons and daughters, and sometimes their grandchildren-where that farm can no longer provide what ordinary Australians would regard as a decent standard of living for more than one family. And certainly not for two or three, as is sometimes the case. Many of those farms once would have been able to, but relentlessly declining terms of trade have overcome many farm families, despite the sector's legendary reputation for improving productivity and doing the job more effectively. Many of these people find that they are just unable to live decently, yet they cannot access the age pension because of the way in which the asset tests impacts on them. Our policy will enable farmers in this situation to transfer ownership of the family farm to a younger generation who are actively involved in running the business and then to receive the age pension immediately instead of, as currently applies, five years down the road. This will benefit not just those older farmers but also the younger generation taking over. They will be able to pick up the reins, relieved of a substantial financial pressure. They will be in a better position, so will those farms and so will the national economy. This is a carefully targeted package which is not available to wealthy farmers but which will be of real value to those many, many hard-pressed farmers out there in real need. I would be particularly interested to know just what conclusions about this gifting provision my opposite number, the shadow minister for primary industries, has now reached. His reaction to this package, which was so widely welcomed by the farm leaders in this country, was that it was a cruel hoax and constituted a few things which were a pale imitation of what they had in place. It would be interesting to know what his attitude is now. I think it is time we started to gain a bit an impression for the benefit of rural Australians as to where he is up to in his policy formation. It is 19 months since they lost their position. I think Australia's farmers would like to know a bit about it. We know a couple of things. He has been out there saying that the Leader of the Opposition has given them a blank page on which to start setting out a rural policy. In fact, he recently said, 'Kim Beazley has given me a total blank sheet.' It is probably very much like the one they took to the last election. It was a blank sheet. There was nothing on it. They did not have a primary industry policy. He quoted the Leader of the Opposition as having said, 'Rural and regional Australia is at the heart of Labor's comeback.' He said that he sees it as a 'huge charter and a challenge to rebuild credibility', whatever that means. We have a blank page here. This is their policy. I wonder, Mr Speaker, could we table the Labor Party's rural policy? Could I have your permission to table it? Filling in the gaps would be a very worthwhile exercise on the part of my opposite number over there because we need to know what it is about. All we know at the moment is that, from his reaction to this package, which has been so widely welcomed in rural Australia, the blank page will not have on it gifting, farm management deposits, farm family restart, Farmbis or anything else that is in the AAA package, the AgricultureAdvancing Australia package, because he says that it is just a cruel hoax. Speaker: Mrs MOYLAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: There are many people, contrary to the shadow minister's allegations, in hostels today who have dementia, who are very frail. They are in hostels. They are paying bonds. They have been paying bonds for the last 10 years. They have not been able to look after their own affairs. They have had to have their families, their legal advisers or the guardianship boards in each of the states and territories, look after their interests. The policy has worked well in hostels. Nothing will change in that respect when it is transferred to nursing homes as well. The government will, however, be monitoring the new arrangements, and we will act firmly if there is any sign of providers abusing this system. What we have done is establish a complaints hotline in every state and territory in this country, something Labor never did in their hostel policy. In addition to that, we have established a complaints committee in every state and territory in this country. That is why I am amazed at the hypocrisy of the shadow minister for aged care. She feigns despair, when she was part of the government which introduced the same policy for hostels. Furthermore, let me remind the House that it was Labor which allowed hostels to charge any level of additional daily fee they wanted to. They could take everything from the resident over and above the pension and the little bit of money a pensioner could earn before their pension was affected. If they earned $20, under their policy the hostels could take $10 of that money. That was the kind of policy that that mob over there introduced when they were in government. We have put a stop to that. Basically, Labor failed. They failed the aged sector in this country. They failed the frail elderly in this country. Labor left the state of many nursing homes in total decay, and we are cleaning up their mess. Retail Tenancies

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member again for his work and also for his question. I must say that I was rather surprised that the opposition made some comments about what they claim to be the inadequacy of our package when it comes to retail tenancy issues, but I would have to say that I have been in their situation before. If the government does something really good, the pressure is on you to find something in it that you do not like so you can at least be an opposition for the sake of being an opposition. But I tell you what: you picked the wrong issue. It is quite remarkable that opposition members should have said what they said yesterday-namely, that the package was inadequate in respect of retail tenancies-because this is not a new issue. Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Prime Minister and it also concerns a matter affecting small business. Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: It is quite apparent that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition 1s not only deprived of relevance but also deprived of advice and deprived of attendance at this House because, after question time yesterday, I made it perfectly clear that some of the press reports which had appeared in relation to this matter, particularly those so vigorously taken up by the Australian Financial Review, were quite wrong. What I made clear was that we were not going to make changes to taxation and we were not going to make changes to the general body of law that would significantly disadvantage the small business community. In fact, in a remark which I made in the party room, which was incorrectly reported in the newspapers, I said that we were not going to take any action to bankrupt small business. Obviously, the abuse of trusts, the use of trusts under the taxation system, is something that ought to attract the attention of any responsible government. I want to make it clear to the parliament and to the Australian community that, in addressing the issue of taxation reform, we intend to match the test of fairness to all of the Australian people. In addressing the issue of taxation reform, we will build a taxation system for the 21st century that will generate jobs, promote exports and attract investment. It is very interesting that I should be asked a question about taxation by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, because it is the Deputy Leader of the Opposition who really wants a GST. He was dropped upon from a great height by the Leader of the Opposition within a couple of hours of making that statement. The longer this debate goes on about taxation, just as you were made irrelevant and left in our wake on small business reform, so you will be made irrelevant and left in our wake on the issue of taxation reform. Your response to the challenge of taxation reform is to say that all you have to do is fiddle at the edges and that basically the system is okay. You had 13 years to fix Australia's taxation system; you made it worse. Now, 18 months into opposition, what is your response to the challenge of taxation reform, which is the greatest single area of economic reform that is needed in Australia to take us into the 21st century? Your response is to say that no reform at all is needed. Let me simply say to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that the taxation reform proposals that we will bring out will give to the Australian community, to the business community and to the ordinary taxpayers of Australia a modem, fair, incentive-driven system that will promote jobs, will attract investment and will free the exporters of Australia from the crippling burden of an old fashioned, ramshackle, out-of-date wholesale sales tax system.

Speaker: Mrs GASH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. After years of neglect and no action on the sensitive subject of child support, many non-custodial parents in my electorate of Gilmore are relieved to hear that this government has had the guts to make some very necessary changes that will make life more bearable for both parents and their children. Could the minister advise those parents in Gilmore, and throughout Australia, just who will benefit from these much needed reforms?

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Gilmore for her question. This is a matter of very considerable interest on this side of the House. Yesterday the government announced some important reforms to the child support scheme to take effect in 199899. The package represents a balanced approach, and it focuses on the interests of children and the balance of responsibility between both parents and fairness to taxpayers generally. The fact is that there are 155,000 payees who will benefit from the introduction of a minimum child support payment of $260 a year. This initiative will reinforce the message that parents have primary responsibility for the financial support of their children. Three hundred thousand payers will pay less child support as a result of an increase in the exempt income amount, and 96,000 payees will have some of this reduction offset through increased family payments. The additional relief. will be provided to blended families through allowing child support payments to be taken into account for family payment purposes. Furthermore, the amount of income the payee will be allowed to earn before it affects child support will be significantly reduced. The non-agency payments in arrears received with the first regular payment of child support will be treated in the same way as other child support under the maintenance income test. Other reforms include allowing parents to use the most recent taxable income assessment for the calculation of child support and broadening the income base to ensure that payers are not avoiding their responsibilities through minimisation. Further administrative reforms will be introduced to the Child Support Agency to build on the significant reforms that have already been made. We recognise that these measures are a second important step in the process of child support reform, and that continued consultation is required. I can assure the honourable member and members such as her who are interested in this matter that we will be seeking to inform at the next stage. I am sure honourable members will be very pleased to note that, after 13 years of inactivity by the former government, this is a government prepared to address these sensitive issues. Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: On 29 September the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) asked me a question relating to the relevance of answers to questions without notice, referring to my statement of 26 May and earlier responses I had made to certain points of order taken during answers to questions. On 4 September 1997 I referred to my statement of 26 May in which I said that I intended to adopt a common sense approach to the application of relevance. I also indicated that if a question was lengthy and ranged over several matters it was open to a wider range of relevance in the answer. The fact that a lengthy question concluded with a specific limited question did not restrict an answer to only the specific concluding words; reference to matters raised his earlier in the question was also relevant. On 29 September, points of relevance were raised, for example, in a question, which takes up 24 lines of Hansard. The answer to the shortest question of that day, taking less than three lines, gave rise to no points of order. The matter is within my direct discretion, and I intend to continue to adopt what I see as a common sense approach to answering questions. Travelling Allowance
