Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I have received a letter from the honourable member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely: The government's failure to protect thousands of Australians from having to pay nearly $100,000 to enter a nursing home from today. I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places. More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Jagajaga) (3.34 p.m.)From today,older Australians and their families will know what this Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) and this government are doing to nursing home care in this country. Today it gets real for this minister. From today, nursing home care will no longer be available to all Australians on the basis of their health need. From today, older Australians too frail and too sick to care for themselves will no longer be automatically guaranteed a bed in a nursing home as the means of getting the care they need. From today, the traumatic process of arranging nursing home care for an older relative has just become more traumatic. It is now clear that, from today, older frail Australians will be paying up to $98,000 to get a nursing home bed. Most people can find that sort of money only in one place: their family home. They do not have it tucked away somewhere else. They do not have it in their back pocket. They have it in one place: their family home. Their family home will have to be sold from today. This Howard government slashed more than half a billion dollars from aged care in the 1996 budget, and that is at the heart of the problem. Half a billion dollars has been taken from the aged. care budget. In order to make up this deficiency and to find the capital necessary, the Howard government has come up with this appalling user-pays system of new fees for nursing homes. This Howard government and this minister have introduced this up-front fee, the so-called accommodation bond. In November, the extra daily fee will begin. The extra daily fee is, of course, just a tax by another name. It really rubs salt into the wounds of older people. The money goes straight to the government, and the residents get no benefit from that payment whatsoever. This minister has been steadfast in her refusal to acknowledge the facts about where the money will come from to pay this· $98,000 entry fee. As the facts mount from today, she is looking more and more like King Canute in her efforts to deny the obvious. The money for the entry fee will come from the sale of people's homes. Let us just briefly walk through the facts one more time. The majority of people in nursing homes are pensioners. Pensioners, Minister! More than 70 per cent of pensioners have only one asset: their family home. Yes, there are exemptions-I am sure the minister will talk about them-when a spouse lives in the home. But the facts are that 90 per cent of the people who need to go into a nursing home live alone before they go into that nursing hClme. They will have to sell their family homes. You might like to say that nobody will be forced. This is the biggest playing with words that I have ever seen. Of course it is not compulsory, Minister, but where does compulsion end and coercion begin? The nursing homes will coerce older people to sell their homes so that they pay the $98,000 in entry fees. The fact is they will have to sell their homes. Let us not forget which people we are talking about here. This is a generation of people, unlike my generation, which has lived through the Great Depression and the Second World War. They have scrimped and saved to pay their bills to give their children-people of your and my generationadvantages that they never had. One of the major objectives of that generation, one of the major objectives of their lives, was to pay off the family home. Minister, part of the cruelty of this legislation is that you do not seem to understand the psychological impact of what you are doing to this generation of Australians. You are trashing the values of a generation. The action is arrogant and contemptuous in its failure to understand the impact it will have on older Australians and their families. Let me share one example with you. It comes from a personal friend of mine. I will not use her name because she would not want me to. Her mother and father have just gone through a very difficult time. Her father has very severe dementia and was becoming very violent towards her mother. They had to find a nursing home bed for her father. They went to many nursing homes in the local area-I think five or six. None of the nursing homes wanted to take this man because he is violent and disruptive. But something had to be done to protect the mother. They could not find a nursing home bed. Eventually, this man had to be committed. This family is saying to me, 'Imagine having to deal with a nursing home saying, "No, we're not taking him. He's too difficult a patient. By the way, you haven't got $98,000 either. '" This is because the mother is still living in the home. "'You haven't got the money. He's too difficult a patient.'" That is the sort of attitude that will take place in our nursing home system as a result of the changes that start today. I have another example. A letter came into my office from a lady who is 64 years of age. She has looked after her father, who is 90 years old, for three years. He has dementia. As she says in her letter: Try caring for a dementia stricken person for 3 weeks and tell me you can do it forever. I am on anti depressants for the first time in my life. I no longer have a life. Why should it end at 64? I was a healthy, active, alive person-not any more. 'Don't tell me that I won't have to sell my home because I have only been looking after my father for three years, not for 5 years.' This woman is not protected by your legislation. She will have to sell her home to get her father into a nursing home because she can no longer look after him. That will be the real effect on families of this abominable piece of legislation that has been introduced. But of course the tragedy and the farce of this legislation do not end there. We will eventually go from a system of care that guaranteed a place to people on the basis of their health needs to one where different levels of care will emerge, depending on how much people can pay. What an abomination. What an un-Australian way of looking after people in their last years of life. It is inevibecome table that raising money through the entry fee system will produce a system that reflects where the money comes from. In other words, it will reflect the capacity of nursing homes to tap into the value of people's homes. Nursing homes in wealthy areas-as this article in the Daily Telegraph clearly showswhere there are high property values will be able to get the $98,000. The government has talked about getting $1.5 billion from this system through the sale of people's homes. What about the nursing homes in poorer areas, in country towns or the poorer parts of our cities where they can only pay a smaller amount? As is made quite clear in the article in the Daily Telegraph, it is about to start; it bonds. will start today. There are places in Sydney that will charge only $30,000. Those places will, of course, end up as second-rate nursing homes. Those that charge $98,000 will be very nice, thanks very much. We have seen from the newspapers today that nursing homes are already saying that poorer areas and lower fees will go together. We have evidence, Minister, that you are responsible. This minister will stand condemned for introducing a two-tiered system into our nursing home care: one system for the rich and another much lesser system for the poor. Of course it will take time for these controof versial changes to work through the system. We know what that means, Minister. Over the next 12 months or so this generation of people who pay their $98,000 to get into a nursing home will not get anything for it because, unfortunately, it is the case that people do not live for a very long time in nursing homes. They will pay these huge upfront fees and get no benefit whatsoever. The nursing homes will not be upgraded in their lifetimes. They will have sold their homes, sold the one thing that they own, and will get no benefit whatsoever in their lifetimes. The government keeps trying to talk up a crisis in nursing home care to justify its actions. Minister, there is not a crisis yet but, sure as heck, one is coming. The way this government is going about these changes there will soon be a crisis in our nursing home system, because the other thing that has very clear in the newspapers today is that about 15 per cent of homes have failed the certification test. This brings in the big catch-22 in this legislation: the test that means that if you need capital to upgrade you definitely will not be able to get it because you cannot charge an accommodation bond. While it is true that substandard homes should never be condoned, this government has shown the height of irresponsibility by being willing to wash its hands of the problems it will create. The minister was quoted in the Sydney Morning Herald today saying: It is unfortunate. Some of those homes will close because of being unable to charge accommodation This minister is completely irresponsible because she has not allocated anything like enough money to make sure these nursing homes have the capital they need to upgrade. I am sure she will say that the government has allocated funds. Let me tell the public: it is $10 million, which might build 2'h nursing homes. That is all. Where will the people go who have to leave the 300 nursing homes which are expected to fail the inspection? Where will the nursing home residents go? This minister just wants to wash her hands it. She is not going to provide the funding for the 300 nursing homes that will close as a result of her incompetent legislation. Minister, you cannot walk away from the ripple effect that this is going to have throughout the whole nursing home sector. Where will the residents from the nursing homes that are closed go? Will they stay in public hospitals? They will not be able to stay in public hospitals. The Australian Medical Association are gOIng to put paid to that idea. They will not stand for nursing home patients staying in public hospitals. They wanted your legislation deferred for 10 years. That is how concerned they are about what will happen to public ho-pitals. Governments are elected to govern, not to shrug their shoulders and look away and say that it is up to market forces. That is what this minister is doing: leaving it to market forces; leaving it to user pays. If you have $98,000 it will be just fine for you. You will be able to get into a nursing home, you will be fine, you will be looked after. If you have got $30,000, you might get into a second-rate nursing home. But, if you have nothing, you go to the back of the queue. That will be the result of this minister's new legislation. Not only will they get nothing, but if they do manage to get into a nursing home they will get second-rate care. That is an abomination to the Australian people and something that we should be totally ashamed of.

Speaker: Mrs MOYLAN
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I welcome this opportunity to proudly mark the commencement of the government's aged care reforms. Today is the day when this government begins to rebuild Australia's nursing homes: a day that never dawned for Labor in the nearly 5,000 days that it was in government. For 5,000 days, Labor sat and watched the state of Australian nursing homes decline and deteriorate. Labor has no credibility whatsoever on this issue. The untruths and distortions spread by the opposition and vested interests have done nothing but scare and humiliate old people, making them political footballs. This debate today is the last-ditch effort by the shadow minister for scares to throw a bit more mud, spread a few more untruths

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Mr Nehl)Order! The honourable minister will refer to the member for Jagajaga by her correct title. Mr Brough-The member for scares. Ms Macklin-On a point of order: I ask the member, who is in the wrong place, to withdraw that remark. Mr Brough-I withdraw.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Thank you. I caution the honourable member for Longman to be in his place if he wants to open his mouth, and he will still be out of order.

Speaker: Mrs MOYLAN
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The untruths and distortions spread by the opposition and vested interests have done nothing but scare and humiliate old people, turning them into political footballs. This debate today is the shadow minister's last-ditch effort to throw a got bit more mud, to spread a few more untruths to disgracefully scare some more elderly and frail Australians. From the very first day of this debate, all the opposition has done is play a totally divisive and negative game. That has been the sum total of the opposition's contribution to this debate on aged care. Not once have we had any acceptance of the parlous state of affairs that nursing homes were left in as a result of the funding system so badly neglected under Labor. Not once have we had any evidence that the shadow minister has been anywhere near some of the older nursing homes, particularly in her state, where a good proportion of nursing homes are simply old houses converted for the purpose. Until today, not once had we had any acknowledgment by the shadow minister of the totally inadequate funding provided for people with dementia under the current system, and the desperate need, as she highlighted-thus highlighting Labor's failure-to develop more appropriate funding and care for dementia patients. Not once have we had any acknowledgment that they even care about the 40 per cent of residents that share wards with four or more people, the 11 per cent of facilities that do not meet fire standards or the 15 per cent that do not meet health standards. Does the shadow minister deny these figures and the disgraceful stories behind such statistics? Her silence to date indicates such outrageous denial. Let me explain what these statistics mean, particularly for residents' quality of life. They mean that too many buildings have serious structural deficiencies. They mean that there are hazards which jeopardise residents' safety and security. They mean an unsafe working environment for staff. There are many institutional buildings with dark narrow corridors with inadequate lighting. This restricts residents' mobility, further hampering their capacity to enjoy a high quality of life. There are also small narrow toilets, perhaps shared between many residents. Some buildings have multiple storeys with no lifts, further restricting mobility. Some buildings have a sterile hospital-like environment which, despite the best efforts of the dedicated staff and providers, are far from homelike. Too many nursing home buildings are serious firetraps. There may be no firewalls, the fire exits could be blocked or even locked. The windows might not open, or perhaps the fire exits open to enclosed courtyards, not allowing residents to escape. There are too many people living in a room with four, six, eight or more beds. This means rows of beds sometimes less than a metre apart-bed after bed after bed. This cramped accommodation means no privacy. It means barely any room for personal belongings. Labor's response was an abject failure. It cut funding on capital expenditure while not allowing nursing home providers to charge bonds. The shadow minister was quite wrong when she said in the House that we have provided only $10 million. Ms MackIin-A year.

Speaker: Mrs MOYLAN
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: We have provided $10 million a year, that is correct, but you did say 'a year'; you just said $10 million. What Labor did in 1992-93 was allocate $45 million for nursing home capital purposes. By 1995-96, this dropped to $10.7 million-a 75 per cent reduction in capital funding. Even worse, only $2.7 million of that was for upgrading old and substandard services. The rest went to build new services. From such a parlous state it is no longer possible to keep placing bandaids on the problem. The wound is festering and it is getting worse. Rather than just ignore it, as Labor did, our reforms will fix it. Our reforms acknowledge that, in stark contrast to nursing home buildings, hostels generally offer a much better standard of accommodation. This is no accident. Labor's hostel policy introduced in 1988 and supported by us meant that hostels had an income stream to significantly finance their own upgrade and refurbishment. This income stream was called entry contributions and now accommodation bonds. Accommodation bonds across both hostels and nursing homes will provide an income stream of some $130 million each year after four years. This matches well with Professor Gregory's estimation that around $125 million a year is needed to bring the nursing home buildings up to reasonable community expectations. It is painfully obvious that the opposition had never had any intention of being a constructive player in this debate and has no understanding of the conditions of the buildings that many residents find themselves living in today. Let me take this opportunity to put some facts on the table, given the shadow minister has decided to ignore them. The reforms that we will implement today will deliver on a number of fronts. I will briefly mention just 10 of those points. Nursing home building quality will improve. People will be housed in a safe environment where they will have comfort and dignity in their most frail years. We will have improved funding for dementia. The new funding system will deliver a substantial increase to funding for dementiaabout a 30 per cent increase on average to a hostel resident with dementia. This will not relieve the financial strain on dementiaspecific facilities and improve access to dementia care. Higher levels of funding will be guaranteed for providers who care for financially disadvantaged people. Under the current system, providers receive a meagre subsidy of $3.50 per day for financially disadvantaged people. Under our system that amount will more than double to $7 a day and it will go to $12 a day if the provider cares for more than 40 per cent of financially disadvantaged residents. This will provide much greater support for providers in poorer areas and those who specialise in financially disadvantaged residents. We will also provide greater services in rural and remote areas. The special viability assistance funding was previously available only to nursing homes. This has been extended to hostels as well. Facilities in remote areas in particular tend to have higher proportions of financially disadvantaged residents and so will benefit greatly from the higher funding levels. In addition, facilities in rural and remote areas will be targeted by the government's capital grants program which provides additional assistance to help facilitates build or upgrade. For this $40 million was announced in the 1996 budget. Facilities can also choose to broaden the range of care they provide and be funded for. So residents will increasingly be able to stay in their own towns rather than move to get the care they need. That is very important to rural and remote areas. There will also be comprehensive access protection for financially disadvantaged people. Much stronger and clearer protection than ever existed in the past will ensure that older Australians get access to care according to their need, not according to their means. When the shadow minister was asked on radio in Perth this morning what the Labor Party would do if it were to lay down a policy, she said, 'We would make sure people get access according to their needs, not according to their means.' That is exactly what this policy does. All nursing homes and hostels will have to set aside a proportion of places for people who cannot afford to pay a bond. Providers will receive higher subsidies for those places. There are also new rules for the family home. For the first time, they are designed to protect spouses, dependent children, close family members and carers who received no special treatment under the system Labor had in place. The new accreditation arrangements, which will be supervised by an independent board, will ensure that all facilities meet standards. This will mean an improved quality of care and quality of life for all residents. The facilities that are failing these basic tests a stark reminder of Labor's neglect of the nursing home sector and its appalling report card in properly caring for our frail aged. The new system breaks down artificial barriers between nursing homes and hostels, and funds people according to their care need, not what sort of facility they happen to be in. The reforms introduce new and stronger consumer safeguards. We launched one of those products this morning which was very well received. These changes will ensure a system of quality care sustainable for the coming decades. It is important also to look at the needs of elderly people outside of residential care and to put the reforms into perspective. Not once have we heard any comment from the opposition on the need of the other sector of our older population. Not once have we had any acknowledgment that only seven to 10 per cent of older people rely on residential care. These people are the forgotten people from the previous government. But, finally, we have implemented many changes to assist people to retain their independence. We have established the Conference for Older Australians. We have established a healthy senior task force to develop programs and activities for older people in the community. In conclusion, the government's age care reform package will bring significant and lasting reform to nursing homes in a way that will make them viable and sustainable well into the future. It will ensure that frail older people will have equitable access to high standards of care and accommodation and that, as their care needs increase over time, they will not have to face the trauma of moving to another facility to get appropriate care. This package will introduce strong protections for consumers and create incentives for providers to continue to invest in maintenance and improvements to building stock. It will ensure that access to quality care is based on care need and not on means to pay. It is based on people's need, on the clinically assessed needs by the ACATS team-not on people's capacity to pay. These are some of the pillars upon which are our reforms are built, born of consultation and a responsible public policy approach-a far cry from what we get from the opposition, which is just a series of distortions and untruths day after day. I would just like to read out some of those endorsements. Betty Johnson, Australian Pensioners and Superannuants' Federation: Your concern for low income residents and your quick action is greatly appreciated. Dr Keith Woollard, Australian Medical Association: The aged care reforms... is one way which Australia can come· to terms with the massive increase in demand for quality accommodation and care of our ageing population. Now we have a government that is willing to make a tough decision that will ultimately benefit all aged care residents by providing proprietors of these facilities no excuse not to improve standards. Australian Nursing Homes and Extended Care Association Ltd: Today's introduction of the aged care reforms is the culmination of many months of consultation between the Government, service providers, consumer organisations and unions. The resultant reform package will herald change in the delivery of aged care (and we are) confident that the changes will be for the better. Denis Jones, Australian Nursing Federation: Mrs Moylan has made a genuine effort to consult all groups involved in the massive overhaul of nursing homes. Ashleigh Lodge Private Nursing Home: We support your aged care reform package and appreciate the fact that you have listened to the sector and you have actually heard what we are saying. Political reporter, Fleur Bitcon, National Nine news coverage: The Aged Care Bill is the most important piece of legislation since the government and the Democrats combined to pass the industrial relations reform. Senator John Woodley, the Australian Democrats aged care spokesman: We now have an agreement which has the stamp of approval from the three main church providers of the aged care facilities. I am confident that improved package will deliver a better standard of care for Australia's ageing population. Finally, Mr Gary Johns, a former Labor minister, on PM: The policy is correct. We'd already done it in hostels. I think it would only be a matter of time, if we'd remained in government, that we would have imposed it for nursing homes as well. It's logical. It's fair. It's reasonable. The opposition have made themselves totally irrelevant in this debate. They are isolated in this debate. They chose to play outside the rules, they chose to play in an unfair way, and at the end of the day their tactics have utterly failed. Today we move forward to bring better care to Australia's frail aged; to build better buildings for them; to guarantee future care for an ever growing number of elderly population; and, more than anything, to underpin current and future Commonwealth aged care policy with security, dignity and compassion for the elderly in Australia today.

Speaker: Mr WILTON
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: What an absolute load of garbage from a minister in her death throes. I can just see all the backbenchers in their offices wringing their hands and saying, 'Oh, no, she has done it again. Why doesn't she go? Why doesn't she just go?' Except for two: Patricia Mary Worth and Ian Douglas Macdonald, who will be saying, 'You beauty, she's done it again.' They will be wringing their hands with glee as they sit in their offices and watch such a poor and tawdry performance as the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) has just put in. This is a coalition which is racked by division and jealousy. This is a coalition which is at war over the spoils of a party which is in rapid decline. The corpses of Jull, MCGauran and Sharp are barely coldalthough some might well say· that they have suffered rigor mortis now for some 18 months

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The honourable member for Isaacs will refer to members by their correct titles.

Speaker: Mr WILTON
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I will, Mr Deputy Speaker. And the vultures are hovering over them, just as they are over the trembling countenance of the minister who has just departed the chamthis ber, in the same way that she has left the aged in this country-high and dry. Let no-one say that those opposite have not been warned. The Labor Party, led by the champion of Australia's frail fraternity, the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), has warned that these controversial aged care changes will devastate the residential aged care sector. But do not just take it from us, Mr Deputy Speaker, concerned and compassionate though we may be. Take a warning, departed Minister, from the Anglican Archbishop of Perth, the Most Reverend Dr Carnley, and also the Moderator of the Uniting Church in the minister's state of WA, Reverend Dunn, who called on the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to delay these disgraceful changes for 12 months. Not only that, but the archbishop raised the possibility of a hidden agenda which may favour what he called profit seekers in the aged care industry. But before I turn to the archbishop's warning on profit seekers, tempted though I may be to raise the likes of Doug Moran immediately, let me inform the House of why those opposite are seeking to implement these most heinous of changes. The government needs the money to pay for nursing home upgrades because it withdrew half a billion dollars from aged care in the 1996 budget. The government considers that this money can be found only in the most rotten and despicable of ways: by making aged people sell off their homes if they need to enter a nursing home. One of the fatal flaws of this legislation is that if nursing homes want to charge an entry fee and get access to this money then they have got to go through a process of being certified as having buildings of a reasonable standard. The catch-22 of this fatally flawed legislation is that nursing homes need to improve accommodation standards. If a nursing home has substandard buildings that need repair, it will fail the certification process and will, therefore, be unable to charge an entry fee and obviously be unable to fix itself up. Ms Ellis-It's stupid.

Speaker: Mr WILTON
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: It is stupid, as the member for Namadgi has rightly interjected. If this money is not going to needy nursing homes, then where is it going? Think the archbishop's warning. Think profit seekers. Think the likes of Doug Moran. The clear losers in all of this are the aged Australians in genuine need of nursing home care. The winners are the likes of Doug Moran and his Moran Health Care Group. This is the very same Doug Moran who boasted on the 7.30 Report earlier this year that he was the government's main adviser in the area of aged care. He also confirmed to the Sunday Age on 27 August that he had significant influence on the government's aged care policy. This same Doug Moran, who made $250 million out of aged care, putting him at No. 40 on the BRW top 200 rich list, has been in rapid expansion mode ever since in anticipation of the financial windfalls this legislation will bring his group. Of course this group was selected to privately develop five Victorian state government nursing homes and keep the profits. The same group is also developing a new nursing home in Rose .Bay in Sydney. The same group also goes under the name of Western Health Care Ltd in Western Australia where it is a large concern. It is opportune to again heed Reverend Carnley's warning-and I return to his letter to the Prime Minister dated 3 September 1997-where, in part, Reverend Carnley says: ... it may be that a hidden agenda is operating in relation to these matters which seek to diminish the role of not for profit providers by favouring the profit seekers in the industry. 1 think this kind of suggestion has a potential to explode into the most horrendous disruption of the industry. To return one last time to the Moran group, an extract from the Sunday Age of that same date, 27 August of this year, said: The Chief Executive Officer of the Moran Group, Mr Shane Moranthe rather incestuous company that it istold the Sunday Age that his company had increased its nursing home investments in the expectation that the government would introduce legislation. Asked if this was the case Mr Shane Moran said: 'I suppose so.' This is a damning indictment of the performance of this government and its intimate association with those who men of the cloth have suggested are profit seekers, who profit from being in bed with government-the same government that is forcing the aged to near debt just to get a bed. No doubt two tiers of care will result from these changes. A survey of Sydney nursing homes in yesterday's Daily Telegraph revealed a fee range of $30,000 to $90,000. The $30,000 fees were concentrated in the lower income areas of Sydney. Undoubtedly homes in those areas will have less money available to them. Many people in these areas will clearly be unable to afford entry fees, driving down the level of overall care. I want to draw the minister's attention to a well-known fact that seems to have escaped her, that being that hostels and nursing homes, until today, were in no way the same. Comparing hostels to nursing homes is like comparing hospitals to hotels because both have beds. It is like comparing bikes to semitrailers because both have wheels. Hostels were established to accommodateand I stress the word 'accommodate' - older people who made a deliberate decision to move into accommodation that offered a degree of supporter living. That they now contain a growing number of people who are increasingly frail is because they are growing older. Another fact that seems to have escap"ed this minister is that we all do grow old. But the key point is that residents of hostels have decided-and again I emphasise 'decided'-to sell up and move into hostels. That they may be frail now does not mean that they were frail or incapacitated when they decided to move into the hostel. Nursing homes, on the other hand, clearly are for seriously ill or seriously frail people who are unable to look after themselves. You do not go into a nursing home by choice, Minister. I know that is one of your favourite words, but it does not apply in this instance. People go into nursing homes when they are assessed as being unable to care for themselves. They are assessed by aged care assessment teams, usually comprising a doctor, nurse, social worker and perhaps a gerontologist. It was said on radio this morning that the government expect to raise $1.5 billion by coercing people to sell their homes. The minister says that Labor has run nursing homes down. Labor acknowledges that nursing homes needed money spent on them. Indeed, it was there in our own forward estimates. That is where the Liberals have made their half a billion dollar saving. When money needed to be put in they cut half a billion dollars out in last year's budget. They plan to generate some $1.5 billion by making people sell their homes, resulting in profits galore for people like Doug Moran, the government's self-confessed aged care adviser. That is where this money is going. Nursing home care under this government is allocated clearly on the basis of wealth, not health. This government might as well nail down the coffin lids of Australia's aged because they will certainly be dancing on the coalition's grave come the next election.

Speaker: Mr BROUGH
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I have been absolutely appalled by the standard of argument put forward by the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) and the member for Isaacs (Mr Wilton). Let us just look at some facts. The Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) outlined the facts of this case, something that members opposite would not have a clue about. All they stand up here and do is belt rhetoric time and time again without once addressing the facts. Let us go back to 1988 when you introduced a payment to go into hostels, supported by this party. I happen to have been in the health care industry. Before I entered parliament I had the displeasure to go through some nursing homes and hostels. I could not understand why hostels seemed to be such wonderful places, such new pristine environments, which you would be happy to have one of your own live in. Then on the same day you would be forced into a nursing home which was dark, dingy, smelly, almost a fire hazard and a risk to people's health. That is what the opposition condemned them to. Here we are some nine years later, and what are they saying? We want more of the same. The facts are that when it comes to standards some people set low standards and fail to achieve them. This crowd does not even have standards in any form of any policy. We have seen that today in relation to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), the Clayton's opposition leader, who will not deal with his recalcitrant senator. We have seen it in relation to health care. We have seen it in relation to so many bills put before this House. Let us look at the real situation. In 1988, were there prudential arrangements for people entering into health care arrangements in hostels? No, not one damn thing was put up by this opposition when they were in government. Was there a cap-the $98,000 that the member for Jagajaga goes on about? I do not hear her saying too much now because there was no cap under her government. There were no safeguards. Where were their safeguards in 1988? Did they run away? No, they did not. Let us go on. Were there safeguards to prevent the sale of the family home to go into a hostel? There were no safeguards, none whatsoever, yet this government has introduced safeguards. Let us get away from the rhetoric and get into the truth, something that you do not mix very well with. What about a guarantee for low income earners? People like yourselves are so dedicated to the poor and the low income earners on the wharves and in the mines, those earning $90,000-odd plus perhaps, your dedicated workers, your union workers out there who are so necessarily in need of a health care place. What guarantee did you give to genuine low income earners? Absolutely none at all. Yet this government legislates that 25 per cent of places will be made available for those people. You stand condemned for what you did not do in the hostel industry in 1988. The fact is that the policy you introduced put money into the system which allowed for an increase in and an improvement in the standard of living of those people who had to go to hostels. The last member to speak for the opposition, the honourable member for Isaacs, almost quoted word for word the requirements to go into a nursing home. Let me tell you the requirements to enter into a hostel in my electorate of Longman, which are no different for any other electorate-that is, you must be assessed by an aged care assessment team which is organised by a doctor. You do not go into a hostel because you think that it great place to be; you go there because you are aged, frail or cannot look after yourself adequately in your own home. For some reason, you seem to think these people go in there for a picnic. It is just not true. I would like to paint a picture for you of nursing homes that, unfortunately, I have had the displeasure to visit and that, recently, some of my relatives have had the misfortune of also having to visit. I note that the member for Jagajaga has stood up here and proclaimed letters from people she does not want to mention, talking about the situations they were in. These are the descriptions of some of the nursing homes that are in Brisbane now. I notice the member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) was chuckling away there before. Some of these are in his very electorate and he does not intend to do anything about it. Some of them were described as rabbit warrens, as fire traps, as very depressing. Is this the way we wish to see our elderly, frail population live out their dying years? I want to just paint this picture for you. You go into an old Queensland building, a very old building, a wooden building with dark, narrow hallways. They are cold. They are damp. You go into a small room and there, with the petition of nothing more than a curtain, are two frail old ladies. Mr Bevis-I've been there, Mal.

Speaker: Mr BROUGH
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Yes, you have been there and you do not want to do anything about it. You are not interested in addressing it. You have seen the improvement in the hostel industry and you do not want to see it happen to the nursing home. Is that because you do not care, they are beyond caring about? Is that what it is? There is no political will, or is it there are no votes? Is that what it is-that is, there are votes in hostels but not in nursing homes? You stand up here in your pious fashion and tell us that you care about older Australians. You stand condemned by your own budget papers. The ALP capital funding of nursing homes in 1992-93 was $45 million, is a and you thought so much of them that, while you borrowed $76 billion to try to get this country somehow looking half decent while you failed us, you spent a miserable $10.7 million in your last year in government$10.7 million, not enough to buy one nursing home or one hostel. You should be disgusted with what you have done. The member for Jagajaga parades herself around this country scaring people, and that is an understatement. I went to a retirement village in my electorate some two or three weeks ago. A fellow said to me, 'I can'tget into a nursing home. They're going to charge me. I'm going to have to sell my house.' I said, ' Sir, have you ever applied to go to a nursing home?' 'No, but that's what I've heard from the member for Jagajaga.' She wants to stand there and scare the living daylights out of these people, people who have contributed to Australia for so many years and who deserve a fair go. All you can do is scare them into an early grave. The previous - ember said that we will be nailing down theIr coffins. You are dancing on their coffins as you attempt to scare them into oblivion. That is the appalling standard of the Labor Party. This minister has introduced the right legislation into this House to ensure that the measures that come into place today will ensure that my parents and some of us in this place who are unfortunate enough to find ourselves in nursing homes will be cared for in a quality environment. There will be standards. You have just stood up there today and said that nursing homes are going to close because we are going to impose standards-300 fail the test. Do you people in the gallery want to see your parents, and perhaps yourselves, condemned to living in a dark, damp, cold, unfriendly environment? Is that what you want-no personal contact in such an environment where the fire hazards are known? We are saying to you that we want this rectified, and this policy will ensure that it is done. You talk about people making money out of aged care. We are saying there needs to be more quality places, and not one bed will be reduced under this policy . You have three years in which to meet the standard. In that time, those places will be improved. The fact is that the member for Jagajaga has failed the Australian public as an adviser to the previous government. The previous government did not have the political will, did not manage to put any finances in this issue and now stands condemned. So the louder she is, the longer she bleats, the more she hopes that she is going to frighten people away from reality. Let us just recap the reality of it. In 1988, were there any safeguards by this Labor opposition? No. Were there any. standards? No. We have another man who has just arrived in the chamber who has no standards, and he has shown that all week. Did they put any money into it? No. They have not put any money into aged care. They have not put any standards into. aged care. They have not put any safeguards there. As for Australians having to sell their houses, I ask you this: what did you do to protect those frail people who had to move into hostels? Did you say to them that 25 per cent of places would be made available to the financially disadvantaged? No. Did you say to them that they did not have to sell their houses? No. The answer is no, no, no. You have failed. You failed in 1988 to put in the right safeguards, and you are failing today. You will continue to fail the Australian population. They deserve better and they are getting better from a coalition government that has the policies to deliver to the Australian public and to ensure that our families can live in the sort of comfort they deserve and demand in their old age. This minister is a credit to this government. The policies she has brought down will stand this government in good stead for many, many years to come. (Time expired)

NA AMENDMENT (MIGRATION AGENTS) BILL 1997 First Reading Bill presented by Mr Ruddock:, and read a first time. Second Reading

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: MIGRATION LEGISLATION
text: I move: That the bill be now read a second time. This bill is one of a package implementing the government's decision to move the migration advice industry towards voluntary self-regulation through a period of statutory self-regulation. The measures contained in the principal bill are consistent with the government's commitment to reduce unnecessary regulation of small business. At the same time, it maintains and strengthens consumer protection for those people in the community who are vulnerable to exploitation by unscrupulous or incompetent migration agents. The measures will also contribute to the integrity of the migration program by actively promoting an ethical and competent migration advice industry. A review of the existing scheme for registration of migration agents was commissioned by the government in June 1996. This scheme was the first regulatory arrangement to be reviewed by the Commonwealth as a party to the competition principles agreement. The review focused on the impact the scheme has had on consumer protection and on the costs of regulation borne by business. The review was conducted by a task force within my department and was guided by a reference group of independent experts chaired by Mr Ian Spicer, the former Chief Executive of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. The reference group also included: Ms Pamela O'Neil, Chairperson of the Migration Agents Registration Board; Mr Ian Tonking, a Sydney barrister and consultant editor of the Australian Trade Practices Reporter; Ms Cheryl Webster, a grant-in-aid worker for Careforce, the Anglican Home Mission; Mr John Hodges, Queensland State President of the Migration Institute of Australia and a former immigration minister; and Ms Pauline Matthewson, National Committee Member of the Migration Institute of Australia. The review found that the existing scheme had achieved a measure of consumer protection. It also found that its credibility had strengthened somewhat in the time since the scheme was reviewed by the Parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on Migration in 1995. The review found that the existing scheme had not adversely affected competition in the migration advice market, although it recognised that there was a need to improve competency standards in a way that would not affect the level of competition in the industry. In considering the findings of the review, the government concluded that, although it would be possible for the industry to be selfregulating in the future, this was not immediately achievable for two main reasons. The first reason is the vulnerability of the consumer group. This group may have difficulties making an informed choice about the quality of the migration advice they are purchasing. There is a history of exploitation of consumers of migration advice by a number of unscrupulous and unethical migration agents. The second reason is the fact that the migration advice industry is not yet 'mature', in the sense that there is limited cooperation occurring between the three main occupational groups and the Migration Institute of Australia. These occupational groups are lawyers, agents in the private sector of the industry, and agents in the voluntary sector. At present, the Migration Institute of Australia, as an industry association, covers only 10 per cent of registered agents. The government has decided to introduce a form of statutory self-regulation as an interim measure for two years, commencing on 21 March 1998. This bill will provide for the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to appoint the Migration Institute of Australia as the Migration Agents Registration Authority. The Migration Institute of Australia is willing to take on this role and strongly supports the government's intention to maintain a professional and ethical migration advice industry. The institute has acknowledged strengths in the areas of competency, education and ethics. However, it will require time and support to develop the infrastructure to undertake the full range of regulatory functions and to achieve coverage of the whole industry. The legislation before the House today will provide the necessary statutory backing for this to occur. In addition to the statutory backing provided by the principal bill, I intend to enter into a formal agreement with the Migration Institute of Australia. The agreement will spell out the details of how the institute will carry out its function as the Migration Agents Registration Authority and will include provisions in relation to: performance requirements; financial accountability; complaints handling and discipline processes referral of instances of unregistered practice and fraud to my department for investigation; and support to be provided by my department. The proposed scheme will be reviewed by the government before 21 March 2000. The review will determine the extent to which the Migration Institute of Australia has developed the capacity and infrastructure to undertake the role as industry regulator in a fully selfregulating environment. This bill retains all of the important elements of the existing scheme for registration of migration agents. For example, it will continue to be a mandatory requirement for all persons who wish to practise as migration agents, including members of the legal profession, to be registered. All applicants for registration will be required to satisfy the registration authority that they are of good character and have the necessary knowledge to give quality migration advice and assistance. As is now the case, unregistered practice will be an offence. My department will continue to rigorously investigate and pursue those who provide immigration advice without being registered. As with the existing scheme, the bill provides for the investigation of complaints made against migration agents who act in an unprofessional or unscrupulous manner. However, it will also introduce significant improvements in the complaints handling process to address the review's finding that the existing process was expensive, slow and insufficiently responsive to consumer concerns. For example, the bill provides for the registration authority to be able to refer a complainant and the relevant agent to a mediator. The intention is to enable the parties to a dispute to negotiate a mutually acceptable outcome without having to resort to lengthy and expensive disciplinary processes. The existing legislation allows for disciplinary action to be taken against an agent who, for example, is found to have breached the code of conduct or is found not to be a person of integrity. Such disciplinary action can take the form of a caution or the agent's registration can be suspended or cancelled. These sanctions will remain. This bill proposes changes to the way disciplinary action against agents who are also practising lawyers will be handled. The changes will make it possible for the Migration Institute of Australia to refer disciplinary matters involving lawyer agents to the relevant professional bodies for disciplinary action. This will place the responsibility for handling malpractice within the legal profession itself, where it properly belongs. The bill also proposes a number of new provisions aimed at strengthening consumer protection and improving the competence of agents. The present definition of 'immigration assistance' does not extend to migration advice given in relation to sponsorships or nominations. This means that a person can tary provide assistance and advice to potential sponsors or nominators without being required to be registered as a migration agent. Both the Joint Standing Committee on Migration and the recent review conducted by my departin ment recommended that this loophole be levels closed, noting that a growing number of of sponsors and nominees were effectively cases. unprotected from poor advice or unscrupulous practice. The government also recognises that travel agents, in advising non-citizen clients of need to have a visa for travel to and from Australia, could arguably be required register as migration agents under the existing scheme. This bill amends the definition 'immigration assistance' in a way which will clearly exclude the limited forms of assistance provided by travel agents and interpreters. The bill, therefore, removes an area of necessary regulation and uncertainty for tourism industry. The government wants ensure that all clients of migration agents fully protected by the legislation. Under the current arrangements, agents operating in the voluntary sector are not required to meet the same knowledge test for registration as agents operating in the private sector. Some of these agents have fully met the knowledge test and are recognised as highly competent and ethical practitioners. However, many have not. In practice, this has led to the development of two different will standards of competency in the industry, with some of the most vulnerable clients receiving a lower standard of service. The bill addresses this inequity by requiring all agents in the voluntary sector to fully the knowledge test in order to qualify for registration as a migration agent. many agents in the voluntary sector would be unable to meet the test without further educaof tion and training, the bill provides for a sixmonth period of grace to enable them to qualify. In addition, my department is making funding available for the provision of training courses to enable agents in the voluntary sector to obtain the level of knowledge required for full registration. At present, agents operating in the volunsector and providing their services free of charge are not required to pay a registration fee. The recent review of the existing scheme found that this arrangement resulted in agents in the private sector cross-subsidising agents the voluntary sector. It also found that fee were higher as a result because the cost processing a registration is the same in all The two charge bills included in this package reduce this cross-subsidy by ensuring that charges are imposed on voluntary sector the agents. The government proposes, however, that the regulations will provide a lower rate to of charge for voluntary sector agents in recognition of their lesser capacity to meet the of full costs of registration. At present, once an agent is registered, there are no incentives for them to maintain or improve their knowledge and professional uncompetency. Clients, therefore, have no way the of knowing whether an agent has made the to effort to keep abreast of changes to the are Migration Act and regulations. The bill contains provisions designed to improve the competency and ethical practice of all migration agents. From 21 March 1999, all agents seeking to re-register must demonstrate that they have met criteria in relation to undertaking continuing professional development. The details of this requirement will be set out in regulations. Agents who fail to meet this requirement be refused re-registration and will not be permitted to continue to practise in the industry until they reapply and meet the requirements. I am aware that this is a serious measure. It potentially affects the livelihood meet of some people in small business. But it is necessary both in the public interest and in Because the interests of consumers. Members would appreciate that the integrity the government's migration program can be compromised by unscrupulous and exploitative practice by migration agents. Currently, consumers have no guarantee that the agent they are paying to give them professional advice is, in fact, fully competent. If this requirement for continuing professional development has the effect of dissuading some agents from remaining in the industry because they do not wish to improve their practice, then the industry and the community would be better off without them. Two charge bills are being introduced in tandem with this bill. Together with the provisions in the principal bill, they will provide a more flexible vehicle for setting the level of fees applying to applications for registration. After appointment as the Migration Agents Registration Authority, the Migration Institute of Australia will be ised to collect fees on behalf of the Commonwealth. The principal bill includes an appropriation to the Migration Institute of Australia to ensure that it recovers the costs of running the new scheme. The Renewal Charge Bill will be repealed on 21 March 1999. After that time, renewal of agents' registration will no longer be automatic. Instead, agents will be required to apply for re-registration and meet the new continuing professional development requirements. The principal bill also includes a series of transitional arrangements. These are designed to enable a seamless transition to the new scheme. Agents who registered under the old scheme will continue to have their registration and renewal dates recognised by the new registration authority. Those who submitted their application for registration close to the expiry of the old scheme will be able to be registered by the new registration authority. In addition, unfinalised complaints and disciplinary processes will be able to be brought to completion by the new registration authority. In conclusion, I would like to emphasise that this package of bills provides a unique opportunity for government and the industry to work together to ensure the development of a competent, reputable and ethical migration advice industry. The government believes this will be of benefit both to consumers and the broader Australian community. I com:mend the· bill to the House. I present the relevant explanatory memorandum. Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Braddon-Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister) (4.43 p.m.)-I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The bill will insert rules in the income tax law to limit the circumstances in which trusts can deduct current year and prior year losses and debt deductions. The measures generally take effect from 9 May 1995. The government announced in the 1996-97 budget its intention to proceed with the previous government's 1995-96 budget announcement on 9 May 1995 that trust loss rules would be introduced. Consultation The government has consulted widely with taxpayers and tax professionals in developing the trust loss legislation. The government announced in the 1996-97 budget that several significant changes would be made to the previous government's draft legislation. Those changes were set out in a press release issued on budget night. Most of these changes were made in response to the concerns expressed by taxpayers and tax professionals about the previous government's proposed legislation. In announcing that it would go ahead with the measures, the government committed itself to consulting widely with taxpayers and tax the professionals before introducing legislation into the parliament. To this end, the government's draft of the legislation was released for public comment on 10 February 1997. A large number of submissions concerning the exposure draft were received. The government has considered these submissions and has taken them into account in finalising the legislation. The government has made many modifications to the measures in response to concerns raised in the submissions. One of the main concerns raised was about the application of the income injection test to family trusts. In response to this concern, the government announced in the 1997-98 budget that it would relax the application of the income injection test for family trusts but the definition of 'family member' would be narrowed from the 1997-98 budget time. Purpose of the trust loss measures The purpose of the trust loss measures is to restrict the recoupment of losses and other deductions of trusts in order to prevent the transfer of the tax benefit of the losses. This occurs when a person who did not bear the economic effect of the loss when it was incurred by the trust obtains a benefit as a result of the trust's ability to deduct the loss. The measures achieve this aim by examining whether there has been a change in underlying ownership or control of a trust or whether certain schemes have been entered into in order to take advantage of a trust's losses or other deductions. The tax law already contains tests which limit the deductibility of losses incurred by companies. The proposed rules that are to apply to trusts will differ in some respects from those that apply to companies, reflecting the different characteristics of trusts. Changes in ownership or control of a trust The tests to be satisfied before losses are deductible will vary depending on the type of trust. Each type of trust has to satisfy certain tests relating to ownership or control of the trust in order to be able to deduct prior and current year losses and debt deductions. For example, while fixed trusts will be subject to a continuity of ownership test, nonfamily discretionary trusts will be subject to continuity of ownership, continuity of control and pattern of distributions tests. This reflects the fact that it is. not possible to apply the same beneficial ownership test to discretionary trusts. Special rules will also apply to widely held unit trusts so that ownership will be tested generally only where· there are abnormal transactions. These rules will help to minimise compliance costs for these types of trusts. Also, a listed widely held unit trust can apply the same business testif it fails the continuity of ownership test. Special tracing rules are provided to overcome difficulties in monitoring ownership of trust interests where certain entities are posed between the loss trust and the underlying beneficiaries. A special tracing rule applies for family trusts. These tests do not apply to family trusts, some superannuation funds, deceased estates within a reasonable administration period and unit trusts with unit holders exempt from income tax. These trusts are called excepted trusts in the legislation. Income injection schemes If a trust is involved in an income injection scheme to take advantage of deductions, the income injection test may prevent the trust from making full use of the deductions. Under these schemes, income is injected into trusts with losses or other deductions so that no tax is payable on the income. This test applies to all trusts other than excepted trusts. However, the test does apply to family trusts in some circumstances. Family trusts Family trusts (as defined) that distribute only to members of the family group will generally not be affected by the proposed measures. The income injection test will generally apply to family trusts only where income is injected from outside the family group. A trust will become a family trust for the purposes of the measures if it makes a family trust election. A consequence of making the election is that a special tax; called family trust distribution tax, is payable where a family trust gives income or capital to persons who are not members of the family group. This tax will be levied at the top marginal rate applying to individuals, plus Medicare levy. - family trust distribution tax is an anti-avoidance measure designed to ensure that· the tax benefit of a family trust's losses cannot be transferred to non-family members. The government hopes the tax will never need to be paid. Drafting of the legislation The trust loss measures have been drafted so as to fit into the new income tax law being developed as part of the tax law improvement project. The proposed rules are lengthy but internecessarily so. For example, there are many different categories of trusts. One way of dealing with trust losses would be to have a few standard rules' that apply to all trusts. This would result in the rules themselves being unfair in their impact. Instead, different rules have been applied to the different categories of trusts, depending on their nature. The result is that the size of the legislation increases, but this is matched by an increase in the fairness of treatment. The length of the provisions has also been greatly affected by the changes made by the government in response to representations from taxpayers and tax professionals. This has resulted in a trade-off between simplicity and equity. Revenue gain The estimated gain to revenue from the proposed changes is $90 million in 1995-96, $185 million in 1996-97, $160 million in 1997-98, $75 million in 1998-99, $20 million in 1999-2000 and $20 million in 2000-200l. I commend the bill to the House. I also present the explanatory memorandum to this bill, the Family Trust Distribution Tax (Primary Liability) Bill 1997, the Family Trust Distribution Tax (Secondary Liability) Bill 1997 and the Medicare Levy Consequential Amendment (Trust Loss) Bill 1997, and provide copies for the House. Debate (on motion by Mr Laurie Ferguson) adjourned. FAMILY TRUST DISTRmUTION TAX (PRIMARY LIABILITY) BILL 1997 First Reading Bill presented by Mr Miles, and read a first time. Second Reading

Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: SUPERANNUATION INDUSTRY
text: Braddon-Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister) (4.55 p.m.)-I move: That the bill be now read a second time. This bill will amend the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 (the SIS Act). The SIS Act regulates the conduct of trustees of superannuation entities to ensure the prudent management of superannuation moneys. The amendments to the SIS Act will improve the flexibility of legislative requirements relating to the nature and timing of elections by superannuation funds to be regulated under the SIS Act. To be eligible to receive concessional taxation treatment a superannuation fund must elect to be regulated under the SIS Act. There are a number of steps involved in making an election, including lodging a standard form with the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner and ensuring that the fund has a trustee that is a constitutional corporation that the sole or primary purpose of the fund is the provision of old-age pensions. There are strict time limits within which superannuation funds must elect to be regulated. A superannuation fund, established after the commencement of the SIS Act, must make an election to be regulated at the same time that it comes into existence or shortly after that day. A superannuation fund that was in existence prior to the commencement of the SIS Act must have elected to be regulated at the latest by the beginning of the fund's 1995-96 year of income. A superannuation fund that was in the process of winding up after the commencement of its 1994-95 year of income could continue. to receive concessional taxation treatment without making an election to be regulated, provided they were wound up by 1 July 1995. Failure to elect within these strict time limits or to wind up by the prescribed date may result in the members of the fund suffering losses due to the removal of taxation concessions. In addition, given that there are a number of steps involved in making an election, a fund may inadvertently lodge a defective election. In this case, a fund is ineligible for taxation concessions until after they have made a valid election. This is despite the fact that the fund may have complied with the SIS Act and regulations in all respects apart from lodging a valid election. The commissioner previously dealt with the shortcomings in the, election process by temporarily modifying the SIS Act under section 333. However, the commissioner's temporary modification power expired on 1 July 1996. This bill amends the SIS Act to permanently reinstate the administrative flexibility which was previously achieved through the temporary modification declarations. In particular, the amendments will confer a discretion on the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to extend the time within which the lodgement of an election must be made with the commissioner and enable trustees to rectify inadverteptly invalid elections. The amendments will also address or restrictive timing requirements for funds established prior to the SIS regime or funds who were in the process of winding up. By overcoming these technical rigidities, the amendments will enable superannuation funds who would otherwise be deprived of concessional taxation treatment in certain years to obtain access to such treatment, without compromising the security of members' benefits or fund compliance with the retirement income standards. It is intended that the amendments will take effect retrospectively from 1 July 1996 to ensure that the eligibility for taxation concessions for funds in the period prior to amendment is not jeopardised. I commend the bill to the House and provide the explanatory memorandum. Debate (on motion by Mr Laurie Ferguson adjourned. Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: COMMITTEES
text: -On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing CommitRAAF tee on Public Works, I present the 9th and 10th reports of the committee for 1997 tled Development of operational facilities at RAAF Base Learmonth, WA and Redevelopments ment of facilities for the 51st Battalion: Far North Queensland Regiment throughout Far North Queensland and the Torres Strait. Ordered that the reports be printed.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: COMMITTEES
text: by leave-The first report which I have tabled concerns the proposed Development of operational facilities at RAAF Base Learmonth, WA. The base is located North West Cape, WA, 1,235 kilometres north of Perth. The base covers an area approximately 2,550 hectares, situated on coastal plain between Cape Range and Exmouth Gulf. The nearest township, Exmouth, is 35 kilometres north of the base. RAAF Base Learmonth is a bare base, which forms part of a chain of defence airfields across northern Australia and is vital to 1997 the air defence of north-western Australia. The primary function of the base is to serve as a deployment base for combat aircraft in a contingency. The base was developed during the early 1970s and 1980s, and no further or major maintenance work has occurred since. The proposal examined by the committee involved the construction of: explosive ordnance loading aprons for fighter, strike and maritime patrol aircraftone apron will double as an explosive ordnance apron for transport aircraft; alert facilities for fighter aircraft; operational and technical support facilities; ordnance preparation facilities; a central emergency power station; rehabilitation of existing airfield pavements; airfield lighting equipment; and airfield lighting, engineering services and civil works. The estimated out-tum cost of the proposed work was $69 million. The committee has recommended that the work should proceed. After inspecting the base and conducting a public hearing at Exmouth, at which senior officers gave evidence, the committee concluded that there is a need for operational entifacilities at RAAF Base Learmonth to be upgraded to bring them into line with requiredesigned to enhance its capabilities for the deployment of fighter, strike and maritime aircraft in a safe and flexible manner. The proposal attracted interest from local government authorities who raised a number of issues relating to the use of the main runway for regular public transport aircraft as well as the siting of a number of facilities on within the civil aviation area. The downgrading of the runway's pavement of classification number by Defence was a the matter of concern, and the committee has recommended that Defence should enter into further discussions with the Shire of Exmouth about the practicalities of upgrading the pavement classification number of the runway. The project was the subject of an environmental impact assessment, and the report mentions a number of safeguards and precautions to be adopted during and after construction of the project. The second report I tabled covers the proposed Redevelopment of facilities for the 51st Battalion: Far North Queensland Regiment throughout Far North Queensland and the Torres Strait. By way of background, I should mention that this army unit, with its headquarters in Cairns, is a general reserve regional force surveillance unit. The role of the unit is to conduct reconnaisand sance and surveillance operations in the Cape York Peninsula, the gulf country and Torres Strait. Elements of the unit are widely dispersed over more than 20 locations throughout its area of operation, which covers 640,000 square kilometres. During any move towards conflict, FNQR would be a vital element of the first three layers of land defence. The unit's observation posts or reconnaissance patrols would be a vital source of initial strategic information which would provide early warning of any changing situation. Once other military forces are in place, the unit would operate in a zone well forward of any protected vital asset in Far North Queensland to provide a surveillance screen. Before addressing the specifics of the proposed work, the committee sought to establish if the unit has an assured future following the restructuring of the army. The committee was advised that this unit, the Pilbara Regiment and Norforce-all regional force surveillance units-have an assured future. The committee also sought to establish if the recruitment of reservists can be sustained. Again, Defence advised that a fundamental principle of recruitment is to recruit people from local communities who have specific knowledge and understanding of their areas and use this to support the surveillance capability. The history of the unit has been characterised by strong representation of members of local communities. At present, 40 per cent-200 members-of the unit are indigenous. It was also pointed out that the unit is currently manned to its full establishment. This is a good indication of the effectiveness of recruitment campaigns and a strong indicator of the support for the unit in Far North Queensland. The proposal involves the provision of facilities which will enhance the unit's ability to meet its operational commitments and will involve the redevelopment of some existing facilities and the provision of new facilities. This work will address current deficiencies such as non-functionality, size, non-compliance with building and occupational health safety standards and location. The proposal involves work at 22 locations. The committee concluded that based on the evidence the general lack of modem storage facilities and poor working conditions at headquarters, company headquarters and patrol locations are having an adverse impact on the ability of the unit to undertake assigned tasks. The proposed work encompasses: construction of a new facility on the Queerah Meatworks site in Cairns for the Regimental Headquarters, Administration Company, Alpha Company and 134 Regional Cadet Unit; new company facilities at Weipa; new platoon facilities at Atherton and Normanton; upgrading of existing platoon facilities at Innisfail and Bamaga; upgrading of the camp on Hom Island; upgrading of existing facilities at Normanby Street and the construction of new facilities at the naval fuel installation site on Thursday Island; and provision of secure storage for vehicles, boats and associated equipment at 14 patrol locations at Cooktown, Coen, Kowanyama, Aurukun, Pormpuraaw, Lockhart River, Cloncurry, Burketown, Mornington Island, Badu Island, Boigu Island, Yam Island, Darnley Island and York Island. The estimated out-turn cost of the proposed work is $22.5 million. The committee has re.commended that the work should proceed. The committee sought to establish if there will be' opportunities for the local construction industry to be involved in the project. The committee was advised that elements of the project will be packaged to maximise opportunities for involvement by locally based companies. Normal tendering processes will be followed. I commend both reports to the House. NA Second Reading Debate resumed.

Speaker: Mr WAKELIN
Title: NATIVE TITLE AMENDMENT BILL
text: I was making the point earlier that the pastoralists bf Grey have been intimidated and provoked by the legal advocates of native title; advocates who are not usually Aboriginal, are usually from Adelaide or Sydney and who have no interest in the productive use of pastoral land. Despite the bitter words of the Democrat senators in the other place, I am proud to include myself amongst the occupation of those people from the land. The pastoralists have been held to ransom. The legislation before us should clarify their position and protect their right to continue to make the soil of this land productive. There is no doubt that the new act and the changes go some way towards that. The miners of Grey have been caught in the inadequacies of the Native Title Act. The larger exploration and development companies have been warned off vast tracts of my electorate and millions of dollars worth of opportunity has disappeared. Perhaps the worse treatment has been meted out to the opal miners of Grey. These men and women and the communities they live in-places like Andamooka, Coober Pedy, Marla and Mintabie-have seen their means of earning a living frozen while the native title process creaks through its many stages. The South Australian authorities are unable to register a precious stones claim since the Wik High Court decision on Lambina pastoral. lease. It has generated such frustration that there has been talk of violence and shootings. I do not say these things lightly. They are a reminder of the frustration and the real dollar and cents cost of native title to people of modest means and the families and communities of my region. I spent much of the past 18 months putting forward the demands of the miners to the government. They have been put, I must say, civilly and reasonably, but they are, nevertheless, demands. I believe that with the passage of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 we 1997 will see a genuine improvement in the situation in the far north of my electorate. I understand that the same stance taken by the Commonwealth on the opal fields of New South Wales has been taken by the Commonwealth on this issue. This legislation should allow for the resolution of that frustration to the benefit of those people in my electorate. I come to the state of Aboriginal Australia. It would be absolutely wrong to suggest the reforms at hand are in some way a zero sum gain trade-off between Aborigines and other Australians as if improving the lot of farmers and miners is only made possible by the disadvantage of Aborigines. After all, more than one in 20 of my constituents is Aboriginal, compared with the electorate of the member for Banks (Mr Melham). I understand only one in 250 of his constituents is Aboriginal. I was able to visit the communities of Oak Valley, Ceduna and the ButtIingarra community at Whyalla not two weeks ago, in the company of the admirable senator the Hon. John Herron, Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Those constituents of mine do not want the feelgood romanticism of native title as it is represented by the ALP: they want running water, reasonable health, English literacy and employment opportunities. More and more, many Aboriginal people are beginning to understand the folly of welfare. They want opportunities, not handouts-an option that was clearly denied to far too many of them under the hypocritical Labor Party and an option that is attainable and is being attained under this government.
