Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: COMMITTEES
text: Hon. G.H. resolu- Adams}- Mr Speaker has received advice from the Chief National Party Whip that he has nominated Mr MCGauran to be a member be of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs in place of Mr Marek. NA AMENDMENT BILL 1997 First Reading Bill presented by Mr Fahey, and read a first time. Second Reading

Speaker: Mr FAHEY
Title: AIRPORTS LEGISLATION
text: I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The Airports Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 will facilitate the sale of the remaining federal airports by amending the Airports (Transitional) Act 1996, the Airports Act 1996 and the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986. On 1 July, the government executed the airport leases for the sale of the three phase which 1 airports-Melbourne, Brisbane and Perththe and the new owners took over running of I should those airports on 2 July 1997. It is a matter of public record that these sales represented a further major step forward a in the micro-economic reform agenda for the aviation sector. The sale of long-term leases do over three of our major airports enables of world's best practice to be brought to the management and operation of Australia's major airports and facilitates future capital to investment on a commercial basis. In this regard I had previously announced to that the new lessees of Brisbane, Melbourne and Perth airports are contractually committed to long-term development obligations-including substantial investment commitments core airport infrastructure-totalling over half a billion dollars over the next 10 years. Moreover, this investment is being made under a post-privatisation pricing which will see a real decline in aeronautical service charges over the next five years line with expected productivity improvements at these airports. Innovative management practices are al1 ready becoming evident with the announceal ment by the new Melbourne airport lessees that rebates of up to 50 per cent on aeronautiwhile cal charges are available to airlines, on applilocal cation, offering new services cent for those increasing frequency of existing services to and from Melbourne airport. Available on a decreasing scale for three provide years, the aim of this measure, with direct benefits to the travelling public, is to lower operating costs for start-up services and facilitate the growth of services considered viable in the longer term. The sale of the Sydney basin airports, which ar- Kingsford Smith, Hoxton Park, Bankstown, and Camden airports, will place only after completion of an environgovernment's mental assessment of options for the site the second Sydney airport and when the transferred government has effectively addressed noise issues relating to Sydney airport. Under this phase of the sales program, regular public transport (RPT) and al aviation (GA) airports are to be disposed of. It is proposed, as for phase 1 sales, the eight RPT airports at Adelaide, Alice Springs, Canberra, Coolangatta, Darwin, Hobart, Launceston and Townsville will be sold by long-term leasehold. Each lease would be 50 years with an option for an additional years. These sales can, of course, be undertakthose en under the existing provisions of the Airment ports (Transitional) Act 1996 and will be subject to the same Commonwealth regulatory controls that apply to the phase 1 airports provided for under the Airports Act 1996 and ment. associated regulations. On this occasion, however, the government wishes to have the flexibility of offering five GA airports at Archerfield, Essendon, J andakot, Moorabbin, and Parafield and two RPT airports at Mount Isa and Tennant Creek for freehold disposal. A freehold disposal of these airports, however, requires amendments to be made to the Airports regime (Transitional) Act 1996. Before I turn to the specifics of the proin posed amendments I would like to briefly elaborate on the reasons for the government's decision. While the airports included in phase were all airports of national and internationsignificance, the 15 airports in phase 2 are diverse. Some are major national airports others are principally of regional and significance, many with a large general and up to 30 per aviation base. Freehold sale of the general aviation airports and the smaller regional airports will greater opportunities for those airports to be integrated into the policy and planning frameworks of state and local authorities. The to sites would cease to be Commonwealth places and in the future the states and territories would assume the responsibility for planning and environment controls on the airports. This is logical and consistent with the take practice adopted under the previous aerodrome local ownership for program where some 230 local airports were under freehold title to local owners, a number of which are far larger in terms of revenue and aircraft traffic volumes than 10 some of those now being proposed to be five generdisposed of by freehold sale. Unlike the major airports, these airports are principally intrastate in their traffic and their non-aviation activities are more locally orientated, with a local community focus and . impact. A freehold sale of these airports for provides an opportunity for a strengthened 49 association with local community interestsbest placed to influence the developand operation of the airports in a manner conducive to fulfilling regional aspirations-without a Commonwealth overlay of as controls in the areas of planning and environExisting Commonwealth controls over safe operations, flight paths and aircraft noise the would be unaffected, but the question of how an airport's operations interlink and interact the with the community in which it is located would become a matter for the state or territory concerned. The Commonwealth will require, however, before an airport is sold . freehold that the relevant state government undertakes to ensure that state or territory local laws do not jeopardise continued airport operations and that the core airport site will be restricted to continued use as such. The Commonwealth wants to ensure that any airport sold freehold continues to be used as an airport, and is reserving the option of leasing any of these airports if the required assurances are not forthcoming from the relevant state or territory governments. As mentioned earlier, in order to allow for freehold sale of some of the phase 2 airports it is necessary to amend the Airports (Transitional) Act 1996. Those amendments are contained in schedule 1 to the bill and their main provisions are to facilitate the transfer of: land from the Federal Airports Corporation to the purchaser; the assets, liabilities, contracts and employees directly to the purchaser following the transfer of land; and the relevant staff at each of the airports to the purchaser. As for the phase 1 sales, it will be important that the jobs and entitlements of FAC staff at the airports to be sold will not be threatened by the disposal process. Therefore, whether the airports are to be leased or sold, staff and management will be transferred to the relevant airport entity immediately upon sale. Existing awards, enterprise agreements and contracts of employment will transmit to the new airport lessees or airport entity which will ensure that airport staff retain key terms and conditions of employment and entitlements to accrued benefits following their transfer. Following the transfer of staff, the terms and conditions of their employment, as contained in awards, enterprise agreements and contracts of employment, will be able to be varied only according to the terms of those agreements. There are two minor amendments to the stamp duty provisions in the Airports (Transitional) Act. Firstly, item 14 of the bill provides that, post sale, an entity is not liable stamp duty in respect of an instrument which was executed by the FAC before sale. This is an extension of the existing provisions under section 47 of the Airports (Transitional) Act in regard to a leasehold disposal. Its purpose is to ensure that an airport company does not and become liable to pay stamp duty in respect of an instrument to which the FAC was party and which was formerly exempt from duty. Any alteration to the instrument after sale which would attract stamp duty is not exempted by this provision. Secondly, item 15 of the bill is to extend the application of section 48 of the Airports (Transitional) Act to freehold entities. Section 48 ensures that stamp duty is payable in circumstances where the sale is affected by making of a declaration vesting the freehold in the airport entity. That section provides that, where stamp duty would have otherwise been payable, it is not exempt just because the transfer of the airport was affected by a ministerial declaration. There is one minor amendment, item 16, to the special income tax rules in the legislation and that is to extend to a freehold entity the power of the minister to make a declaration that the Income Tax Assessment Act applies to the FAC as though it had received payment for the disposal. This provision was used in the phase 1 sales to declare the value for tax purposes on the assets disposed by the FAC. As for the phase 1 sales, I am not proposing to utilise the determination provisions available in sections 49,50 and 51 of the Airports (Transitional) Act. For the purposes of their bids, prospective purchasers will be advised that they should value the airports on the basis of depreciation arrangements that are consistent with those outlined in the Treasurer's press release of 4 August 1997. This bill also contains amendments to the Airports Act 1996 which are proposed to streamline the regulatory regime for the leased federal airports. Schedule 2 of the bill covers four main areas, which I will deal with in turn. Firstly, section 5 of the Airports Act specifically defines a joint-user airport as Canberra, Darwin and Townsville. The Departto ment of Defence is currently considering the nature of its operations at Canberra Airport and the status of the airport may change in the future. The bill will amend section 5 of the Airports Act to enable a regulation to be made declaring that Canberra would no longer be a joint-user airport at such time as the Department of Defence chooses to cease operating at that airport. Secondly, section 33 of the Airports Act provides that an airport lessee company cannot enter into an airport management agreement with another person unless that person is both approved in writing by the minister and a qualified company within the meaning gi ven under the act. The Airports Act also provides that the minister cannot approve an airport management company if it breaches ownership restrictions under the act. Since the ownership restrictions in part 3 of the act already apply to an airport management company, the provision is unnecessary and so the bill provides for the requirement to be repealed. In its place the Minister for Transport and Regional Development will retain a simple power to determine by disallowable instrument whether a specific agreement is, or is not, an airport management agreement, and to not approve any agreements if there are concerns with them. The government wishes to take advantage of the benefits that foreign management expertise can bring to Australia's airports, but it remains important that any structures designed to circumvent the public policy objectives of the legislation can be denied. Thirdly, section 192 of the act provides that the minister may determine that each airport service provided at an airport will be a declared service for the purposes of the access regime set out in part lIlA of the Trade Practices Act 1974, except to the extent to which a service is the subject of an access undertaking given within 12 months after the airport is leased to the private sector. The bill proposes to give authority to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, the ACCC, to determine by disallowable instrument which activities at an airport fit within the relevant definition of an 'airport service' as a result of a determination by the minister. This amendment will ensure that the ACCC has the capacity to clarify situations where doubt arises about the scope of an 'airport service' that has been declared as a result of the minister's determination. Fourthly, subsection 242(1) of the Airports Act provides for applications to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for review of certain decisions made by the minister. Those decisions concern the approval of master plans, major development plans and environment strategies, including variations to master plans and major development plans and environment strategies. Under the act, the airport lessee is required to undertake wide public consultation prior to submitting draft master plans, major development plans and environment strategies to the minister for approval. The minister then either approves or refuses to approve the draft plans having regard to the matters to be considered as set out in the act, including: whether an airport development would assist airport users; how the airport and surrounding areas are affected; comments made by interested and affected parties as part of the public consultation process; and the environmental impact. These procedures are comprehensive and permit soundly based decisions to be made by the minister. The amendments ensure that . these decisions will be open to the scrutiny of the parliament. The minister is required to prepare and table in both houses of parliament a statement about these decisions, except to the extent that the commercial interests of a person would be substantially prejudiced. This will also bring these provisions into line with planning processes under state law. In addition to these four changes, the bill will insert a number of notes to existing sections of the Airports Act to clarify the way in which state law applies to airport activities. Schedule 3 of the bill extends the corporation's functions to include assisting in the sale of a federal airport by way of freehold disposal. This removes any ambiguity as to whether the corporation is empowered to assist in the disposal of its assets by this means and provides the board with an assurance that they are clearly operating within their responsibilities. The additional amendment to section 41 of the FAC Act clarifies that information obtained by the government under a ministerial direction given before the commencement of the amendment may be used after its commencement. This ensures that there is no perceived legal impediment to using the information in connection with any freehold sales. In conclusion, I would like to note that the government's airport sales process and the post-sale regulatory regime, which has been put in place, is making Australia a world leader in airport ownership and management. It provides the opportunity for the utilisation of private sector investment and expertise at Australia's airports. There is already a great deal of investor interest in the next tranche of airports, particularly in regional areas. The proposed measures outlined in this bill will maximise the opportunities for the development of regional airports and will provide a more streamlined and effective regulatory regime. Given the need to provide certainty to airport bidders and airport users, it is essential that this legislation be passed in the current sittings to meet the airport sales timetable. I commend the bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill. Debate (on motion by Dr Theophanous) adjourned. AUDITOR-GENERAL BILL 1996 Consideration of Senate Message Bill returned from the Senate with amendments. Ordered that the amendments be taken into consideration at forthwith. Senate's amendments(1) Clause 15, page 10 (after line 10), at the end of the clause, add: (3) For the purposes of this section, an Agency is taken not to include any persons who are employed or engaged under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984 and who are allocated to the Agency by regulations for the purposes of the definition of Agency in section 5 of the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1996. (2) Clause 37, page 23 (after line 17), after subclause (2), insert: . (2A) The Attorney-General must not issue a certificate in respect of information quested of the Auditor-General by a House of the Parliament, a committee of a House of the Parliament or a joint committee of both Houses of the Parliament. Motion (by Mr Fahey) agreed to: That amendment No.1 be agreed to.

Speaker: Mr FAHEY
Title: AIRPORTS LEGISLATION
text: I move: That Senate amendment No.2 be disagreed to. This amendment to clause 37, page 23, after subclause (2), seeks to include the words 'The Attorney-General must not issue a certificate in respect of information requested of the Auditor-General by a House of the Parliament, a committee of a House of the Parliament or a joint committee of both Houses of the Parliament'. The House of Representatives does not accept the amendment for two reasons. First, it is the proper role of the elected executive to bear responsibility for preventing damage to the public interest. It is the executive which will be held accountable to the parliament and ultimately to the electorate for its performance in that regard. Secondly, the framework of clause 37, as amended by the Senate, would provide scope for the Auditor-General to be drawn in as an unwitting party to the often political issues that members and senators may wish to pursue. I have some difficulties in understanding why the Labor Party came to the conclusion they did in the debate on this particular amendment in the Senate. I note that Senator Cook stated in his remarks on this amendment: ... it is possible to construct scenarios in which some matter may be being sought to be inquired of by a parliamentary committee which does border on the national interest or directly impinge on the national interest or some state secret. He went on to say that it is generally the case that parliamentary committees are made up in the majority by members of the government and, therefore, the government would act to protect the national interest, to protect national interest issues. I think that clearly indicates what this particular section is all about as it restands in the bill before it was amended by the Senate and it perhaps indicates what the Senate had in mind in seeking to amend it. Clause 37 of the bill is specifically relevant to those areas which apply to national security. I would have thought that all members of this House would appreciate that it should not be left open for the Auditor-General to be interfered with in his decisions on matters of national security and national interest or, for that matter, for it to be left in the hands of a committee of the parliament to seek information that would go into the public arena in a way that could do great damage to Australia's standing on an international basis or otherwise. I believe that in the drafting of the bill, it was originally passed by this House, the government had this in mind, and I had many discussions on the need to ensure, firstly, that there was an unfettered power there for the Auditor-General as an officer of the parliament entrenched by these bills and, secondly, that the Auditor-General was not embroiled in political controversy brought about by some decision of a committee whereby the majority on that committee were not members of the executive government of the day. Clause 37 replicates a framework which has been in operation in the Audit Act 1901 for almost 20 years. The scope for intervention by the Attorney-General to prevent disclosure of particular kinds of information on public interest grounds is not extensive. In view of discussions I had on that very point, it was considered appropriate that the Attorney General, again in the national interest, should give a certificate to the Auditor-General as to why information should be withheld by the Auditor-General. Again, that is to ensure that the maximum amount of accountability was there and at the same time we did not interfere with the national interest and particularly, as I say, the national security. There are provisions to prevent information being forthcoming that might prejudice matters before a court. Of course, this just entrenches the sub judice rule. One can appreciate the fact that that can do untold damage to many people in the community if a committee of the parliament could take advantage of information that had been brought to its attention to circumvent what should surely be in the interests of justice in this country of ours. The reasons listed in clause 37(2) for the Attorney-General to issue the certificate relate only to matters of genuine importance and significance. (Extension of time granted) If one were to imagine a worse case scenario that could occur under the Senate amendment it is possible to see how damage could be caused to Australia's national or international security and how the integrity of the Commonwealth's position could be undermined in ways that caused genuine damage to as Australia, Accordingly, the House of Representatives believes that it is not worth the risk to accept the Senate amendment. The House of Representatives believes that the framework in clause 37, unamended, has been proven to operate in a realistic and sensible way, having been used only once for reasons of national security. Moreover, clause 37 as drafted provides an added measure of accountability on the executive in that it compels the Auditor-General to report any intervention by the executive and the reasons for it.. The House of Representatives believes that the framework provided for in clause 37 is sound and therefore disagrees with the Senate amendment.

Speaker: Mr KELVIN THOMSON
Title: AIRPORTS LEGISLATION
text: The only point of difference between the opposition and the government on this whole package of legislation relates to clause 37. The legislative package itself dates back to 1989 and the work of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. It lapsed in previous years, principally because of an obstructive opposition at the time. As the Labor opposition, we support the legislative package. It is largely our creation. Whilst the former opposition delayed the package literally for years, in this parliament we have facilitated quick passage and intend to continue doing so. The Commonwealth needs modern financial systems in legislation and this package will deliver that. However, there is one matter of contention, and that relates to the power of the executive to gag the Auditor-General. Labor accepts that in some situations the national interest will be served by the nondisclosure of some information-for example, sensitive Defence or foreign relations information. We agree with that position and, accordingly, support the right of the Attorney General to issue a certificate under clause 37 in appropriate circumstances. I note that this power currently exists and apparently has been used only once over the last 20 years or so. I believe it was during time of the Fraser government. However, the amendment which the Senate agreed to is designed to stop potential abuse of what is by any yardstick a very wide power given to the Attorney-General. The amendment of the Senate, whilst maintaining the general power of the Attorney, qualifies it in one important respect-namely, that the Attorney cannot issue a certificate to silence the Auditor General about an issue on which the parliament, or a committee of the parliament, has requested information. Just as the reserve power for the Attorney is important, so too is a legislative guarantee against the abuse of that power. Indeed, the unfortunate recent episode where we saw the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) seeking to gag the Law Reform Commission is a striking and contemporary illustration of the need for this kind of protection. We have had the Law Reform Commission seeking to make a submission concerning the native title legislation. We have had clear evidence that the Attorney-General has interfered with that process. His defences have been that this issue is outside the charter of the Law Reform Commission, yet the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister, Nick Minchin, has sought himself the views of the Law Reform Commission on the native title and Wik legislation. The Law Reform Commission routinely comments on inquiries by parliamentary committees. Indeed, the Attorney-General had to own up this afternoon to having tabled an annual report which gave a number of examples of that process in action. The Attorney General had not even bothered to read it, according to his response this afternoon. The real reason for that attempt by the Attorney General at suppression was political-the embarrassment of the government at the Law Reform Commission's findings that the government's proposed native title legislation may be unconstitutional,may involve massive taxpayer compensation, may be in breach of this nation's international obligations .. It was never a problem before that the Law Reform Commission made submissions to parliamentary committees and other bodies. the So for this government, when the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) attacks Aborigines, that is free speech and ought to be celebrated but, when the Law Reform Commission wants to tell the government some home truths and tries to support Aborigines, that material ought to be suppressed and never see the light of day. In my view, this is not the kind of Attorney-General whom we would want to see having the kind of unlimited power which the government is seeking to provide for with its provision. It is clearly a political use of the Attorney-General's power to suppress what he has been engaging in. The matter was reported to the office of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) by the Chief of Staff to the Attorney-General, Mr Hugh Funder. He spoke with the principal private secretary to the Prime Minister, Tony Nutt, to let him know what was going on. This was all about high politics, not some appropriate and genuine concern on the part of the Attorney-General about the Law Reform Commission exceeding its powers. The Labor opposition will support the Senate amendment. We will be supporting it again in the Senate. We believe it represents an appropriate safeguard. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: AIRPORTS LEGISLATION
text: In speaking to the Senate's amendment No.2, I have a couple of questions I would like to ask the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) on the matter. I am interested to know exactly in the terms of this particular amendment of the Senate whether it in fact would make the Auditor-General more answerable to the parliament, as was, in my view, the understanding of the role of the Auditor-General. I refer to House of Representatives Practice, which specifically says: The Audit Act provides that reports of the Auditor General must be forwarded to the Speaker for presentation to the House, and this is illustrative of the position of the Auditor-General as a person responsible to Parliament, rather than to Governarena. ment. I would have thought that the Democrats' amendment in the Senate is in fact enhancing the relationship between the Auditor-General and the parliament rather than perhaps reinforcing the relationship of the Auditor General as a creature of or answerable to the executive. I would be interested in his response to that.

Speaker: Mr FAHEY
Title: AIRPORTS LEGISLATION
text: Very briefly, in response to the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing), I can indicate that, if the honourable member for Moore looks at section 37 and the subsections there in terms of the provisions that are applicable, the circumstances in which the Attorney-General can in fact issue a certificate is very clear. That certificate can only be issued by the Attorney General and, of course, reported on by the Attorney-General to the parliament where it is in the public interest to do so. This is about a protection of areas. I would have thought that the honourable member for Moore would understand more than anyone else that information will be forthcoming from committees of this parliament on a regular basis where the government is not in the majority, particularly in another place, is an opportunity given for base political purposes. I seek to avoid the national interest being affected by such decisions that are taken for base political purposes. I certainly would want to avoid any risk being put to national security. That is the basis for the clause as drafted. That right, that protection, is taken away by the amendment moved by the Democrats in the Senate. There are very limited opportunities for the Attorney-General to issue such a certificate. I have indicated that in the past 20 years it has occurred on one occasion. I would have thought that the honourable member for Moore could imagine many situations in any single week where information is in the national interest. Dare I say it, events in New Guinea and Bougainville earlier this year might have been fairly relevant, but it would not have been in this government's interest for that sort of information to be in the public It is narrow. It is clearly in the public interest to have that there, and the amendment would destroy that protection which I believe is vitally important for this nation's future.

Speaker: Mr KELVIN THOMSON
Title: AIRPORTS LEGISLATION
text: Let me repeat: it is not the opposition's view that it is appropriate for a power of this kind to be given to the Attorney-General without any qualification which has regard to the parliament. We believe this does raise separation of powers issues involving the primacy and supremacy of parliament. We note that part of this bill is to make the Auditor-General an officer of the parliament and, against that background, we think it is appropriate that parliament should have some fetter on the powers of the Auditor-General. I emphasise that, for the Auditor-General to be truly independent, the Auditor-General is in a position to carry out his or her functions in the way that he or she sees fit. I do not think what is being proposed by the Senate gives rise to the prospect of parliamentary committees dictating to the Auditor-General in any shape or form. I would make the point that, while the opposition does not propose to divide on the bill in the House again, and we are keen that it has an appropriate passage, we do intend to if there pursue this issue in the Senate. Question resolved in the affirmative. Committee of Reasons Motion (by Mr Fahey) agreed to: That Mr Reid, Mr Andrew and the mover be appointed a committee to draw up reasons for the House of Representatives disagreeing to amendment No.2 of the Senate.

Speaker: Mr FAHEY
Title: AIRPORTS LEGISLATION
text: On behalf of the committee appointed to draw up reasons for the House disagreeing to amendment No.2 of the Senate, I present the reasons which are being circulated to honourable members. The reasons read as followsSenate Amendment Number 2 The amendment proposes clause 37, page 23 after subclause (2) be supplemented to include that the Attorney-General must not issue a certificate in respect of information requested of the Auditor General by a House of the Parliament, a committee of a House of the Parliament or a joint committee of both Houses of the Parliament. The House of Representatives does not accept the amendment for two reasons. First, it is the proper role of the elected Executive to bear responsibility for preventing damage to the public interest - and it is the Executive which will be held accountable by the Parliament and, ultimately, the electorate for its performance in that regard. Secondly, the framework of clause 37, as amended by the Senate, would provide scope for the Auditor-General to be drawn in as an unwitting party to the, often, political issues that Members and Senators may wish to pursue. Clause 37 replicates a framework that has been in operation in the Audit Act 1901 for almost 20 years. The scope for intervention by the Attorney General to prevent disclosure of particular kinds of information on public interest grounds is not extensive. The reasons listed in Clause 37(2) for the Attorney-General to issue a certificate relate only to matters of genuine importance and significance. If one were to imagine a worse case scenario that could occur under the Senate amendment, it is possible to see how damage could be caused to Australia's national or international security and how the integrity of the Commonwealth's position could be undermined in ways that caused genuine damage to Australia. Accordingly, the House of Representatives believes that it in not worth the risk to accept the Senate amendment. The House of Representatives believes that the framework in Clause 37, unamended, has been pr:oven to operate in a realistic and sensible way, having been used only once, for reasons of national security. Moreover, Clause 37,.as drafted, provides an added measure of accountability on the Executive in that it compels the Auditor-General to report any intervention by the Executive and the reasons for it. The House of Representatives believes that the framework provided for in clause 37 is sound and therefore disagrees with the Senate amendment. Motion (by Mr Fahey) agreed: That the committee's reasons be adopted. NA ACCOUNTABILITY BILL 1996 Consideration of Senate Message Bill returned from the Senate with an amendment. Ordered that the amendment be taken into consideration forthwith. Speaker: Mr TAYLOR
Title: PRIVILEGE
text: Groom) (7.28 p.m.)Earlier today I received a letter from a man in Nambour, Queensland, in the electorate of Fairfax. Over the last couple of days, both in this place and in the Main Committee, we have been debating quite extensively the firearm reforms. I want to take the opportunity to congratulate everybody concerned with I do not want to take up too much of the time of the House doing that, but I cannot let the opportunity go by without congratulating the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), the premiers, the chief ministers and indeed· the Australian people. That effort involved a lot of rea'sonable people. . This letter that I have received reflects the view of a minority group of unreasonable people. I am very pleased that the honourable member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) is in the chamber. She should, I suggest, listen to this because these are some of the so-called supporters of what her One Nation party stands for. I would like to read to the House what this letter said. I will only read part of it, but it is the salient part. It is headed 'Treason Trials', and it says: I have been instructed to advise you sir, that your name is in the eighth batch of one hundred (100) alleged political, judicial, administrative, media and financial criminals to be charged, tried, and where found guilty, HUNG for treason, crimes against the constitution, crimes against the Bill Of Rights 1688 ... and crimes against humanity et. al. It goes on: As you would be, or should be well aware by now, this will be your last term in office. After that to, see section 18B the Treason Trials. I have provided a copy of this letter in accordance with standing orders to the clerk. It is signed by Mr Norm Segal of Nambour, Queensland. This gentleman, if that is the right terminology, and one or two others of the same ilk-the MCNivens, the Dawnings, the Tony Pitts-who are involved in the member for Oxley's organisation and the publication of such outlandish magazines as Lock, Stock and Barrel are the sorts of people who are writing to us. Like a lot of politicians, I have to have a thick skin. I do not want to make anybody a martyr in this matter, but I think it is about time we exposed some of these people for what they are. They are a very vociferous minority group in our community, and I think it is about time we exposed them for what they are. Adjournment proposed and negatived.

Speaker: Mr TAYLOR
Title: PRIVILEGE
text: MrSpeaker, I was raising a matter of privilege and was referring to some of these people and the writer of this particular letter that I received. Others may have received such a letter; I do not know. I can only act as an individual. Some of these people are absolute loony tunes and fringe dwellers, and we should expose them just as that. We listen to what they have to say, but I think it is about time we drew the line and did something about it. A lot of these people are involved with the member for Oxley's organisation and with the organisation of the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). Both members want to hide behind some of these people. If I were the member for Oxley, I would be looking over my shoulder at these people. I do not know that you understand the way you are being manipulated by these minority groups, and that was reflected in your speech earlier in the day in this place on native title. You talk about one nation conspiracy theories and new world orders. That is quite ridiculous. You are being driven by some of these vociferous minority groups. It is about time you grew up and knew exactly what was happening. Mr Speaker, I would like to raise this letter as a matter of privilege. Before you came in, I provided a copy of this letter to the clerk and I seek your guidance. As I said before, nobody wants to make anybody a martyr. But I think it is about time that this particular gentleman really understood what parliamentary privilege is all about. I seek your guidance and your ruling understanding orders 95 to 97 A.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PRIVILEGE
text: I thank the honourable member for Groom. You raise some very interesting questions. I will take the matter on notice and report back further. NA Motion (by Mr Miles) proposed: That the House do now adjourn. Unemployment

Speaker: Mr SAWFORD
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: A couple of weeks ago Channel 9 and News Limited, in conjunction with the CES, ran a Jobs for Australia campaign. They should be commended for that, as should the employers of Australia that offered the 20,000 jobs. However, the stark reality is that these 20,000 jobs, even if they all eventuated, would do nothing of a fundamental nature to change the chronic and endemic unemployment that stagnates the economies of Australia and the developed world. Corporations and business will not deliver full employment. Why would they? They do not have the long-term responsibility for stability and families that governments can have. Governments need to lead. Governments need to set the policy environment in order to seek the cooperation of corporations, business and labour unions. Yet governments around the world, including the Howard government, are moving away from the commitments and social contracts they have had with ordinary workers post-World War II. In an article in Foreign Affairs volume 75 No.3, Ethan Kapstein, Director of Studies at the Council on Foreign Relations in the United States, made a number of points about globalisation and its impact on employment: The global economy is leaving millions of disaffected workers in its train . . . Just when working people most need the nationstate as a buffer from the world economy it is abandoning them . . . For generations students were taught that increasing trade and investment, coupled with technological change, would drive national productivity and create wealth. Yet over the past decade despite a continuing booming international trade and finance, productivity has faltered and inequality in the United States and unemployment in Europe has worsened ... In globalisation's previous incarnation governments had done little to protect working people from its malign effects, and their mistakes exacted a in revolutions and war. Kapstein argues that governments are trying to break their postwar deal with workers expansionary while maintaining their commitment to an open economy. Governments cannot have it both ways and, instead, the policy focus should be on negotiating a package that helps workers adjust to ongoing changes. Kapstein says: If the concern is incoming inequality, policies should be adopted to close the income gap. If concern is unemployment more jobs created. In developing positive solutions however, it is important to recognise that declining rates of economic growth caused largely by a drop off productivity are hurting all workers. Governments from the mid-1980s until now have adopted policies deemed sustainable credible by financial markets. These policies have privileged stability over employment, according to Kapstein. Restrictive economic policies, reduced deficits, reduced spending, reduced taxes and-the most exalted deitylow inflation have favoured financial interests at the expense of workers. Politicians and public officials who adopt these restrictive measures are labelled 'responsible' by editoriing alists, and the markets reward their behaviour sustaining the ideology. Kapstein says that governments essentially have four choices to assist their unskilled and semi-skilled work force. The first choiCe protectionism, which is a remedy worse than the disease. The second is education and training, and that is perhaps the only policy intervention that meets with universal approval. Democratic societies should be financed. It makes for good politics and good economwas ics. But, in the near term, it cannot provide the solution to the structural problems of employment and inequality. The third approach is to increase the number of jobs through public works programs and employment subsidies to the private sector. Public job creation is relatively cient and socially productive-since it prosmall vides younger workers with needed job experience-and it can be done fairly quickly. The fourth policy choice is tax reform, perhaps eliminating income taxes altogether for a large number of the working poor while price making them sharply more progressive up the income ladder. One of the main arguments against an strategy is that it is inflationary. Certainly, inflation is unwelcome, but so is unemployment, which in this country is more like 13 to 15 per cent and much higher than the admitted rate of almost nine per cent. Kapstein acknowledges that restrictive policies may have been necessary when first conceived in the 1980s to bring stability to the financial markets, but they have failed too should be many people for too long. The challenge to all governments is clear: in restore growth and opportunity. Unfortunately, in this country of Australia that we all represent, realisation of the message that Ethan or Kapstein brings-who was also one of the proponents of globalisation in a former lifetotally escapes the Howard government. Telstra: Phonecard Vending Machines

Speaker: Mr BILSON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Dunkley) (7.37 p.m.}-Two Dunkley small businessmen have lost substantial sums of money· investing in a phonecard vending machine business that had the backof Telstra. Mr Gerhard Schulz and Mr Ted Hancock each lost $16,000 by investing in a business opportunity in 1993 promoted by General Vending (Australia) Pty Ltd, an associated company to Del-Marina Pty Ltd, is which shared a common director, Mr Rod Montague Laski of Prahran East, Victoria. Mr Laski's companies claimed in advertisements published in the Age in early 1993 a 'staggering 40 per cent minimum guaranteed return on your investment'. This same claim reiterated in subsequent correspondence between Mr Laski and my constituents. The written guarantee promised that only sites that took revenue of at least $340 per week per machine would be selected. Naively but not unnaturally, as the associated company, DelMarina Pty Ltd, had a distribution agreement effiwith Telstra, they were among at least 19 investors who believed these claims and purchased phonecard vending machines subsequently deployed at various retail outlets and around Melbourne and Sydney. Companies like Telstra and those associated with it have an obligation to behave ethically. On 14 October 1994 after the Casualties of Telecom saga with one compensation payment of $2.3 million, Telstra CEO, Mr Blount, said in large advertisements that Telstra embraced 'an approach based on honesty and integrity ... values fundamental to the way we do business'. My constituents assumed Telstra would have conducted a full study on Del-Marina Pty Ltd in view of their distribution agreement and relationship. Telstra suggested to potential investors Del-Marina would be the sole source of new phonecard distribution outlets. The Telstra phonecard brand name was used in advertiseeight ments. My constituents assert that Telstra never enforced its agreement with Del-Marina which insisted investors read the distribution agreement, only provided to Mr Schulz four months after he had made his investment. In July 1993 Telstra stated that General Vending Pty Ltd was the trading arm of Del-Marina Melbourne. and that General Vending (Australia) Pty Ltd was now registered as a company. By September 1993 my constituents knew that the claimed return on investment was mythical. Mr Schulz complained to the Trade Practices Commission which advised that, with their limited resources, the matter did involve widespread consumer detriment therefore would not be pursued. Despite Marina receiving complaints in mid-1992, Telstra failed to terminate General Vending's contract until 28 October 1993. Telstra knew of Mr Laski from previous dealings and had ously terminated a contract with him. This surprising reaffirmation of faith in Mr Laski by Telstra allowed General Vending to win around $1 million in revenue. Telstra benefitSecurities ed from more phonecard sales and a reduction in vandalism at public phone boxes. While Telstra offered to allow affected investors to supply phonecards sites, this was impractical because a tiny number of people were supplying large areas by this time in view of the low returns from each machine. By October 1994 Telstra was indicating to Mr Schulz's solicitors that might consider funding an action against Laski, but nothing came of efforts to get Telstra to fund a class action against Mr Laski or the companies, justified by' Telstra on basis that General Vending was pending company deregistration. This was despite Telstra engaging solicitors to prepare a class action. Eventually, in April 1995, Telstra offered Mr Schulz $1,600 to use as he saw fit. Mr Rodney Laski did not cease as a director of General Vending (Australia) Pty Ltd until 24 April 1996 but had ceased his directorship with Del-Marina Pty Ltd on 2 February 1993. These vending machines were sold by General that Vending for up to $1,800 each. Australian Securities Commission records show Mr Laski to be currently the director of other companies including Miami Coin International Pty Ltd. Mr Laski's companies have previously been located in the CadburySchweppes building at Level 10, 636 St Kilda Road, Melbourne. About six months ago, he did a 'midnight flit' from this building. He now trades at Level 1, 391 St Kilda Road, Mrs Robyn Peet of Dingley, Victoria, obtained judgment against General Vending Pty Ltd, Del-Marina Pty Ltd and Conmorre Pty Ltd for $71,800 in February 1996. Mrs Peet had been pregnant at the time she originally invested $63,000. Mr Donald Smith not obtained a judgment in the county court for and $70,000 in November 1995 against Deland Mr Laski. In July this year Telstra wrote to Mr Schulz saying that they were unwilling to reopen their previous goodwill offer or renegotiate. Mr Laski is now offering previso-called 'club cards' for phone sex. I call upon Telstra to put aside its indifference and to again consider doing what it can to assist these investors. The Australian Commission should formally consider whether Mr Laski is a fit and proper person to hold Australian company directorship under section 230 of the Corporations to existing Law. Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: This evening to I would like return to they one of my favourite and recurring themesMr namely, the hopelessness of the Western Australian parliamentary Liberal team. We know that my view of their hopelessness is the shared by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) because there is not one Western Australian Liberal in the cabinet. We know that, in all of the speculation this week, about who is going to come and who is going to go, the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) and the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) are much more likely to go out than they are to go up. We have seen headlines in recent times such as 'PM takes Moylan to task', 'Time may soon be up for minister' and 'Moylan too ill to fend off her critics'. So we know that the Minister for Family Services is on a short fuse. We also know, as the member for Moore (Mr Filing) alluded to today in question time Senator Campbell from Western Australia is gunning for her as well. He is after her spot. We also know that the Premier of Western Australia, Mr Court, has no confidence in either the Attorney-General or the Minister for Family Services. Yesterday he refused to be drawn on either of them, either their current performance or their future. What do we know about the Attorney General? We know that the Prime Minister has no confidence in him because as an Attorney-General he is not in cabinet. Now we discover that the Premier of Western Australia has no confidence in him either. An article in the West Australian of 1 October headed 'WA cabinet call' says: Premier Richard Court put in a bid yesterday for a WA Cabinet minister in the Howard Government's ministerial reshuffle . . . Mr Court said it was ludicrous that WA was not represented in Cabinet . . . He refused to comment on speculation that WA's Judi Moylan would be dumped ... Mr Court singled out senators Chris Ellison and Ian Campbell as talented MPs who would make good Cabinet ministers. That is picked up in the Australian, whose headline reads 'Premier at odds with PM over make-up of cabinet'. He again calls on Senators Ellison and Campbell to be made cabinet ministers. We know the Prime Minister has no confidence in the Attorney-General. Now we know the Premier has no confidence in him. Daryl would have gone by the end of the week, but now that he has been caught out over the Australian Law Reform Commission, the Prime Minister is handcuffed to him and he cannot take him out. Who is one West Australian Liberal who the Prime Minister would like to promote? His good friend, the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher). An article in the West Australian of 29 August headed 'Rocher to bide time' says: Prime Minister John Howard is missing one of his most loyal lieutenants. He wants his long-time friend and political ally Allan Rocher to return to the Liberal Party. It is understood he wants to meet privately with Mr Rocher-possibly as early as next week-to discuss future options, including a way of facilitating his comeback. The scheduled meeting for Wednesday of this week was cancelled because of other matters. But an article in the Sunday Times on 28 September headed 'PM backs return by WA's Rocher' states: Prime Minister John Howard has privately backed moves to bring a former Liberal and now independent MP, Allan Rocher, back into the Government. But the move is believed to have run into opposition in WA, with one Liberal warning it would be "World War ill" if it went ahead. Liberal Party president Tony Staley is understood to have approached the WA Liberal Party in July offering a deal to bring Mr Rocher into the party. The deal was that a WA minister would go into the Cabinet if the party agreed to re-endorse Mr Rocher for the seat of Curtin. "Staley would not have done that off his own bat," one Liberal source said. "Tony was the emissary for Allan's good friend-the Prime Minister." So we can have a WA cabinet minister from the Liberal Party if Allan is back in the show! Why would Premier Court want to promote Senator Campbell? Because. we know that there is real trouble for Liberal senators in preselections coming up in October and November. The West Australian on 19 September states there is 'serious jockeying for position by incumbents Sue Knowles and Ian Campbell' for the Senate spot. Why do we know that Senator Campbell is in trouble? Because he - as l-t down the WA resources and prospectmg mdustry over section 23(pa), as the parliamentary secretary at the table well knows. So, why would Premier Court want to support someone who is letting down Western Australia so badly? Because they are both No-l. Crichton-Browne kids-they grew up in polItIcs at the feet of Noel Crichton-Browne. There is another Noel Crichton-Browne kidSenator Lightfoot-who is prepared to stand up for Western Australia. Today I received in my office a letter dated 26 September from Senator Lightfoot, senator for Western Australia. It is addressed to Senator Ian Campbell, senator for Western Australia, Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, and it says: ....it is still my unchangeable position, that the sectIOn 23 (pa) should stay intacto within the present act. There are no possible suggested amendments that could replace that section that will be either revenue positive, or recreat- the incentive for prospectors to add to the Nation's mineral reserves wealth. May I also add, that with the combination of Native Title, Diesel Fuel Rebate capping, the removal of 23(pa), the Western Australia Government's soon to be implemented Gold Royalty, a worrying number of miners are on their fiscal knees: A- the Nation's biggest dollar earner, I am becommg mcreasingly uncomfortable with my Government's indifferent, even irresponsible attitude to the mining industry. So let us hope, for the mineral and resources industries in WA, that Senator Campbell's disloyalty to the industry is not rewarded by a promotion into the cabinet over the Attorney-General and over the Minister for Family Services. Senator Campbell does not deserve to be promoted on the basis that he has monstrously and massively let down the Western Australia mineral resources and prospecting industries. Kingscliff High School

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Richmond) (7.48 p.m.}-I rise tonight to speak about a school in the Richmond electorate-Kingscliff High School. This is a very progressive school which has oyer 1,150 students. The principal, Milton SImmons, has seen the school grow from 400 students from when he became the first principal of the school in 1986. One of the reasons for the success of the school is its initiative in reaching out to feeder schools. It has become a standard feature.of the high school that students spend some tIme at feeder primary schools telling the pupils what the high school children are doing, especially in the environmental field. As - iltonputs it, it is 'kids teaching kids', and It has been very effective. They have been very proactive in environmental work and I fully support and encourage the principal, Milton Simmons, and a number of very professional and dedicated teachers. At the school they have the Kingscliff Enviro Club and membership is about one-third of the whole school from all age brack-ts. Their involvement with landcare projects mcludes dune regeneration work, reafforestation work at Kingscliff and river care. They won the NSW Landcare award in 1996, they were finalists for the Telstra Landcare Education Award in 1996, they won the Banksia Environmental Award in 1996, they were entrants in the NSW Landcare award this year and they are also now putting together a proposal for the United Nations Environment Programme Environmental Youth Forum for South Pacific and Asian nations. There are three students in particular who attended the Australian Youth Forum at the Old Parliament House in Canberra whom I would like to mention: Lara Maciuk, Tammy MCDonald and Kim Meighan. Several very positive decisions came out of the conference and particularly the proposal for a youth congress which would talk directly to government. These three and others from the Kingscliff High School are actively working to bring people in the Tweed Valley into environmental programs. They participate in the activities of the local Tweed Valley Family and Youth Support Service-run by David Neely who is doing a very good job as a youth officer-and set up a Tweed Coast Youth Council which meets every month at the Kingscliff High School. They are discussing not just environment issues but public transport, other activities and facilities for young people. Lara Maciuk, a 16-year-old year 11 student was also nominated for the 1998 Young Australian of the Year Award for her environmental and youth work. This is the second year running she has been nominated for the award. She is a key member of the Kingscliff Enviro Club which, as I mentioned, were finalists in the NSW Landcare awards to be announced in November. She has represented Australia at the United Nations Youth Forum. There are some other individuals, too, in electorate that I should mention. Christopher Teitzel of Mount St Patrick's School in form Murwillumbah has also been nominated for award for a CD, Saving the Environment, which he produced and which was sponsored by the Total Catchment Management of the name but a few. Tweed Valley. Melinda Schubert has been doing a CPA and has been nominated for a career achievement award. The school's rugby union team won a country schools' competition-the Yeates Shield-in the electorate of Calare on 21 September. The good old Kingscliff school from the north coast stole the match away from Kinross Wolaroi, scoring twice in the last three minutes-almost as good as the rugby league game last week-3l note that the son of the member for Calare (Mr Andren) was also playing in the local team but, unfortunately, the boys from the north coast beat them. The school is also a leader in the performing arts. They have participated over the last six to seven years in the Coca Cola Schools Spectacular held at the Sydney Entertainment Centre which I am sure many of my Melin bourne colleagues would know quite well. ty Also, many of the students are involved in the drama and entertainment fields. In other areas of sporting achievements, this year Kingscliff High School won the secondary schools swimming titles. They won the girls' sectionMr Hockey-Good!

Speaker: Ms HANSON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: While it is indeed lamentable that the Australian music industry is foreign owned and controlled, there are many Australian artists who record with these companies and the industry supports thousands of Australian jobs. As free trade and the so-called level playing field are the destroying 'our manufacturing and farming sectors, free trade in our music industry in the of parallel importing will very likely do an serious damage to the whole music industry and everyone it supports: production people, workers, and nearly 2000 music retailers-to The best case scenario for price reductions under the government's plan on new releases is only about $2 to $3 per CD. This minor saving would hardly seem worth the potential cost to the industry and Australian jobs. While reducing the cost of consumer goods is a worthy cause, many would say the human price is too high. A recent poll found that 85 per cent of Australians would pay a little more to save jobs and therefore have a better to 29. I and more secure society. There is also no guarantee that the price of CDs will fall. Considering that the deregulation of the banking sector has resulted in the highest bank charges-and the poorest service ever-just as with banking, the supposed savings may not even be passed on to the consumer. We must also ask if this is just the first step a broader breakdown of intellectual properrights in Australia-a situation that puts at risk all industries that depend on copyright, patent or trademark protection. We should be wary of this government's intentions for the music industry. If it is the first step to a broader approach including patents and the like, we will all yet again feel the darkness of the shadow of our old enemy, the United Nations and its Lima declaration. If the coalition is fair dinkum about reducthe price of CDs, as it promised at the last election, then it should do so by changing the High inefficient sales tax regime which slugs am business and consumers. Copyrights, like that. tariffs, protect Australian jobs and local industries, and jobs must be our No. 1 priority. More jobs will lead to a more secure society with less crime, less substance abuse, less family breakdown and less suicide. Jobs in Australia will be created only by applying the principles of economic nationalism, while those of free trade will keep our country in a downward spiral. Governments have a lot to learn about ordinary Australians and what they are going through. I fear that these are lessons neither Liberal or Labor will ever learn.

Speaker: Mr HOCKEY
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: On 30 July this year I conducted a youth forum on drugs at North Sydney Leagues Club. Students from nearly 21 local secondary schools as well as some prominent local guest speakers came along, including Alice Wood, who, at the age of 17, lost her 15-year-old sister, Anna, after she took an ecstasy tablet at a dance party, and Billy Moore, an Australian representative in rugby league who plays football for the local North Sydney Bears. The discussion on this vital issue was forthright. I learnt from students that drugs such as marijuana and ecstasy are more common and accessible in our local schools than even I previously believed. Gone are the stereotypical drug pushers who lurk in public toilets and lane ways waiting for kids to finish school for the day. Now the dealers are students in the schools and, despite what older people may think, they no longer have to widely ply their trade. Students these days have more knowledge about where to get drugs than they do about what drugs actually contain and what they can actually do. Some students at the forum spoke of peers who tum up to school stoned; others told of the frankness and openness with which marijuana use in particular is spoken about at school. Still others discussed the fairly sophisthat ticated way in which credit for drug purchases is provided. As our discussions continued, I was amazed at how undisturbed these students appeared to be about the presence of illegal drugs in their lives, both at school and at parties. The stereotypical North Shore student shows no real intrigue and is not unfamiliar with the different types of drugs available, nor the various methods of use. But from almost all the approximately 40 students in the room I received an overwhelming message: fear campaigns such as the anti-smoking campaign are very effective. The as show kids how uncool it is to smoke. Currently, some influential figures in the lives of the average teenager send deadly Drugs messages. It could be a band like Oasis-who I happen to like-or singer Evan Dando, who put their song writing ability down to a permanent drug haze, or actor River Phoenix, whose death from a drug cocktail is attributed to merely 'bad karma', that are inspiration for a student to give it a go. We need to fight back with a campaign illustrating how you can be successful, drug free and cool at the same time. We need some positive role models. The second demand of students was for a real life education campaign that was not couched in the usual rhetoric of a 'teacher knows best' classroom. On the real life effects of drugs, we all have much to learn. For example, I was surprised by Billy Moore's comment that as a professional footballer he cannot stay in a room where people may be smoking marijuana, because the smoke from a joint will penetrate the pores of his skin. Of course, with the random drug tests in professional sport this could mean the end of a sporting career. In fact, it was a guest crown prosecutor who surprised students with a detailed treatise on exactly what goes into uppers like ecstasy, acid, and other laboratory manufactured drugs. He spoke of the contaminated backyard stills where drugs are mixed and cut with various substances in an environment that is a far cry from the sterile surroundings where legal pharmaceuticals are made. He concluded if drug users could see and smell these garage factories they would not be so keen to ingest the finished products. We must be honest with ourselves and our young Australians. There must be a certain degree of acceptance in this battle. Drugs are part of our community, like it or not. So let us teach our young people not merely that drugs. are bad but that drugs can interfere with achieving long-term goals and can bring about future health problems. We should respond to the calls from students in my electorate with a two-pronged attack. Firstly, we must prove to young Australians that drugs are uncoo!. Secondly, we must educate our youth and allow them to make informed decisions as mature, young adults. If we do not respond, then Anna Wood will be just one of many young people in our society who, after making a flippant and ill informed decision, ended their lives in a manner which allowed them no opportunity to say, 'This was a dumb idea after all.' Question resolved in the affirmative. Job Seeker Allowance (Question No. 2112) Mr Barry Jones asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 25 August 1997: (1) What social security entitlements does an unemployed person have who sets up as a sole trader and is then seeking work on his or her own account. (2) If such a sole trader is able to provide work for another person, is he or she entitled to a job seeker's allowance. (3) Is it an anomaly that job seeker allowance is not available to help the creation of a trading entity or small business that provides work for other unemployed persons. Mr Ruddock-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (1) To be eligible for Newstart Allowance a customer must firstly be unemployed. A person who is substantially involved in running a business would not normally be regarded as unemployed. An exception to this is where the business is on a small scale and designed to be a supplement rather than an alternative to wages and is compatible with taking a full-time job. Where it is determined that a person is unemployed for the purpose of meeting the eligibility requirements for Newstart Allowance, they must also satisfy a set of requirements known as the activity test. A major requirement of the activity test is that a person must be actively searching for and willing to undertake any suitable paid work. A self-employed person generally must meet this job search requirement, including not refusing an offer of employment because it interferes with their business. Sub-contractors or other self-employed people, who hire themselves and/or their plant or equipment out for particular jobs, may be regarded as unemployed when out of work but they too must meet the above tests. In certain circumstances, the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) may approve the development of self employment opportunities as an activity which satisfies activity test requirements and Newstart Allowance can be paid. (2) The provision of work for another person would not in itself disqualify a person from receiving Newstart Allowance. However, it is unlikely that a sole trader in these circumstances would be considered to be unemployed or be able to satisfy the activity test requirements. If, for example, a sub-contractor obtains some casual work, he or she would not be disqualified from payment on the basis that they employed another person. Where the work was of a casual nature, they would be treated in a similar manner to other casual workers and would generally remain qualified for payment, subject to the income test. Self-employed people earning income may receive reduced payments or no payments at all. (3) Newstart Allowance provides income support to unemployed people who are looking for work or who are engaged in other labour market related activities. There is no anomaly in denying an unemployment payment to someone who is not unemployed. People who have been on Newstart Allowance for at least 6 months can undertake self employment development (SED) as part of their activity agreement. SED can be approved as part of a person's activity agreement where the CES is satisfied that the business will be commercially viable within 12 months of commencement and it is likely to provide the person with full-time employment at a level of income at least equivalent to the rate of Newstart Allowance. The approval is intended to be for the developmental stage only and it is expected that once the business commences, income support will cease and healthy, fair competition will prevail. In addition, the New Enterprise Incentive Scheme (NElS), administered by the CES, provides income support for up to 12 months to people setting up and running businesses, as well as training in business management.
